reviewText:
The Walking Dead is a story-driven adventure game.
Though it feels more like an interactive story, than an actual game, it still got me from the first minute.
There is not much gameplay in it, you walk here and there and talk to other people and every now and then you need to make choices (for most of them there is a short time limit).
There are a lot likable (and not so likable) characters. Together with the choices you have to make, it is a thrilling and emotional experience.

Highly recommended if you like story-driven games and/or adventures.

reviewText:
Loved every part of this game.
Some people may argue that your choices don't actually matter, and I'd say they are not wrong... But they are not right either. The choices you make in the game may not have an impact on the end itself, but it will have an impact on how the story gets told to you. Will you become a respectable man, or will you be an ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• throughout the entire game? The choice is yours.

What does matter here is the travel, and not the destination.

The graphics are enjoyable; you really feel like you're part of the original comics universe. The game developpers also had the good idea to create their own story and not simply take the comics story. This is not a simple adaptation of the comics books, this is a parallel story which does not make some fan services; the references to the books are smart and really not invasive.

All in all, this is a simple, yet very enjoyable story-driven point-and-click, merging some humor and a lot of drama in a good and smart enough interactive story.

Turn the lights off, and play it alone or with someone else, and discuss about the choices you should make or should have made.

A must play!

reviewText: I really have to say this game is almost perfection. I was worried about it going in that it would focus too much on random zombie action and take away from WHY we love the Walking Dead. We like it because it actually has story and character development. Not just random gore. The game is a point and click adventure. If that's not your type of game wait for the crappy FPS coming out soon. (That I'll still probably play.) The timed decisions mechanic is a great move from the developers. Only have seconds to make a split choice really ripens the tension and panic of your situations. On top of that the game has a lot of content. 5 full episodes that can be a couple hours each to finish, with different paths and outcomes depending on how your handle things. Every choice you make can affect you way later down the road to similar to the style Mass Effect recently took.\n\nIf your a fan of the show, comics, zombies in general and like a good game that will challenge your wit and morals, get it.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Nightmare of the living dead
The Walking Dead: Season 1 is gaming's equivalent of being put through the emotional ringer. That a single game could pack so much surprise, scares, shocks (and on numerous occasions I might add) and raw emotion into its core package is proof that gaming has grown up and is a definite showcase for all those naysayers out there that still believe gaming is a children's hobby.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=338123407
Having never read the comics by Robert Kirkman or seen the television show upon which this is all based, I went in without a single notion of what to expect and was continually surprised and often dismayed at every corner. Playing as escaped convict - Lee Everett, who has a murky and tragic past - it's not long into the game before you meet up with a young girl named Clementine who is holed up in her tree house after a zombie outbreak in which her caregiver is attacked and killed whilst her parents are out of town on a business trip. Agreeing to accompany the young girl to the city her parents are visiting it becomes clear that not only is Lee looking for redemption but to also to once again feel the need to be needed after a tragic act of violence brought on by a betrayal resulted in his incarceration.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=338122543
It's quite astonishing that the game has managed to elicit the protector in all of us just from reading commentary for the game on forum websites from other gamers alike. The level of care the main protagonist develops for the young Clementine over the course of all 5 episodes is truly one of gamings greatest achievements. For the first time ever I really cared about the safety of my little gaming charge and having to witness her grow up so quickly due to the surrounding circumstances was incredibly bittersweet.

The Walking Dead: Season 1 keeps things very clean and simple in terms of adventuring and item collecting, not like those classics of yester-year with inventories as long a piece of string and more items than you knew what to do with. You will only ever carry one or two items on you at any given point and they act simply as devices to move the story along. Along the way you will also be continually forced to make tough judgement calls that could put you in favor or disfavor with certain individuals of the rag-tag group of survivors you find yourself with which slightly influences the outcome of the story.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=338121505
Whilst one can argue that there is actually very little gameplay available throughout the entire play-through the emphasis here is on the tale of survivors at what looks like the end of the world as we know it. There are very few lulls which results in the game moving at a frantic clip. One thing is for sure, when the story to your game is this good (and I mean seriously good), you can't blame the developers for wanting to hurry things along or add that sense of urgency that I imagine would be required if facing the end of days.

The Walking Dead: Season 1 has one of the finest script and voice over character work you are likely to experience in a computer game. This is one of those experiences where everything comes together in alignment so perfectly you would almost think it was celestial. Playing to each characters good and bad nature, each member of the groups feels fully fleshed out and human, firmly rooted to an end of the world reality that sees them respond in a real and relatable ways. This is one of those marvelous games which has the player feeling a range of emotions so don't be surprised if you find yourself shedding a tear or two at some of the games more gut-wrenching sequences. Highly, highly recommended!

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is an episodic interactive story adventure developed and published by Telltale Games based on The Walking Dead comic book series.  The game consist of five separate chapters which we released spread out across 2012.

The game takes place shortly after the start of a zombie apocalypse in the US state of Georgia. Most of the characters are all unique to the game. You play the role of a university professor, who is also a convicted murderer. You rescue and care for a little called called Clementine.

Very much unlike other adventure games, there is hardly any puzzle solving to be found in The Walking Dead; it focuses mainly on the story and character development and relationships. The story is heavily effected by dialogue choices and actions taken during quick time events - these choices will often lead to game altering changes such as a character being killed off etc.  All of the choices and events from one episode are carried over onto the next. I have also leaned since completing the game; that Telltale actually tracked the choices made too, and helped them to influence their writing in later episodes in the story.

You play the game mainly in a third person perspective and the camera changes depending on the scenery and objects around the player. You are constantly in communication with the rest of your group of survivors; you will build friendships, enemies and you will bond with most of the characters in someway. You will be emotionally attached to them, especially the young child, Clementine. While most of the game is also based around the dialogue, there are a number of quick time events throughout the series, normally I am not a huge fan of QTEs, but these are required in the story in order to get their point across and to at least keep you conscious of your surroundings when playing.

Graphics do not play a huge role in this game; it is by far the least important aspect to be seen. Saying that; the art style is nice and many developers should learn from this that having top of the range graphics isn't always the be all and end all for when creating a game.

The story is probably the best I have ever seen/heard in a video game; you will be drawn in from the minute you start interacting with different characters, learning about their backstory, building bonds. There are so many twists and turns in the story to keep you guessing too. By the end, if you are like me, you'll be a complete and utter emotional wreck with that the cast have gone through. This is one of the only games that has almost brought me to tears.

Since the game doesn't resolve around fast paced action other than the QTEs, there isn't any real difficulty; there is no wrong" choice when it comes to dialogue
date: you are free to let the story develop however you choose.\n\nEach of the chapters level design are so well thought out; there are tons of objects to interact with
recommended: pick up and use with you in future situations. If it is of any interest; then you will be able to do something with it. The art style really gets across how doomed the civilized world is in the ruined remains of cities and towns.\n\nI have run through The Walking Dead two times now; my first play through was back when it originally came out during the sporadic release of the episodes
hoursPlayed:
and just recently when I played through them all in a big binge. It is very rare that I want to play through a game again a second time; and The Walking Dead offers exactly the same excitement the second time around; you make different choices allowing the story to change and adapt to them. The whole game takes about fourteen hours to get through all of the chapters; so you are looking at a really good length game/story too.

The game can be played using a controller too - which is a nice touch given that this is the perfect sort you could play while sitting back on the sofa and soaking up the story.  I also had no other technical problems while playing.

Most people already have The Walking Dead; and most will probably have already played it given it's age now. But this is a genre defining game that has brought the adventure games right back to the forefront of PC gaming. You need to experience this heart wrenching tale. Even if zombies aren't your thing; you will get emotionally hooked from the get go. Do your self a favor and play this masterpiece.

If you found this review helpful

reviewText:
By and large, most choice-driven games have followed the same formula, inviting you to make your mark in the world by deciding if you want to be ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad,‚Äù and accepting the binary nature of existence. But in the post-apocalyptic world of The Walking Dead, where the titular dead walk the decaying earth, the notion of good and bad is somewhat dated. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúright‚Äù when right can mean shooting an innocent child before it can turn into a flesh-eating beast, and there‚Äôs no ‚Äúwrong‚Äù when wrong can mean stealing the supplies you need to survive from those just as needy as you. The Walking Dead is the story of the choices you can‚Äôt live with, and the choices you can, coming together to create an experience as depressing and pessimistic as it is remarkable and memorable.

The Walking Dead never pretends to be anything less than a cruel, dour analysis of humanity‚Äôs downfall. You‚Äôre tossed into the cuffs of Lee Everett, a convicted murderer on his way to prison when the first episode begins. In the opening moments, his police escort is sidetracked by the zombie apocalypse, freeing Lee into a world that‚Äôs not nearly as comfortable as a jail cell would've been. Soon, he‚Äôs joined by the young Clementine, a child left on her own after her parents took a poorly timed vacation and her babysitter contracted a bad case of the flesh munchies. And off into the new, horrible world Lee goes, hoping to find Clementine‚Äôs parents despite knowing that they‚Äôre likely dead; off to find sanctuary when he doubts one even exists.

In stark contrast to the rest of gaming, The Walking Dead is more focused on what you do than how you do it. There aren‚Äôt many traditional puzzles, per se, as much as there are tasks that you‚Äôre asked to perform to move the story forward. Menial activities like finding batteries for a radio or starting up a train aren‚Äôt all that engaging by themselves, but they serve a very necessary pacing purpose, as well as give you a chance to explore the world a bit and get to know the characters better. If you‚Äôre looking to rampage around Georgia popping the heads off of undead monsters, you‚Äôre better served by one of the many other zombie games on the market.

Though some might be turned off by this minimization of traditional gameplay, it works well in the context of the game. The effect you have on the world is fairly minimal by design, mixing together Telltale‚Äôs point-and-click adventure game style with a smattering of quick-time events and choice-driven dialogue. This amorphous take on gameplay works very well to make you feel like you‚Äôre a part of the world, without allowing you to go too far off the rails. But just because you‚Äôre not allowed to stray too far off the beaten path, doesn‚Äôt mean you don‚Äôt have an actual influence--on the contrary, your words and actions actually play an integral part in crafting the world.

Incredibly strong writing and voice-acting give the narrative the spotlight it deserves. The vast majority of the characters you interact with are well-developed, and it‚Äôs hard not to feel compassion for even the meanest of the bunch, making you actually care about who you foster relationships with and who you choose to disappoint. What‚Äôs more, your actions have an impact not just on the events that you encounter, but in how people treat you. Don‚Äôt back up Kenny when his son is accused of being bitten, and he might not have your back a few episodes later when you need him to. Side with Lilly when she‚Äôs trying to ration the food, and she might respect you enough to help you in the coming episodes.

Your choices, both large and small, have repercussions, and can change the course of the remaining episodes--even if it‚Äôs only a slight shift. Split-second choices made later in the game can rewrite how people react to you regardless of how you‚Äôve treated them up to that point, making each and every action all the more important. Inaction, too, is usually an option, amplified by the inclusion of a timer that makes it possible to completely miss a chance at making a decision, forcing you to sit on the sidelines and watch whatever your indifference hath wrought.

These decisions wouldn't be as emotional if it didn‚Äôt feel like there was something on the line, but there is: Clementine. The hopelessness of the world would be infectious if not for her constant optimism, giving you something to fight for. She‚Äôs slow to adapt to the fact that good and evil are now meaningless, and her innocence keeps the concept of hope alive in the survivors. More importantly, it makes it harder to justify going against what you think is truly ‚Äúright,‚Äù since you know you‚Äôre going to have her big, sad eyes staring up at you. It‚Äôs heartbreaking and motivational, inspirational and depressing.

The Walking Dead‚Äôs success isn‚Äôt in creating a Choose Your Own Adventure game with hundreds of possible outcomes and limitless plotlines. Instead, it reflect the reality of life, reminding you that many of the choices you‚Äôre given have predetermined outcomes, and some things simply can‚Äôt be changed. And yet, this undermining of everything that makes The Walking Dead unique is arguably its greatest triumph. Despite not always being in control, The Walking Dead makes you feel as though you are. Even though you can‚Äôt always save someone from death, you can give it your best try, shaping the person you are. And it‚Äôs up to you to decide if it‚Äôs worth the effort to change what, in all likelihood, can not be changed.

Sure, you can replay it to see what else would happen, but that won‚Äôt change anything. It won‚Äôt change that you‚Äôre not going to leave The Walking Dead happy. You‚Äôll feel like you made mistakes. You‚Äôll feel like you could have done better, if you gave it another go. At best, you‚Äôll leave without any regrets, knowing that you did the best you could do. The Walking Dead deals in a spectrum of emotion that few other games dare to take on, and it does so with aplomb. It‚Äôs utterly triumphant, crafting a narrative that proves the power of the medium by embracing what makes it unique, leading to one of the most memorable gameplay experiences ever created.

reviewText:
Telltale have made a game in The Walking Dead that helps redefine the Point & Click genre and bring into a more modern era. Alongside that they've truely mastered the art of 'choice'. Many games have attempted to bring the player choice and consequences, but few have managed to do it with great success. Most of the time the player is left with Ending 1 or Ending 2 even though they made 100 'crucial' choices throughout the game.

The Walking Dead, however, manages to really make the player feel that their choices matter, if not only in the game than morally and emotionally too. It achieves this by having a very story driven game that is supported by some of the best characters in a computer game. Characters that you don't really like (by design) due to their very human faults and personal baggage, yet as the journey progresses you become fond of them - they become part of your group.
That's when you know Telltale have you hooked in.

They manage to pull off The Walking Dead dynamic far greater, and with more ease, than the TV show has ever achieved in 3+ seasons (to date). Sure, computer games have the benefit of having no real watershed or TV Regulations to censor it's content; yet that's not what makes The Walking Dead game effective.
It's the high emotion dialect, the interaction between the characters and the observations you make as Lee (... and you will find yourself becoming Lee). All of this happens as a great underplayed soundtrack supports the drama, which at times pays a little tribute to previous Zombie Movie music (such as the electronic throbs of Dawn of the Dead's music).

When I look back I find no real fault in The Walking Dead, as long as you're aware of what you're letting yourself become a part of. This isn't an action game - it's one of the best emotionally driven interactive stories you will play. It's very easy to see why this game won so many awards in 2012.

So if you're a fan of strong characters, story driven gameplay, or are perhaps intrigued at the prospect of a modernised 'Point and Click' adventure then you should check out The Walking Dead. The good news is that you'll be able to play all 5 Chapters of Season 1 today, which will put you in a good place for Season 2 (which will hopefully be released early 2014).
The bad news is... you'll have to wait for the drip feed of each chapter in Season 2 to be released...

reviewText:
This game is awesome, nothing less.

I got 18hs straight playing it, just cannot stop until finish, through a really good and very tense narrative and different action/gameplay style who puts you in the middle of difficult decisions, which have direct impact on what's going on next.

You have not always the time to think about, just react, but if your reactions are bad you can have troubles now or after, consequences brought by your decisions. And just like on real life, some of them you will have to carry with you until the end of story.

Although you have to follow a lot of dialogues, more than real action, you cannot simply sit down and think, most of times. You have to be ready to act or make decisions, so you just stare at the screen, and not rarely you can feel you're really there, a deep immersion factor.

Soundtrack is decent, matching the tension. Graphics are wonderful, and history too.
I can see just two problems about that game:

You can lost a split second, confusing by the controls, and sometimes it's lethal. The good news is that although the game have not a better save system than autosave, if you die on the middle of an action scene the autosave brings you exactly at the point you died.

Also, the game have a lot of replay value, if you think you can have different decisions to make and different things to handle according on how you act before. But the game needs a way to skip some cut scenes or even dialogues faster, for those who previously finished.

One of the best and imaginative games i've ever played.

reviewText:
I highly recommend the Walking Dead. This is more of an interactive story that anyone can play wrapped together like a point and click adventure. Most of the time, you're just watching a great story play out with excellent voice acting. It is based more on the comic book than the TV show, but the first episode does have a character from the TV show in a cameo. The story will have you playing Lee, a man that starts off in police custody until a zombie apocalypse happens. You will meet a little girl named Clemontine and basically be her guardian.  The story is littered with crazy and hotheaded characters, along with pleasant and reasonable ones for a nice contrast.

In this story, you make decisions that affect lives. Who lives and who dies. After completing the game on PSN and going through it on Steam, I have a pair of play throughs contrasting. Even small choices like who you side with in arguments will drastically affect the dialog, but not the story. Everything will unfold in a way that is pre determined, but its always your choices that will get you to the same place.

Basically someone will always have to die and someone will always hate you. The story gets pretty intense and they talk about topics that no other video game would touch, such as killing kids. Its not all heavy, there is some humor sprinkled in and moments of down time. Because of the choices, this warrants several play throughs, but nothing really changes the game, so much as the dialog and how people react to you.

The game is broken into 2+ hour episodic chunks that come out every so often in 5 episode 'seasons.' You can either buy the episodes one by one, or buy the season pass. There is even an interlude episode to bring you from the first to second season. Personally, I say wait until a season is over to buy the entire season than play episode by episode month after month when they come out.

reviewText:
About the Game
The Walking Dead game is a telltale game that tells the story of a man named Lee who is on his way to prison for committing a murder. The trip takes an unexpected turn as his life turn into a living hell.

Storyline/Gameplay
Just like it's TV series counterpart. The Walking Dead game is not about killing zombies. There is barely an action in the game. TWD focuses more on the psychological effect of a world crisis into the human mind. The game will handle mostly about frustrations and being smart. You could say this game involves a lot of puzzle-like gameplay utilizing what's around to survive. The puzzles aren't that hard but it might be tricky for some and it can get really boring and repetitive.

Mechanics
This game is taillored by how you play."

Graphics

how the entire world and character are designed makes this game really good overall.

Final thoughts

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:The Walking Dead by Telltale Games is an episodic video game based on the popular Comic Book series of the same title which was made mainstream by an equally popular TV series, also of the same title. The game features 5 'Episodes' with a 6th Episode as DLC. It boasts an outstanding plot, great characters and immersive choice and consequence based storytelling.

You are Lee Everett, a professor on his way to prison for the murder of a US State Senator who was having an affair with Lee's wife. The game starts with Lee at the back of a police car when he met an accident that wounded him and killed his officer escort. All hell breaks loose when he discovers that the dead now walks and is hungry for human flesh but, in his desperate search for help, he stumbles across a young girl named Clementine. Follow their struggles as they try to survive a terrifying and deadly world in this post-apocalyptic suspense game where every choice you make directly impacts the lives of the people around you.

PROS:+ Great use of 3D cell-shaded art style
+ Excellent example of Consequence based choices and Story (The game's biggest selling point)
+ Great Story
+ Great voice acting
+ Memorable characters
+ True to the Comics source material
+ Good game time and nice replayability
+ Guilt inducing choices
+ Stress inducing choices

CONS:- Restrictive camera
- Very small maps with no room for exploration (I don't mean it should be sandbox, but it would have been nice if the players had more leg room)
- Gameplay is a bare minimum (not much to do)
- Some choices have no real impact to the overall plot
- Tendency to have some boring scenes and segements

CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME. RECOMMENDED for both fans of the comics and gamers who are into good stories and plots. The Walking Dead by Telltale Games is the best example of immersive consequence based storytelling I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. The story is top notch with a well written and well round characters who were excellently voiced. The art style works in the game's favor as the cell-shaded world captures the look, feel and tone of the comics.

Gameplay, sad to say, is a bare minimum, nothing to do more than make decisions. Some of the action sequences are heart pounding, but in it's core, its just a regular Quick Time Event scenario. The game also suffers from a restrictive camera with some odd angles. Despite these though, the game is still WORTH IT whether it be full price or sale price. This is a MUST HAVE game even for just the experience.

---------------------------------------------------------

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

reviewText:
The absolute certainty about The Walking Dead Game is that it will surprise you with its magnificence. It is not a game for everyone, but to those who appreciate other genre of video games will simply love how unique and fantastic 'TWDG' really is. In fact, it the most unique game I have ever played and provided me perhaps my most favorite experience playing a video game.

The mechanics of TWDG is essentially point and click. The core elements will not have you constantly shooting zombies or platforming of any sort, it is basically a fantastic story that you are apart of, you can investigate the surrounding or engage in conversations with other survivors. But there are two main parts about the game that make it so incredible. The journey you go through as a player is memorable, each episode is innovative and different with the current and new characters really engage you into the story.

But perhaps the number one reason why TWDG is an incredible game is how the writers managed to pull off the amazing relationship and chemistry between Lee and Clementine. Lee is Clem's father figure, each conversation you have has significance and you really care for her throughout, you simply can't hate her.

All I can say is The Walking Dead Game will be a game like none you have played before, its cheap and worth a try because by the time you beat the story, it will be one of your favorite games ever.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gNTJWSncQ0U

The Walking Dead fits into the comic canon and features cameos from popular characters but it's real focus is on original characters. You take control of Lee Everett, a college professor who has been convicted of a serious crime and beings the game in the back of a cop car. After escaping from his cuffs and surviving a near fatal encounter with a walker Lee stumbles into the home of Clementine, an eight year old girl whose parents left for Savannah prior to the onset of the zombie epidemic. Her innocence juxtaposes Lee's dark past and she is in many respects a source of redemption as Lee takes it upon himself to protect her and help reunite her with her family. The relationship between Lee and Clementine carries the experience. Clementine herself is very likable and despite her age she never comes off as too needy or whiny. Lee himself comes off as sympathetic and  cultivating his relationship with Clementine is an emotional investment rarely found in games.

Where The Walking Dead's tale succeeds is in its focus on the dark side of humanity rather than the danger of undead flesh eating cannibals. At times it can be brutal and gut-wrenching. There are conflicts within your party, conflicts with bandits and clashes with other survivors. These situations are more compelling than facing off with walkers and offer an appreciable degree of moral ambiguity, generally culminating in a brutally nihilistic resolution. This moral ambiguity is important since most of the gameplay in The Walking Dead centers around managing your relationships with those in your party. Members of your groups almost always have dissenting opinions and it breeds conflict. During conversations you get to choose how to respond and unlike other titles that allow you to voice the protagonist and make choices, The Walking Dead features a timer that prevents you from analyzing your decisions. It keeps the tension up and the conversations flowing naturally. Who you side with and what you say determines how close you are to each person and can ultimately affect how they react in future scenarios. If a character feels that you have their interests in mind they will back you and those who you oppose may become hostile to Lee.

While this sounds great on paper in practice it's not as exciting as it seems. The problem is that in spite of giving you a lot of decisions to make, The Walking Dead doesn't change much in terms of it's narrative arc. Some scenarios ask you to make a choice that to save one character causing the other to perish. These two characters generally serve the same role in the plot and there isn't a compelling reason to see both scenarios play out since you won't see any noteworthy additions to the experience. You see the same locations and partake in the same scenarios and puzzles. You as the player have little overall influence on the the narrative and the experience is cheapened by attempting to take another approach on a second playthrough since it becomes apparent very quickly how inflexible the game is. With it's episodic release schedule, it's wholly understandable that The Walking Dead doesn't feature a massive branching narrative but it would have been nice if the path you take to the conclusion of each episode could vary. As it stands there isn't much replayability in The Walking Dead.

Puzzles and gameplay in the Walking Dead are rudimentary, some sequences have you aiming a weapon to take down a few walkers, quick time events are sprinkled throughout the game's five episodes and DLC and there are only a few puzzles. While The Walking Dead gleefully avoids the obtuse puzzles that characterize many point and click games it's simplicity can be off putting to veteran gamers. Puzzles have very apparent solutions and often the only objects you can pick up are the ones used to solve a puzzle. Having a few red herrings or multiple solutions to a scenario might have made these sequences more rewarding.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is a narrative-driven adventure about a zombie apocalypse that has the feel of an interactive comic book.  This is executed perfectly by Telltale with a cell-shaded art style that mimics a comic and a very well-written story that tailors the story to the choices and actions of the player.

Gameplay is very simple.  The player is often presented with choice-driven dialog.  The narrative is carefully paced through player interactions with objects and persons in the environment and the action pieces are accomplished via quick-time events.  This style of gameplay is perfect since it does not burden the player with complex mechanics and allows for focus on the plot and story elements.

As I have already mentioned, the story is very well written.  Characters are well developed to the point that I cared about them.  Tough decisions are often presented which were almost always painful to make.  What really impresses me most is that this game is presented as a survival story and the zombies are often not the worst dangers to the team.  This really makes me think deeper about the primal nature of humans and some of the disturbing things we would do to survive at all costs.  This is not your typical zombie game.  I have never watched the TV series that this is based on, but if the narrative for those shows are like this game, I may just start watching these.

This is a very good game for those who like narrative-driven adventures.  I highly recommend.


In addition, if you are an achievement hunter, it is very easy to 100% this game by simply doing a single playthrough.

reviewText:
When it was first announced that The Walking Dead would be getting a video game version, you wouldn't have been crazy to assume it would be some kind of survival horror shooter. After all, zombie shooters seem to be all the rage these days. But The Walking Dead was never really about shooting zombies, instead focusing on the horrible things people do when trying to survive. Zombies aren't as scary as people pushed to their limits, and it just takes a couple walking corpses to get people to show their worst. So instead of some sort of bullet-filled slaughter-fest, Telltale has decided to create a socially focused point-and-click adventure game.

On the surface, this genre fits The Walking Dead superbly. The game forces you to make harsh decisions constantly. Nearly every dialogue choice is timed, forcing you to answer with your gut instinct. As a result, the main character Lee Everett very quickly becomes a reflection of yourself, causing you to empathize with his plight. Though this does get annoying at some points, most notably points where there really isn't any sort of urgency to your response, it does successfully prevent gamers from exploiting the system to always pick the right" response.

The decision-making in The Walking Dead is probably the most enjoyable part of the game. Let's get something straight right now: There is no happy ending to a zombie apocalypse. At times
date: you will have to choose who lives and who dies
recommended: and that is a weight that will sit heavy on your shoulders. Very simple decisions could mean the difference between surviving and becoming zombie chow

reviewText: The Walking Dead was an emotional and an adventerous journey. It's one of those rare games that make you feel for the characters and get attached to them and their story. While the gameplay is pretty simple, it's the decisions that you have to make which are hard, too hard at times. The circumstances and situations that are portrayed in the story makes you see how tough decision taking in life can be. If it''s tough for you to decide something major in a video game, about fictional characters then I can only imagine how tough it would be in real life. In some cases where I had to decide the fate of someone who killed my friend or something similar and was clearly a bad guy, even then compassion comes into play and even deciding the fate of a murderer gets really tough. The game makes you do brutal things. Physically normal under  such circumstances as presented in the game but emotionally brutal.\n\nThe story of this game is grasping and really interesting from the start. The decision making and choosing what or what not to speak is a great factor that makes the game. The quick time events are great as well. This game would make you feel contemplative many times, sometimes a bit melancholy, might even make you shed a few tears and would also make you feel enraged at which points you would feel like killing a character or beating the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of them but when the game actually gives you the choice to do that, it would become a hard choice. Funny how the human mind works.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead TV show on AMC has broken worldwide audience records and every new season just keeps upping the ante on the previous one. This game is based on the official TV show, but its story is different with new characters, although they still evolve in the exact same zombie world as in the original TV show.

There have been too many zombie-themed games prior to The Walking Dead game, but the latter infuses renewed energy into an over-exploited genre. Its primary strength lies in its story. The graphics and game engine are particularly fine-tuned to deliver the intended experience. Oh, what a fantastic story! The script is simply superb and pushes the limits all the time. You can never be sure of what's going to happen next. Any of the main characters can meet with some unexpected event and die. You learn that early in the first episode. The game itself revolves around your decisions and the consequences of your acts will guide the rest of the gameplay. The first season comprises of 5 episodes plus 1 DLC which bridges the storyline between season 1 and 2.

Throughout the game, it really surprised me that some of decisions i made from episode 1 still carried over to the other episodes, until the last one. The characters reacted differently to what i had expected as they recalled some of my actions in the previous episodes of the game. This changed the game and ultimately the game experience. You can replay this game several times and depending on your choices when interacting with the characters and the game itself, you will be able to explore The Walking Dead game's universe even further. This game reveals surprises at every corner. The human factor and the line between what's morally right and what's needed to survive is often blurred. You will have some difficult choices to make as the story evolves but sometimes you just have to do what it takes to get out of the situation alive.

It's zombie apocalypse and civilization has ceased to exist. You play as one of the survivors in a small group, not knowing what to expect. The game delivers a truly excellent story, right next to the high standards set by the original TV series. This title is basically half movie and half game. Explore and appreciate the realism and consequences behind your every click and turn.

reviewText:
Oh man, the characters and story is so much better and keeps you way more involved than you think it would. It‚Äôs up there with the first season of The Walking Dead tv series before it devolved into a sh*tty soap opera in its later seasons. I‚Äôm hoping season 2 and 3 of the game doesn‚Äôt make the same mistakes the tv series made.  Apparently this is based on the comic book universe and not the tv series universe, so any main characters you run into in this like (SPOILER)‚Ä¶..Glenn, is the Glenn from the comic book universe.

Things are constantly happening and escalating which keeps tension high and you slightly on edge throughout, you just know something f*cked up is about to happen most of the time. It‚Äôs not like the tv show where there were a lot of filler episodes in the later seasons. There‚Äôs 5 episodes in the game, and one DLC episode each lasting around 2 hours in length. Each episode has you go to a different area, so your surrounding environment is always different. The DLC episode 400 days is way too short, and seems to be only for introducing characters that will be in season 2.

The characters in this are really great, Lee and Clementine being the two standouts. The writing, character interactions and voice acting all comes across as authentic and better written than the tv series.

Don‚Äôt be fooled by the cartoony aesthetic for the game, this is maybe the darkest and depressingly bleak game I have ever played (in a good way), or at least finished. The ambient and sombre musical scores really add to it as well. Episode 3 is especially f*cked up, putting you in situations and having you make choices you REALLY don‚Äôt want to make (‚Äúquack‚Äù, if you‚Äôve played it you know what I mean by that). This game is the definition of giving you the feels, getting to you in an emotional way which many games and other types of media like tv or films even fail to do most of the time.

Saying all of that though, the actual ‚Äúgame‚Äù elements are severely lacking. I know it‚Äôs a point and click game, but they have you do the most basic searching and puzzle solving you could think of in a game. Example being, you need to find a pencil, and when you go to ‚Äúlook‚Äù in the RV that‚Äôs literally the only thing you can interact with, there‚Äôs no choices, or other objects to pick up. Most of the time it will be telling you to find a weapon, and there‚Äôs only one weapon there, there was only once or twice where it actually let you choose between different weapons.

Also the overall narrative only has one trajectory, you will always end up in the same place, at a certain moment one character will always die, you get to choose who lives and dies, but later on if that character dies and you wonder if you had chosen the other person instead, would it have turned out differently?‚Ä¶..it doesn‚Äôt. The choices you make and dialogue options you choose may affect your appearance or how certain characters treat you, but overall it‚Äôs the same story whatever you choose.

Luckily the characters and writing are strong enough to overcome those drawbacks. Is it worth you playing it instead of watching a walkthrough on youtube? I would say yes, depending on how you answer questions or who you side with, you can find out more about people in your group so it has some replay value in that sense, and your playthrough would be different enough that it‚Äôs worth playing. Also when it‚Äôs actually you clicking a button to smash a zombies head in, or making tough emotional decisions, you are way more invested in the outcome than when you are a passive observer.

reviewText:
This game was incredible to play. Every choice, response and action that you do or do not do affects what happens next and can be devastating or rewarding. I played this game using headphones, in the quiet so I could immerse myself completely into this game and it was amazing. It was nothing what I expecting when I loaded up the game, it's not all kicking Zombie-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, but progressing with your companions, earning their trust and unavoidantly - destroying it too. There were some jumpscares and a gruesome scene (at least for my choice anyway) near the end of the story and it was rather shocking.

The whole last chapter pretty much had me tense, assuming I knew what was coming. Midway when I finally got Clem, everything was falling apart. The last scene is rather heartbreaking and properly had those water molecules flowing from my eyes, it was too much and was expertly crafted.

The music alone makes this game amazing. From intense scenes to almost silence. Without the Music and sound effects I don't think this game would have been half as immersive as it is.

Can't wait to buy Season 2.

If you haven't played this game yet, you're missing out, big time.

reviewText:
What A GAME!...

Brilliant story, interesting characters... Sound, voice acting, art style, direction, music, gameplay... Everything is SO incredibly good that words can't describe all the experience of playing this game.

From the very beginning the story catches you and you feel attached to Clementine and survival becomes even more important because of her.

All characters are very well written, all of them will build some connection with you, letting the fate of the group in your hands and making you take the (hard) decisions that will affect all the story.

The gameplay is pretty simple and works very well, the puzzles aren't that hard but all of them are very well designed. The greatest thing in the gameplay is the timer on the choices you have to make, it keeps the tension on the story.

It IS a masterpiece and you must play it. Even if you don't like zombies.

reviewText:
I hate zombie games and other zombie related stuff...And i loved this game!
Dead Block, Dead Pixels, Dead Head Fred, Dead Effect, Dead Island, Dead Nation, Dead Rising, Deadlight, Dead Space, Dead State...

Zombies should be only in RPGs where necromancers brought 'em back to walk on Earth. At least that would make sense. OK, having couple of zombie games is fine...But this is out of hand! I don't understand why people keep eating this s**t up. Most zombie games, like 3/4, are not even mediocre! They're downright horrible!

This game tho. This game right here. This, this is a masterpiece. The storytelling, voice acting, character development, the music...It's all so very well done.
If you're a bit more sensitive then you will cry...A LOT. The game does a great job of keeping the story intense at all times. You just can't wait to see what happens next.

There's not much gameplay but that's fine in my opinion. We play adventure games for the story and this is why i like TellTales new take on the adventure genre. The formula they have in their latest titles is just so perfect for storytelling!
The gameplay is there tho. Some quick time events, a bit of walking and picking up items...That's pretty much it.
I recommend using a controller and playing while sitting on a couch 'cus you want to sit back and enjoy the story...Like you're watching a good movie. A long movie.
Took me about 10h to finish the entire game. That's about 2h per chapter. That's like a length of a full The Walking Dead" season. Only that this one is actually good and has a gripping story.

This is one of the few zombie games i recommend getting. There's not many original zombie games out there so getting a rare pearl like this is pretty much a must for every gamer."

reviewText:
I absolutely reccomend this game, even if you never watched the series.

When I started this game I was affraid that it was going to be one of those extremely predictable zombie games again, but it wasn't, it's far from predictable.
The character development is amazing, you really get to know everyone you meet in the game and get either attached to them or despise them, you will find yourself doing anything to help one character sometimes.
The story often takes unexpected turns which keeps the game interesting, and near the end it gets pretty emotional..

..really emotional, I hade to wipe some tears from my face when I saw the ending, sad but amazing, when the credits rolled after the last episode I cried, something I normally never do.

So yes, this is absolutely one of the best games I've ever played, maybe even THE best in terms of storytelling

reviewText:
+ Quality voice acting
+ Average time spent playing will surely be enough to justify the purchase
+ Audio score does much to enhance the mood and atmosphere
+ Sound effects are perfect in their use, and of admirable quality
+ Art style blends comic book textures and 3d rendering very well
+ Game relaly makes you feel like your choices have consequences attached to them
+ For the most part, plot is well-written

- Poor camera movement in many scenes
- Game suffers some pacing issues, in that some sections are extremely boring and use irrational behavior and forced tension between characters as plot devices; this causes unnecessary disasters that move the plot forward in a lazy way

reviewText:
I don't write reviews. I feel it's a waste of time and effort but I felt a need to do one for The Walking Dead.

The stylized graphics look really great to me. For the times I noticed it, the music is great and perfectly matches what you're looking at. Gameplay is your typical point and click but with keyboard movement controls and QTEs thrown in which works well. All these make for a mediocre game if not for the story which is what makes this game the masterpiece that it is.

All that being said, I hate this game. I only recommend this to get as many people as possible to suffer with me.

The game will constantly put you in situations you do not want to be in and force you to make hard decisions. Many times I wanted to stand up and walk away but the game will suck you in and compel you to keep going through its many screwed-up events. We're talking about A Song of Ice and FIre" level of screwed-up. You find yourself loving the characters and hating some but one thing you won't be able to do is be indifferent. Even the most passive gamer would find him/herself emotionally invested. I was an unwilling participant and fought as hard as I could against the poignant and visceral feelings the game stirs up but broke down at the very end.

I play games for amusement and entertainment
date: I was neither amused nor entertained but was powerless to stop myself from seeing the game through. The last time I felt this way was when I watched "Grave of Fireflies" the first time and I had to watch reruns of Modern Family and Big Bang Theory over the next few days to recover. I am currently steeling myself before firing up Season 2 and was advised to get Tales From the Borderlands as a possible antidote after.\n\nTL;DR: A masterpiece. 10/10. Will never play again. Play it and taste bitter regret afterwards. Avoid if depressive

reviewText: This game has such an amazingly gripping story, it left me with the feeling of needing more. The gameplay itself is decent, the controls are sometimes a bit unclear, but they're easy to get the hang of after an hour or so of playing.\n\nI recommend this game to anyone, even those that aren't fans of The Walking Dead comic or TV series. The story alone will have you at the edge of your seat and wanting to finish the game in one sit-down.

reviewText:
Although I am a big fan of The Walking Dead, to playing this game I got for longer time. For the first time I saw the game on YouTube. Initially, the graphics has discouraged me, but this game confirms that sometimes it doesn't matter on it. You play all the time as a teacher and murderer Lee, whose life stories are developed simultaneously with the game. With Lee you recognize the other main character - Clementine , who will also accompany you in a whole game. During the game you will know more new characters but also some of them you will lose, due to your decisions which affects the course of the game. However, in the game you have limited decision time and less able people may have a problem with selection answers. Great voices of the characters and a soundtrack perfectly complements a powerful story.

+ the diversity of the characters (some of them you will love, some of them you will hate)
+ powerful story
+ great DLC
+ Clementine ‚ô•

- you can't skip the end of every episode

DLC: 400 days
I am glad that I receive this DLC to the walking dead. For me, one of the best DLC, which I have played. It is a great complement to the main story. It consists of five stories of various characters, who will at the end meet and get together.

10/10

reviewText: The must buy for every Walking Dead fan. It's not based on the tv series. It's based on the comics and there are few cameos from those as well. Keep in mind that this game is not all about blasting thousands of zombies away. It's stories about survival and the people. In this game you have to make hard choices, usually all them have some pros and cons and will haunt you later in the game. It's a great game and this game truly is tailored by the choices made. There are even really surprising twists, which sometimes make you think that you should have done it the other way. But that's what makes this game so great. It has a great plot and all the episodes are out. So what are you waiting for? Grab it and see zombie apocalypse from the point of casual people trying to survive rather than a single hero surviving and slaying hundreds. Just warning tho, this game isn't a fairy tale. It's really depressing, but in a good way if you can say that.

reviewText:
A powerful story I got to experience, not just observe.

In an era of games about survival, The Walking Dead examines both your heart and mind, not just your trigger finger.
Will you protect yourself from threats by any means or will you try to keep your humanity? Who will you help and who will you hurt? Sometimes, even if you do your best, the worst will still come afterwards.
While not a fan of the TV series and never having read the comics, I found myself immediately immersed in the world of this game and connected with the different characters. It felt like I had to think and react in near real time. The choices I could make were often far from ideal and the conflict affected me deeply. At times my heart was lifted and many it was broken. A brilliant story with gameplay that isn't about winning, but introspection. I don't feel I can say more than what's been said about this game by others, just add myself to the collective of people who think they experienced something exceptional. Any perceived flaws are slight blemishes that can be easily looked past due to the many highlights this game offers and the total refinement of the story, in my opinion.

reviewText:
So much to say, the first of which is that THIS REVIEW CONTAINS NO SPOILERS!  If I mention anything specific, it is only a fabricated example.  That being said, let's start with the technical stuff, which is based off of the keyboard/mouse PC gameplay.

I should also mention that I've never seen the TV series, nor read the comic series that this game is based upon.  I have read that this game follows a different set of characters, so you don't have to worry about spoilers via crossovers.

MOVEMENT:  W-A-S-D or Arrow keys.

FIGHTING:  Q and E keys

SAVING/PAUSING/LOADING:

There is no option to save -- it's automatic.  Watch for a swirl of lines in the top right corner.  This is the game saving your progress.  If you exit the game or go back to the main menu, you will lose anything you've done since the last auto-save.

To pause the game, just hit the Escape key.  You'll go right back to where you left off (even in the middle of a conversation) when you continue.

THE ZOMBIES:

These are not the running, jumping, climbing, can-almost-think-type of zombie that you see in the movies as of late.  What we have in The Walking Dead are the more classic-style of the undead.  They shamble, barely have the coordination to stand upright.  They're slow because their bodies are rotting away.  They will never stop coming.

There seem to be three things they react to:  Sight, sound, and a ravenous hunger for living flesh.

To fight off the undead, rapidly hit the Q key when you see the prompt on the screen, and be ready to hit the E key to attack as soon as the prompt pops up.  Sometimes you'll have to use the mouse to aim an attack, and that's not as easy as you may think!  During fighting scenes the cursor can be hard to move around.  Make no mistake, this is definitely intentional, and a brilliant decision by the development crew.  It really adds to the reality and intensity of the situation, further immersing you in the story.

YOUR CHOICES WILL AFFECT THE WAY THE PLOT OF THE GAME.  You're told this each time you start a new chapter of the game, and it's absolutely true.  Not only do your choices carry over from one chapter to another, but also to new seasons.  We play as a man named Lee, and WE choose what his personality is like.  Is he angry and defiant?  Calm and caring?  Some combination of the two?  That's entirely up to YOU, and it will affect how the other characters interact with you.

There is not a lot of fighting, as one might expect from a title about zombigeddon.  Yes, of course we struggle, we shoot, we flee, and sometimes we die... but the primary thrust of the game is the story.  This is like no adventure game I've ever seen, seeming more like we're part of a movie, rather than playing a game.

In tense situations, as in real life, we don't have an unlimited amount of time to decide what to say or do.  We have to make some snap decisions, and it heightens the immersiveness, wrapping around our psyche, taunting, calling, making us unable to stop thinking about what's happened, and what WILL happen because of our choices.

The way interactions and inventory are handled are much different than I'm used to.  You can see small icons that show your inventory on the left-hand side of the screen, but you don't do the usual click on inventory item
date: then click on the scene" routine.  Instead
recommended: when you mouse-over a hotspot on the scene
hoursPlayed: you will see options that you can choose from (assuming that there's more than one action available.)  If it's possible to try an inventory item on that spot
voteText: you'll see it in the options.  Just use your mouse wheel or arrow keys on your keyboard to highlight your desired choice; same as you do when you're having a conversation or choosing an action to take.\n\nThis is not the kind of game where you can speed up the dialogue or skip cutscenes.  The Walking Dead is all about experiencing the story

You can see from the screenshots that the characters are done graphic art-style.  Not surprising since this is based off a comic book series.  And yet... deep within the gameplay

reviewText:
Genre: Adventure

The game is based on the comic book series from Robert Kirkman and plays in the months following a zombie apocalypse. You play Lee Everett, a convicted murderer, who was on his way to prison, when the zombie apocalypse starts. In your adventure you meet a lot of different characters, including one known from the movie series. The most important of this characters is Clementine, a little orphaned girl, that you defend on your journey throughout the game.
You have to make a lot of tough decisions in this game and the cool thing is that at the end you can see how the other gamers decided to play the game.

From the storytelling part this is probably one of the best games in the last years.

Positive:
+ very good storytelling
+ nice comicstyle graphics
+ good voice actors
+ breathtaking moments
+ you make decisions, that influence the game in a way...

Negative:
- ... but in the end don't matter that much
- episode format means that you have to wait some months to play the next chapter (outdated, as the game is completely available)

In the end this is a very great game and a must play for every fan of adventures, zombie stories and i recommend everybody else just to try it out. It is worth it.

Fun gameplay: ca. 14 hours

Achievements:

Type: Playing
Difficulty: Very Easy
Time needed: Little

reviewText:
This is a preliminary review, since I'm only 1.5 hours into the game and haven't finished episode 1 yet.

Let me start off by saying that I really don't care for anything involving zombies, with the exception of two things: Shaun of the Dead[www.imdb.com] and Left 4 Dead 2. And both of these things I like in spite of the zombies, and not because of them. Other than that, I just plain don't like zombies, and I'm well and thoroughly sick of them crossing over into every medium and genre imaginable. So it means something when I say that The Walking Dead overcomes my zombie hate easily and gets to be the third exception.

As an adventure game, so far, TWD is no challenge. In fact, I've only stopped because I just hit the first puzzle" I couldn't immediately solve
date: and that's probably just because I overlooked something. Gameplay is a mix between point and click
recommended: dialogue trees and the occasional quick time event. For those of you who hate QTEs (as well you might): the QTEs presented here are telegraphed well in advance and require little timing skill
hoursPlayed: so they actually enhance the immersion rather than breaking it from having to replay them over and over again
voteText: which is the major problem I have with QTEs.\n\nThe appeal here is the story and not the gameplay
helpfulPercent: and the way it draws you in is masterfully done. Characters are introduced and you're given reasons to care for them (either positively or negatively) with a minimum of exposition and infodumping -- and that includes you
votesHelpful: the protagonist. At the same time
votesTotal: it's clear that the story is driven by you and your actions
votesFunny: and you're not just clicking through to the next cutscene. Does every choice you make matter? Probably not. Is the game adept at making you think it does? Very.\n\nThat's all I can say after 1.5 hours -- but if the rest is as good as what I've already seen

reviewText:
when i first played this game ( episode 1) i was like what is this game ?!! lol looks dumb (first time i ever heard of the walking dead also Telltale ) boy was i wrong,30 min after that i was like HELL i need the second episode ASAP ( had to wait a month for the second episode to come out) now good thing you got the full game + the dlc ( took me 20 h to complete it without the dlc) .
- first of all the plot : (the best thing you get in this game) the story is divided to 5 episodes ( back in 2012 you had to wait and pay for each episode but now you get the whole thing ) your decisions and choices will affect the main plot event in season 2 which i think its the best thing you can ask in a video game ( cause it feels like you're actually live the story not just playing ) also there is not right or wrong , bad or good decisions you just have to do what you think is best ( like in real life) ohh you will meet some people from the TV show like glenn and hershel.
- graphically : the devs choices to make the game looks like a 3D/comic art style ( like in the comics i guess ) witch is great considering the origin of the game .
-now the gameplay : like any other point and click game you walk with WASD and the mouse to look around and to select or grab stuff + QTE when it comes to fight ( sometimes to gotta be quick making decision)
-sound: perfect voice acting ( really get in to you when the game gets emotional) + a lot of dialogue , music and sound effects are great .
-no multy of course ( duhhh) but after each episode , the game with compare your choses to other players around the world and show you the statistics so you can see how people played games like this one ( also in the end of the game)
-bugs or glitches : sometimes characters and items glitches in the game and sometimes they becomes invisible but doesn't crash or block the progression in the game( maybe something to do with windows 10 or my pc who knows).
-achievements : 48 easy achievements for achievements hunters like myself ( story related you just have to play the game to unlock them) 40 from the main game and 8 from the dlc so make sure to get it to complete everything.
-steam trading cards.
finally, i highly recommend this game for anyone that wants a good storytelling game worth the money ( i warn you you gonna cry :3) or make sure to grab it on sales (around 4.99$ - 7$) if its too much for you and dont forget the dlc because it adds some extra to the story and you will need it in S2.
9/10

The Walking dead is a graphic adventure game its played from a third person perspective. reviewText:
This game is brutal.

Let me back up a little there. I saw the release of the game originally and expected it to be based on the first series of the TV show, not the graphic novels which I was unaware of, so I watched a few minutes of people streaming it then put it on my list of games to buy some time, no big hurry though. Then about a month ago I watched someone playing a while and remembered I wanted the game and lo and behold Steam put it on sale. I bought it.

Sometimes I play a couple of hours of an FPS online and I get tired but it's a physical tiredness, The Walking Dead left me emotionally and mentally drained. The short time I watched people streaming it I laughed at their choices and told them how they were going wrong, armchair gaming, warrior style.  Now I have played it for myself I can see I was no better than the people I watched stream it, with my choices. This game is like interacting with a movie, the story is there but how you play it decides the outcomes of many situations and can decide the type of person you are, morality wise. When Kenny doesn't want to help me at the end of Chapter 4? I know I made some bad choices.

I don't want to give any spoilers away, just play this game.

Oh yeh, I said this game was brutal? If it doesn't punch you full on in the feels, you should check your pulse.

reviewText: This game is phenomenal and powerful. Very few games take into account the consequence of your actions as seriously as The Walking Dead does. It is quite a bleak experience, don't expect things to be sugarcoated here, the walker threat is real and its impact is felt throughout the whole game.\n\nThe voice acting is top notch, which is a good thing, since this game is entirely plot driven. The characters are all great, you're meant to love some, hate some, and be somewhere in the middle of the road with others. Everyone has their own shades of gray, and the game really sends home the message that morality is secondary when you're purely dealing with survival. Every choice has its outcome, and its advantage along with its disavantage. It's worth replaying just to see how different it can be simply due to the most minor of decisions that you may have taken. It will make you remember each and every yes" and "no" you have given

reviewText: Games that are tailored to the decisions you make are pretty few and far between these days, and eventually that itch is going to need some serious scratching.  Well, scratch away, people, because Telltale Games has you covered with this episodic title.  Basically, in a nutshell, the game is a dialogue heavy, decision based platform with a few quick-time event sequences in them.  While it's compared to Heavy Rain, The Walking Dead has strengths over Heavy Rain, and vice versa.  The decisions in The Walking Dead feel like they have a much greater impact on the story than Heavy Rain, however, the QTE sequences in Heavy Rain are extremely intense and failing them has great consequences.  In The Walking Dead, QTE failure just makes you restart it, so literally nothing is at stake during them and they feel like padding.  In the end, The Walking Dead is a very absorbing title for those who enjoy games with decision making over action, and is well worth the price.

reviewText:
If there's a genre I avoid like the plague (excuse pun!), it's zombies - so I've really not even bothered reading reviews about The Walking Dead - my mistake right there.

So, here I am reeling from a game with quite possibly more feels in it than the entire legendary series of Mass Effect (pure videogame blasphemy, that).  Yet, I was only tempted into buying The Walking Dead by its namesake Pinball FX2 table where scoring choices declared that I'd chosen to 'save' one person or another (I just wanted to find out what all that was about...).  How mistaken I was to think this was some kind of zombie FPS!

For fellow gamers who hate zombies, let me put this out there: this game is not actually about zombies.  With a title of The Walking Dead" and a zillion screenshots of
recommended: zombies - I might sound like I'm off my rocker here
hoursPlayed: but no.  An unexplained disease outbreak has suddenly taken place (you never get to find out what
voteText: how or why in the game) which results in the dead returning to devour the flesh of anything they can grab (yep
helpfulPercent: sounds suspiciously zombie-like
votesHelpful: doesn't it?) but this is really just the backdrop to the storyline.  The backdrop event could equally be about a nuclear holocaust
votesTotal: or some killer virus outbreak (kinda not far off this story actually).  It is the events caused by this cataclysmic
votesFunny: life-changing backdrop that you play through.  The game is a story-rich masterpiece about survival.  You will constantly be presented with moral choices and difficult dilemmas.  Do you trust fellow survivors or not?  Do you depend on them?  Do you let a threat live?  Do you let compassion rule over logic?  Do you be honest or withold the brutal truth from a child?  In truth
commentsCount: you might do a little of all these things because this is a game with very few rights versus wrongs.  There is little point flipping through walk-throughs in hope of pursuing the perfect game.  It simply doesn't work like that.  You will be presented with tear-jerking choices where neither is great
column16: but you HAVE to choose.  Heartbreaking moments surface throughout - so all but the most hardened of players might appreciate a box of Kleenex by their side!  This game is very much the 8-person lifeboat scenario where you forever always seem to have 9 people.  Who goes?  YOU decide.  But not everyone can live happily ever after and life is not always fair...\n\nI don't know how true to the comics the game happens to be
column17: but I will say that the characters were very easy to care about (even the dislikeable ones had a story)
column18: the artwork is novel and effective (somehow 3D without losing the water-colour comic essence)
column19: and the haunting melodic music throughout sets the tone for the dark storyline perfectly.  The game plays well with both keyboard/mouse and gamepad and doesn't require a ninja PC to play it (which is always nice).  There are no pointless 'collectibles' missions to detract from the story and no quick-save options to dilute the pressure of the instant-decision process (though for busy people it is never-the-less possible to rewind back to an earlier point if part of the story is missed).\n\nFor anyone who enjoys a great story-driven adventure built strongly upon the choices you make throughout each episode

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is an excellent interactive story with believable characters, beautiful artwork, voice acting and music, and a powerful emotional impact.

There are some puzzles to solve and zombies to kill, but mostly the game involves deciding what to do or say to the other characters during time-limited interactions that are often filled with tension. These decisions make the story feel like it is your own, allowing you to shape Lee and his relationship with Clementine and the other characters, and I felt this resulted in it having more of an impact on me than if I had watched it on TV.

The characters are well developed and felt real, many becoming people for whom I cared (and still think about) and it hurt to see them suffer during what were intense and sometimes devastating scenes. Oftentimes I found myself questioning my decisions, regardless of how justifiable they seemed. But while the story is pretty grim at times, there are touching moments as well, particularly during the interactions with Clementine, who is the heart and soul of the game.

Expect to get around 2-4 hours per episode depending if you inspect everything and exhaust all dialogue options. I enjoyed The Walking Dead, and it is easily one of the best games I have played.

reviewText:
I am a big fan of The Walking Dead TV series and this game brings The Walking Dead into a Game series perfectly.
This game has a Story, Character Development, Walkers, Deaths and Drama, just what I love about The Walking Dead.

You are Lee, a convicted murderer for the man your wife was cheating with. You are in a police car when it hits a walker on the road, the car spins into a forest and you wake up in the middle of a forest full with walkers, you don't know what they are but you climb over a wall into a garden, and there's a girl, Clementime, shes alone, orphaned by the apocalyse.
You make it your job to look after her, to let anything happen to her.

As for gameplay, most of the game is cutscenes, these don't get boring and you are involved the whole time, by choosing what your character says and the many quicktime events.

The game changes on your choices in both of these events are comparable to Mass Effect.
Outside these, there are parts of the game were you have to walk around and talk to people, walk through walkers and interative with objectives in a point and click 3D form.

If you are a fan of the TV Series, Comic Series or just zombies in general, I recommend you get this game, there are 5 episodes in this Season and each will last nearly 2 hours each. Anyone will love this great Game Season.
I give it a 10 out of 10

reviewText:
Review:

What is the ultimate goal of playing a video game?  What do we, as those interacting with the medium, hope to walk away with when we let go of the mouse and keyboard at the end of a gaming session?  The answer is simple, but it is often difficult to achieve in most games.  We play games to attempt to grasp a sense of accomplishment and connection with the story that we just dedicated precious time to accomplishing. Telltale Games‚Äô  The Walking Dead  provides the player with a definitive sense of satisfaction and concern for the story laid out over the course of five episodes.  An expertly crafted story guided by Telltale Games, but shaped by each individual player, guides the narrative of  The Walking Dead .  Set in a sudden and bleak zombie apocalypse, players assume the role of Lee Everett as he embarks on an emotionally powerful endeavor to survive in this new world whilst still holding on to what little sense of humanity can be grasped. The ageless formula and storytelling abilities of the ‚Äúpoint and click‚Äù genre has achieved a near-perfection in every episode of  The Walking Dead .  At moments, controls can become finicky such as when navigating the main character, Lee Everett, around tight spaces, but this shortcoming in control is easily forgotten as the narrative itself of  The Walking Dead  slowly build up momentum and gathers the attention of all who have the chance to enjoy the game.

Positives:
The sense of personalization to the story and connection with the characters felt by the player in  The Walking Dead  is rarely found in gaming today.
Episode 5: ‚ÄúNo Time Left‚Äù instantly ranks amongst the most powerful moments in all of gaming.
Even the smallest decisions made seem to come back and appear later on in the game as both minor references and also major repercussions.
Musical score is equally as powerful as the writing of the story itself.
The multitude of different endings possible leave for a very high replay value. Negatives:
Controls can become tough to operate at times, but these moments were rare and few and lasted for only a brief few seconds.
Pacing can become slow at some instances in the story, particular in Episode 3: Long Road Ahead."  This by no means takes away form the overall experience of playing  The Walking Dead
recommended:
momentary issues with pacing become prevalent. Summary:

Telltale Games‚Äô  The Walking Dead  is a rarity in gaming today.  The connection developed and nurtured with the cast and their plight in the game begins instantly from the first moment and carries with the player through to the rolling of the final credits.  Support Telltale Games‚Äô near masterpiece and download  The Walking Dead  today.

Overall Score:

9.5 out of 10.0"

reviewText:
The problem with reviews for games like this (at the time of writing episode one is over two years old) is that pretty much everything has been said already.

You probably already know that the story telling and emotion crammed into this 12 hour game is unbelievable. You don't want the game spoiled for you as this would essentially destroy the whole experience, but the ending for season one is probably the most heart-breaking moment in video games I have ever experienced - certainly since Shadow of the Colossus.

Definitely pick this up and immerse yourself in the world, the characters and the choices you make along the way. The game shines through your emotional investment.
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the most engaging interactive adventures I have played! Incredibly strong writing & voice-acting give the narrative the focus & impact it needs maintaining a good pace through all 5 episodes.

Choices made throughout the game have repercussions & vary the outcome of the story. They also give small timeframes to decide which adds significant intensity.

Fans of the TV Show will get a little more from the story & locations as there is some crossover but its not a prerequisite to enjoy the game. You never know who is going to live or die, but unlike the TV Show here you atleast have input on who makes it & how it goes down.

Emotional, memorable, heart-breaking, disturbing adventure set in a Zombie post-apocalyptic world.

One of those must have experiences for any gamer!


If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

reviewText:
The Walking Dead - Season One may look and play like an interactive storytelling game, but that is not bad at all, in fact, how Telltale handles the storytelling is something marvelous; lovable characters, gritty atmosphere and a hooking story make this game one of the best graphical adventures there are in the market. Alongside appealing comic graphics and interactive gameplay, this game does not require you to be a fan of The Walking Dead series, Telltale made this game to be enjoyed by everyone.

+Intense storytelling
+Memorable characters
+Choices affect how the story is developed
+Comic-like visual style
+Inmersive sound

-Gameplay may not appeal to everyone

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is an interactive graphic adventure, the first of Telltale Games to be critically acclaimed.

You follow Lee and Clementine from the very first days of the incident that took place in Robert Kirkman's The Dead Walking universe. I'd just say it was an amazing story, worth every praise it has already got. What makes this one different from the other Telltale games I've played is that I was more identified with the characters, their pain, their tears, their choices and their regrets. I broke in tears playing this... And I still would if I played it again.
