reviewText:
The Walking Dead is an adventure game by Telltale Games Studios best known for developing episodic games, such as Sam & Max, Wallace & Gromit, Tales of Monkey Island, Back to the Future, and Jurassic Park. The game is based on the award-winning comic book series created by Robert Kirkman, entitled The Walking Dead.

The game is split into episodes that make up seasons, just like a TV show. The main protagonist of the first season of The Walking Dead is Lee Everett. The story begins at the outbreak of zombie apocalypse, at the time when Rick Grimes (the protagonist of the comic) is in coma. When the infection begins its bloody harvest, Lee is sitting handcuffed at the backseat of a police car. He was arrested for murdering a man who slept with his wife. The developers decided to present adventures of an entirely new group of people, while the major inspiration in the creation process was Robert Kirkman‚Äôs work, which is regarded by the developers as the canonical version of the story. Players can visit places and meet characters well-known from the comic books and learn additional information about them. The first season of the game is divided into five episodes. Completing each takes on average about two hours.

The gameplay mainly consists of exploration, conducting conversations, collecting items, and solving puzzles. From time to time there are also simple action sequences, but it is worth noting that QTE (quick time events) do not play such an important role in this game, as they did in the previous production from Telltale Games - Jurassic Park. In contrast to a typical zombie game, The Walking Dead is not about exterminating hordes of undead. The developers decided on a slower-paced gameplay, and players need to keep quiet, especially in places where the walking dead like to roam.

The Walking Dead is the first game from Telltale, in which decisions made by the players influence the experience. What you do in the first episode has consequences later in the story. It is worth noting that players have a limited time to make a decision and do not have a chance to carefully reflect on possible repercussions. When it comes to puzzles that you encounter in the game, they do not resemble ‚Äúadventure game-like problems‚Äù, but reflect the reality of a zombie apocalypse. The creators also saw to it that the environment was interactive, so to provided players with more freedom when solving puzzles.

The title has attractive, cartoon-like graphics, slightly resembling the comic books by Robert Kirkman. The game does not feature multiplayer mode and is distributed only via digital means.

9.4/10

reviewText:
The recent TellTale games have quickly become my favourite games and it began with this incredible game. The Walking Dead has you play as a Lee Everret, a man on his way to prison on the day the outbreak began who takes on a small girl, Clementine, who you vow to protect as you journey through the big bad world looking for more survivors. I've never been a fan of point and click games but I am a fan of rich singleplayer stories and that is what this game delivers

+Gorgeous cell-shaded art style
+A compelling story
+Unrivalled story telling
+Amazing voice acting
+Five episodes each around two hours long
+The choices you make have consequences on the rest of the game, sometimes minute, sometimes massive
+Very interesting characters who have rich backstories
+At the end of each episode you can compare your choices with others who have played the game
+Less focus on zombies, more focus on the people who you meet meaning you quickly become attached
+The most heart-wrenching ending to a game I have ever encountered

+/-Most of the gameplay comes from looking around or quick time events but if you're here for gameplay you're in the wrong place

Verdict:
10

Easily one of my all-time favourite games. It's probably not for everyone but I for one adore it. The perfect game for those who love a good story and/or The Walking Dead universe.

El K.

An ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• finds a little girl, tricks her into to coming with him, meets up with several other ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s and spends the entire game brutally scarring her until shes an empty shell wandering the wheat fields covered in blood and fluids playing with empty casings.

Serious review:

This is a very well done point and click story with lots of suprises. Expect to be pulled into the story and wanting to know what happens next.
Your choices impact how other characters look, talk and treat you. It also has an impact on the overall story.

400 days is a series of 5 short episodes that looks into other survivors lives during the 1st 400 days things hit the fan.
Each one is relatively short but good. After playing all 5, theres a extra bit that ties it in together and the outcome will carry over into the beginning of season 2's main story.

reviewText: Walking Dead is rather like watching five episodes of a new version of the show, complete with credits and ‚Äúpreviously‚Äù montages, which all seems a bit odd for a video game . Based on the comic rather than the TV show, the game-play is a little lacking. Instead the game focuses on the story and the numerous difficult decisions and their often dire consequences. Oh, and now and then you have to hit a few keys in typical QTE style. It seems almost as if the game designers didn‚Äôt like the TV show and wanted to bring us the original story, but couldn‚Äôt afford live actors. Despite this, it has to be said that the story is much, much better than the TV show. For a start there is a black guy as the star, rather than the all American, gun toting plonker sheriff that we have in the TV show. And although there sure is stereotypoing, it's far less than the TV show - women can not only shoot in the game, but they often steal the show in the action sequences. That‚Äôs a totally different picture to the TV show, which often painted them as only fit to do the cooking and washing up.\nSo all in all the game comes recommended, but don‚Äôt expect great game-play, instead settle in to a great story and atmosphere.

reviewText:
After being recommended by a lot of people to play this game, I finally did, and I must say it would have to be one of greatest and moving zombie apocalypse games, and playing it was actually an amazing decision. And after that, now I am recommending it myself.

So this game is based on The Walking Dead comic books, and something that I really like about it too is how the graphics of the game follows the theme of comic art, which I found to be great. You can see even if the characters aren‚Äôt talking, the expressions on their face show their emotions. I really thought that was great. The sound effects are amazing, and always keep you focused on the game and make it that little bit more realistic (and can make you jump as well even if you‚Äôre not paying full attention).

The game gets you from the moment you start it. You go on a journey through tragedy, fear, pressure, suspense, sadness‚Ä¶ the list goes on. If you play this game and don‚Äôt get emotionally attached or feel any sort of these emotions I‚Äôd be surprised. 	Speaking of surprises the game is full of them, it‚Äôs unexpected, and some things that happen in the game will leave you shocked. The gameplay is simple, and the game itself is kind of like a movie, and when prompted you follow the instructions given. I like how the story is based on the decisions you make yourself, which is just another reason why I loved this game.

There isn‚Äôt much else to say, all I‚Äôd suggest now is grabbing a copy of this game and a box of tissues and enjoy yourself!

reviewText:
The Walking Dead was one of the first games I was introduced to on Steam. I hadn‚Äôt ever played a game quite like this one. Before playing The Walking Dead, in my eyes games were limited to Pac-Man, platformers like Mario, multiplayer racing games, Zoo Tycoon, etc. I never really experienced a ‚Äúchoose your own adventure‚Äù game before, and prior to playing this game.. I wasn‚Äôt really all that interested in trying one either.

Although I went into this game kicking and screaming, an episode or two in, I was hooked. I was not a huge fan of the blood and gore, but that aside, the story was very inviting. I truly felt as if I was making all of the major decisions in the game, therefore influencing how my character, as well as all those around me would turn out in the end. I grew attached to some characters (Ben) that took me on an emotional journey at times, which was interesting to me, because I never knew that games could get you to feel such emotional ties to a fictional character.

Like I mentioned earlier, this game lets YOU decide how you want to play the game. You could play as the hero, or the villain. You can choose to leave people behind, and you can choose to save peoples lives. The most interesting part of the game is seeing how your choices you make earlier in the game can influence how your games pans out 2 or 3 episodes down the line.

You start out the game as a man named Lee. You do not know much about Lee, but you soon start to see his backstory unfold. He may have a criminal background, but you can choose whom, if anyone, you want to share this information with as you begin to make bonds and partnerships with people. You later run into a little girl named Clementine. You learn she is currently on her own when something terrible happened to her babysitter when her parents went out on a trip. You and Clementine team up and try to escape the monsters that seem to be taking over the area. She reminds you time and time again that the main goal is to find and reunite her with her family, until then, you are her guardian. The things you two will encounter and defeat together give you two an almost inseparable bond. You two start to learn things about each other not many people may know, which will help you in the end when you have to make some major life altering choices. You will meet a number of other survivors, victims, and criminals along your journey together. You will have to make decisions on who you trust and don‚Äôt trust, and hope that the people you do bring along for the ride will have your back when it counts.

Just remember that ALL of the choices you make, whether they are big or small will have some sort of repercussion. Some decisions you will have to make in a split second, and others you will have a little more time to think about.. but all your decisions are very important. Even though you may not always be able to save everyone from death and destruction, you have to remember your main goal is to keep Clementine safe. This is another layer to the game that makes all of your choices in the long run an emotional journey. Just when you think that you feel you‚Äôve gotten away with something, remember you will have her watching you from the sidelines, learning to act just as you do.

I hope you do give this game a fair try. There is a reason it has been so successful, the writers do know what they are doing. The artwork is different which makes gameplay enjoyable. Even though you are placed in a time period that may be depressing and hopeless, the graphics somehow make you almost feel a glimpse of hope to reach for. Being an apocalyptic type game, there is a fair share of blood and guts, but most times it is safe to turn your head and look away for a slit second. Embrace this different form of gameplay and open your eyes to the new experiences and emotions that will rapidly unfold when you play this game.

reviewText:
I got this game much later than the release date but I really enjoyed this game and consider it a classic. A lot of reviews have said similar things but game's strength is in its story and character development, which is absolutely top notch.

You play a character Lee who is trying to survive the zombie apocalypse with a young girl named Clementine. As the story progresses, your relationship with the girl you are protecting and other characters grow. It makes the decisions in the story feel important and consequential.

I won't spoil anything, but I loved the story. Episode 2 was especially epic and the ending was a really heartfealt conclusion.

The one criticism I have is that compared to the old games I've played such as Still Life and Monkey Island, the puzzles are not difficult at all. That really doesn't take away from the game at all because the story makes you want to progress through it all quickly. It also has an effect on the length of the game since harder games take longer to explore and finish.

The cell-shaded cartoony graphics are suitable and look great on the game.

I expect this game is pretty genre-defining for new adventure games. Overall it's a good thing. There's potential for games with great and compelling stories. There is more replay value in these games because you feel like playing them again and making different decisions. However, I think puzzle aspect has been downgraded. I think I can live with this compromise and I'm now really looking forward to playing more like the Wolf Among Us and Game of Thrones.

Great storyline based on the comic, not sure how close this resembles the tv program but either way it works.
Plenty of gore and violence just like a typical zombie horror, and i feel its a slow paced game but not the type to make you bored.
Its a choice based game too, so each decision you make has an affect on the game and how it plays out. No questions buy it you havnt already.
Id also advise to buy the 400 days DLC, its short but a great add-on, and im looking forward to season 2 as the story continues

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying, this game will help you work out if you're a human or a robot. If you are having doubts about whether or not you're a cold hearted son of a b**ch then play this game and by the end you will know.

This game is a masterpiece.
When I first heard about The walking dead game I thought that it sounded rather dull and that How much fun can one have just clicking on stuff?"
Then my friend said to me recently that I would love the walking dead and to give it a shot. So I took his word for it and got it.
The first 30 minutes of the game didn't really captivate me and I began to have regrets but decided I needed to just get through the first chapter before I made my decision. Boy was I wrong
date: around 31 minutes into the game something happened which turned a switch on in my brain and made me really like what was going on.\nFrom the second chapter onward the game just kept getting better
hoursPlayed: the decisions got tougher and you learn to love (or hate) the characters!\nDon't let the fact that this is a point and click game fool you
voteText:
until you have played it and began to understand the story and build your characters personality you really have no idea what this game is about.
Sure if you don't like point and click styled games and you don't like zombies or you don't like having your heart torn into a trillion pieces then maybe this game isn't for you.
For the rest of you do yourselves a favor and get this at the next steam sale!

+Voice acting
+Beautiful graphics
+Amazing characters
+Zombies
+Best story I have ever experienced in a game

-Not all decisions seem totally relevant
-Can make you feel depressed

9.5/10"

reviewText:
There is nothing to say about this game, which has not already been said. Having that said, I am going to say this. I doubted the game upon start. I rejected the choice of graphic style. I thought the music was lacking, I felt the characters were shallow.

When I was mid-way through, I was hooked, I felt that someone had touched my heart, I was shocked about some of the scenes, I had built up new friendships, I had glanced at love and I were curious about the future.

When I finished the game, I sat empty, yet my mind was filled with new wonderful things. I cried, not only from loneliness, but from happiness and fulfillment. I was ready to let it go, yet something inside of me wished for more.

If I would have missed out on this game, I would not have been as complete as I am today. Though just a game with a lot of options, it changes you. It‚Äôs hard to walk away from this game untouched, or to wonder if it were something you could have changed. Was there something you could have done differently?
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wonderful game in my opinion. There are some flaws such as the illusion of choice at some places (you can't change the main script event), not very much of a gameplay itself (mostly QTE and choosing between 3 variants of an answer), but these flaws don't spoil the whole impression you get when you play the game.

I am not a fan of TV show Walking dead (watched a few episodes, didn't like them) and I haven't read the novel, so I didn't know what to expect from the game. But when I started it, I fell in love. Telltale games can really tell the tale, the story is the main core of the game.The characters are alive, they have personalities. My favourite is of course Clementine. She's just a child who becomes grown up having seen bad things happen throughout the whole story.

There are some genuinely funny moments, but the most memorable are the tragic ones. Honestly, I almost cried during one of them.

The game uses cell-shading style, and I think it really suits here. The game is based on graphic novel, so it looks like one.

All in all, it's one of the best stories I have ever played. 10 out of 10.

P.S. What concerns DLC 400 days. It's a good addition to the first season, as you meet a few familiar faces. And I know that it is a bridge between 1st and 2nd seasons, but as a standalone game it isn't worth it. For the fans only.

reviewText: It's a really really good game. The storyline is amazing, with the interaction between characters more than stunning. An explanation can't really do it justice. While the gameplay is not the main aspect there is enough interactivity and thinking for what it's worth. While some people have debated over how much of an impact your decisions have on the overall game, it is still a part of the game either way, and one that is particularly enjoyable. Some people complain when a game is like a movie, but the way I see it that is one of the highest compliments you could give, that an interactive art form made for a certain entertainment has enough in it to qualify as another, one that when done right creates an equally as amazing experience. Now, I have not seen or read anything else pertaining to The Walking Dead, but I can assure you Telltale did an amazing job with whatever it is they were given. In one aspect this is an emotional journey, at another it is an exciting adventure, fun to be a part of. The entire time, however, it is at the very least enjoyable. I don't think there is anything quite like it.\n\nCompletely recommended.

reviewText: Personally, I'm not a fan of zombie games and don't buy them unless they offer something special, and this is something special.\n\nI understand that people still have the perception that this is just another zombie game
date:
but it would be a mistake to dismiss this game just because it has zombies in it.

In case you're unfamiliar with Telltale Games' adventure titles, they're fourth generation adventure games (1st: text adventures; 2nd; When LucasArts, Sierra and FMV dominated the adventure game; 3rd: The introduction of 3D graphics to adventure games). As opposed to the majority of adventure titles of the past, this one includes branching storylines and accomodates to your choices.

The nature of the choices you're expected to make in The Walking Dead are often difficult and tragic. This ISN'T the feel good title where you chew through hordes of zombies with reckless abandon. There are consequences for your words and actions. Other characters will remember whether you acted in their interests or not.

The characters themselves are all well written and voice acted. Interacting with them is one of the main draws of this game. You really feel for these characters and it makes some decisions harder and some seemingly easy, though you will have to live with the consequences.

The game is rendered in an art style that resembles a comic book in 3D. Here in lies my one problem with the game. The art style itself is not the problem, but sometimes you'll see lines that represent creases in the characters clothes levitating above their shoulders. It is detracting from the immersion, but it's an extremely minor problem.

This game is extremely replayable, especially if you're intreiged to see what happens if you chose your decisions differently.

If you've been avoiding this title because it has zombies in it then you may have missed the point. The situation this game puts you in is the point and the story couldn't be told in any other way. This is different than most zombie games where if you changed the assets from zombies to anything else it wouldn't make a difference.

If you're looking for something that is dark, tragic and challenges your ability to reason in tough situations then I think this is the game you're looking for.

reviewText:
I never thought a video-game would make me cry... Except for Mario Kart.

With the joke aside, I'll list the pros and cons of this game:

CONS:
-Graphics: Yes, I know it's made to look like the comic book, but it just looked too dated to me.
-Animation: Usually when the characters talked their lips didn't match their words.

PROS:
-Story/Plot: The story in this game was AMAZING! The people at TellTale knew how to draw their gamers into their game and make them feel connected to the characters.
-Gameplay: Overall the gameplay was pretty good. It had just the right action and dialouge.
-Controls: I don't feel there was nothing wrong with the controls. It was the basic click and/or move.

WARNING: If you look up this game on YouTube spoilers will arouse, I don't reccomend doing that.

Eh this is hard to put on a scale, but I'll give it a 8.8/10. I had a fun time with it, and can't wait to play the second one.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead by Telltale Games is a great thrilling game.

First off, I guess that games are more thrilling than series. You can make decisions and really emphasize with your character. Everything is more emotional than in series. I would describe this game as an interactive series.

Now, this game knows how to capture you with it's story perfectly. The emotions come over quite well and will capture you. To make out what is the best thing to do you emphasize with all the persons around you. In a situation of danger you have to make heavy decisions and these effect the people around you. If someone doesn't like you he won't help you, for example.
Of course you can not change the whole story with your acting but you can decide about life and death of your company, directly and indirectly.

Playing this game means tension all the time. You are always scared about whether someone dies or not or whether you die or not.

Furthermore, there is the action part of the game. Sometimes you have to shoot some zombies or click somewhere fast to react to another person. These quicktime events are a cool variety and give the game the last polish.

To sum up, I totally want to recommend buying this game. Just everything is fine in this game: the story, the emotions, the effects of your acting... It's an awesome interactive story that is going to capture you soon. And if you like The Walking Dead anyways you shall not miss this magnificent zombie game.

reviewText: Surprisingly good adventure game. A thinking game, not a hack n slash. Based on the comics, not the TV series. Lots of deep decisions to make, and often you have only seconds to make them, and the story changes depending on your choices. Who do you choose to save? Are you a liar or do you tell the truth? Much better than watching the TV series because you become part of the story. In fact, it's probably the best adventure game I've ever played, and I'm not a big adventure game fan.

reviewText:
I'm going to make this short, simple and spoiler free as possible.

Buy this game, now!

I have never really been a big fan of PaC(Point and click) games, however this is one of the best games I've ever played. I'm going to tell you right now, this is not a game you're going to play for gameplay, action or whatever. This is a game you're going to play for the story, which is the main focus. Think of this more as a interactive movie, or even more accurately , a show.  Gameplay is a relatively similar to other PaCs, though there are some very minor differences such as more focus dialogue and story.

A short, spoiler-freeish summary of the story:

You're  Lee Everett, a former professor of history at the University of Georgia who, for reasons I'll let you find out, was heading to jail...on the day of the apocalypse. However, you didn't make it. You later find a little 8 year old girl named Clementine, alone, and you decide to take care of her. This where the main point of the game comes in; Keeping safe, and taking care of Clementine, who you will end up caring about a lot.


Telltale does a amazing job of making you care about Clementine, a game as never made Me as emotionally invested in characters as The Walking Dead does.

There are, however, a few small performance issues and graphical bugs, but I found turning off AA(Anti-aliasing), setting shadows to low and having it run as administrator fixed most of the problems.

I would go into more about the games story and all that, but I really don't want to spoil to much.

Please just trust Me, buy this game, and it's DLC 400 Days. Even if you don't want to pay full price, then wait for a sale and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing get it then!

I promise you, you will not regret it!

If I had to do a stupid score thing, I would give this game a 9.9/10 and 400 Days DLC a 5.5/10
=======================================

[Updated My review]

After playing through season 2, I'm going to change My rating for 400 Days from a 8.7 to 5.5/10 and would also say that you could skip it, as choices you make in it are, in season 2 at least, pointless, and most of the characters, minus Bonnie, have nothing more then pointless cameos.

reviewText: The Walking Dead Season 1 weaves poignant story-telling and beautiful art to create a game that I can only describe as a masterpiece. This point-and-click adventure game features excellent character development and a well-paced plot which serves to maximize immersion. Even if you are not familiar with the Walking Dead in other mediums (i.e. the TV show or comics), you will find yourself attached to the characters in this game. Every heart-wrenching decision you make has consequences, some large, some small, and you will often find yourself wondering if you made the right choice.\n\nKeep in mind, however, that this is not an action game. Don't look to this game for any sort of combat or survival mechanics. The purpose of the game is to tell a story, and it is an amazing narrative about love, loss and morality. If this is what you are looking for, then I would HIGHLY recommend the Walking Dead Season 1.

reviewText:
Literally just completed the story... What an incredible journey this game took me on. Can't remember the last time I felt so strongly connected to a games set of characters, feelings, backgrounds... I've hardly touched this particular Point & Click game style before but I am pleased to say that through this Telltale experience I have thoroughly enjoyed it.

I don't just feel like I'm experiencing the story, I'm controlling it! My decisions ultimately changed the way my story progressed. This is not something I've come across alot in games, therefore its great to see this being a unique feature in The Walking Dead.

I can see now why its rated as Overwhelmingly Positive". If you are one of the crazy people that haven't purchased this yet
date: go ahead and go for it. An unforgettable gem worthy of anyones time & money. Already have Walking Dead Season 2 to continue with
recommended: and will definitely be going through more Telltale games as a result of this."

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is a point-and-click game with a heavy focus on dialog and writing, with a beautiful cell-shading art style and fantastic voice-acting.

Dialog choices you make will heavily affect the game, and characters will talk to you, hold grudges against you or do kind things for you depending on those dialog choices. The characters feel human, and you really feel a part of this journey to survive. I really don't want to talk about it too much because I don't want to ruin the magic for you.

I would recommend this to everyone, gamer or not. It is so easy to pick up and play. Make sure you don't give up on this game, it does start a little slow, but when you hit its rhythm, it has one of the best stories I have ever played through. It is so hard not to fall in love with this game. It is a phenomenal piece of work, with such a moving story. If you like a good story, Clem and Lee's adventures will most definitely fit the bill.

reviewText:
10/10 - Gripping, Emotional and Thrilling

I got this in a bundle but after completing all 5 episodes I would have paid full price! This game is great. It doesn't matter if you are a walking dead fan. This one is a must have.

You choose the outcome. At times I felt like a hero and others I buried my head in my shirt. Games like this really suck you in. One of the best Interactive Fiction games I have ever played.

Worth the $30.. get it on sale though.

reviewText:
I don't like zombie apocalypse games/movies. Possibility of it sounds for me really stupid - especially in our modern world with our GPS systems, payment purchases through fingerprints and fast Internet on the space station. But this game changed my opinion about zombies, because:
1. This game magnificently shows you, how hard it is - to kill a zombie, which 10 minutes ago was a human with his own feelings, wishes, thoughts and memories.
2. After 2-3 hours of game process you start thinking: who's worse - people or zombies, because all of them do awful things.
About the game itself - it's brilliant. There isn't so much action, the whole game process is just point'n'click and sometimes QTE (with choosing phrases in dialogues). But the story and characters are wonderful. I would also like to note voices of characters, especially Clementine. Voices...well...impossible to describe it, actors did their best.
Strongly recommended for:
1. people, who want to see excellent story in the game
2. people who like zombie apocalypse
3. people who don't like zombie apocalypse (they will change their mind, as I did)
imho, 10/10
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I decided to give a chance to TWD after seeing so many positive reviews. Although I like the zombie theme, the series never excited me and I never read the comics, I was surprised at how good and special this game is.

I confess I had already tested other games from Telltale and didn't like, point and click adventures are not my thing, but with the TWD I liked the gameplay, it's a game focused more on plot, dialogues and interactions of the characters but that has a dynamic side, with situations in which you should have quick reaction. The graphics are cartoony and the game has great sound quality, effects, soundtrack and voice acting.

It's the storyline and script that the game shines, thoroughly engaging and captivating, a story in which you must make choices that impact during the game and in relations with the characters, there impactful moments when it is impossible not to be touched, addition to all is the construction of the characters, their qualities, defects and emotions is perfect, the immersive factor is present in a unique way in this game.

The DLC is a good length, although short, sets the stage for the second season, I have to say I enjoyed the game much more than the series, I highly recommend it to everyone, even those who don't have much interest in this kind of game.

9/10

reviewText:
Many players love this game, and you might too. But the game is not universally adored. If you are like me, you see through the thin veneer that covers an extremely linear story that requires hardly any player interaction. This is more a movie with some light choices than a game.

On the surface, the game seems to give you choices that change the storyline. The game actually claims that that is the case. However, if you rewind a bit and replay a part of the game in a different way, you will find that the story is on railroad tracks and there is nothing that you can do to change it. Your choices hardly matter.

To give an example (light spoiler alert): in the first episode you will have to choose between two characters, one of whom will die, while the other will go with you to the next episode. It sounds like that has a huge impact on the story, but the fact of the matter is that after this choice that particular character hardly features in the story anymore. You might find it an agonizing choice (will I save A or B?), but for the story the choice is moot.

So I guess, to appreciate this game, you must be so deeply immersed into it that you believe that your choices actually shape the game. Unfortunately, the game does its utmost to destroy the immersion -- namely through quick time events (with, I might add, very awkward and not re-mappable controls for left-handed players). The game is full of them, and after you have lost one, you rewind and have to replay a bit of the story, because they are all of the press X not to die" quality. The QTE's seem like a desparate attempt to introduce some gameplay into the borderline-movie
date: but it is gameplay that should have been avoided.\n\nAdd to that the issue that very often you cannot actually make the choices that you would want to make. For instance (another light spoiler): when a character gets stuck in a bear trap while zombies are approaching
recommended: you cannot leave him behind or give him a merciful death -- no
hoursPlayed: you have to chop off his leg. Because that has been written in the story
voteText: and you only get options that end up with you chopping off a leg. And you cannot even go for the leg directly

reviewText:
The Walking Feels.

Drop the show and comicbook if you're watching/reading it. Right now. This game is a favorite of mine. There are some elements taken from the comicbook but it wouldn't be called The Walking Dead" if they didn't keep true to some of the things going on in the original.

TWD gives the phrase "between a rock and a hard place" a meaning. You are constantly getting thrown into difficult situations where the direction of the story and the relationships you maintain are dependent on the decisions you make. Many games have tried this style of narrative but they fall flat on more than one aspect or another (ex: Heavy Rain). Because I feel this game is nearly flawless and because I know Telltale is listening to their audience's critiques
date: I have high hopes for the second installment and anticipate on another emotionally harrowing/rewarding game.\n\nThere are very few games that are able to fully immerse their audience into their stories and characters. Some people complain about the lack of button mashing and zombie smashing. To them I say
recommended: "You have a very narrow view of what a game should be." Like movies
hoursPlayed: shows
voteText: and books
helpfulPercent: games don't always have to be fun to be games‚Äîand this game is not fun by any means. Entertaining
votesHelpful: yes. You will laugh
votesTotal: you will cry
votesFunny: and you will be engaged but you will not have fun. It's a drama; it shouldn't be a problem for anyone seeing as how neither the show nor the comicbook would be described as "fun."\n\nAnother complaint that gets coupled with the lack of button mashing that I'd like to rebut is that the player isn't playing and instead
commentsCount: they're watching a film. Yes
column16: you are more or less watching the story but TWD is an interactive game that Telltale does masterfully. Had you simply watched it as a film and had no role in the decision-making
column17: do you think you'd feel the same way about the story and the characters? No
column18: you wouldn't. In the show/comicbook
column19: I didn't give a rat's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about Rick or most of the characters. This game made me sympathetic toward characters I only knew for a few seconds and characters whose names I'd never know. The game requires interaction rather than just observation. This marriage between you and the mechanics is what makes the struggle for survival more rewarding than most games
column20: let alone any zombie media.\n\nThe only criticism I really have is the poor choice in the voice actress for Clementine
column21: a core character in the narrative. It felt inauthentic and forced. I know it's not a child's voice acting and I'm reminded of it half the time she speaks. However
column22:
it doesn't affect the character's personality and significance in the story.

You will think back on your choices that can open up for a lot of different types of discussion with others‚Äîsomething not a lot of games can manage to do. Some people may even do a little bit of personal reflection. All I know is that your body is not ready but the human experience will be worth it. I promise.

10/10"

reviewText:
Just an amazing and extremely sad story.
If you are not playing this game because you don't like the walking dead tv series well I don't like it either! Yes I watched all the seasons and I think the whole story is crap, how the characters behave, they all act like idiots or teenagers with a lot of hormones on them, everything that happens is stupid and you can't believe it I cannot feel attach or care with any of the characters because they are idiots and do stupid things, they are always putting themselves on risky situations for nothing. Here in the game on the other hand it's just as real as it gets (well sometimes you will find silly things but they are very scarce throughout the game), your main protagonist acts like a real human ADULT guy and the choices you made are really hard ones and they do carry consequences in both long and short term. You will end up caring for the characters.
You will hate some characters and love others, but all of them behave like real people!
The voice acting is superb!
This game is a must game, BUY IT you won't regret it.

The bad: Well the game is very poor optimized, don't know if it's the engine or what but it will hang between scenes for a few seconds, it's really annoying.
The save system is not the best either, it will save from time to time (always on the same parts) so lets say you made a choice but you dont like it and want to load and try it again...well bad luck for you, sometimes you will have to play 30min...
You can't skip the dialogs. (in a game like this with a lot of choices it's a must!)
The DLC is very short!
Last and I don't know if this is a bad thing (it was for me) the dialog options sometimes goes too fast, there are times when you don't have time to read what's on the screen but you need to take an action or the game will do it for you, lets say you need to read 4 lines in 3 seconds. (most of the time the games picks to not say anything at all on those cases) Happened to me 1 time on the entire game but It felt like the game was forcing me to take an answer and maybe with more time to think about it I would picked other and not that one.

reviewText:
This game is all character development. If you think there's going to be a lot of action, you're wrong. The gem of this post-apocalyptic wasteland is the time you spend bonding or identifying with the characters. The story moves forward and forward, and only one thing remains constant in this game; Lee and Clementine's bond. Above all else, think about Clementine, because Lee is there with his manly soothing voice.

In all seriousness, the game is GREAT. A lot of solving puzzles, defusing situations, and learning how each person stands in a situation. There are only a few hard choices compared to the second season, but assuming you choose the right choices, this ride of a game will take you from neutrality to empathy, to sadness, and then just misery. You're going to be flat-out bawling like I did when I finished this. The 400 Days Expansion is also worth its money, because it too affects the second season and any person that plays this game and finishes will crave more anyhow. This game is well done by TellTale, and always remember:

Duck is a detective.

reviewText: The Walking Dead Episodes is a game about dead that makes you feel alive. Based on the comic book series of the same name by Robert Kirkman, Tony Moore, and Charlie Adlard. Through entire game you will be pushed to hard choices that lead to some consequences. Every move you make will change the story. reviewText:
Graphics
The game is designed in a Cell Shading technology engine.
Everything is simplified and realism is a matter of perception.
For me personally; I'm a crazy comics fan, my dream is to make a comic book myself once in the future.
Having checked the comic of the original The Walking Dead story,
I say the game looks imspiring and I really liked it.
The environment is simple enough to let your eyes go through the areas,
and detailed enough to set up teh perfect mood for teh perfect moments.

It's nothing like Borderlands I can tell you that. You may check trailers and you will understand.
What we got here is a realistic comic story coming alive through animation.

however, i noticed some bugs. not sure if its cos of my rig's age, but i noticed some very few bugs in the game.
like a door animation missplacement once, or a face animation that was supposed not to be talking but the mouth was animated if it did.
But well.. IMHO those were completelly minimal stuff to me. bugs exist in all games anyway so.


Music and sounds
Music enough to let you concentrate on what you have to concentrate on.
Pretty much is there, but doesn't take your attention away.
No special soundtrack selections though no.
Sounds and sound effect are pretty neat. Everything is simple and cool.
Zombie sounds are pretty as amazing as i expected.

Gameplay
The game is focuses on a story, passing through your monitor's screen like a movie.
The developer's said what you do matters on what happenes next, and they give you dialogue selections.
BUT don't get it wrong. The story WILL take you into direct events and you will just have to follow that line.
The only reason they give your those dialogue and action selections is to form the herp's character
as you wish and affect the way the other characters see you and talk to you later on.

You can be a good guy, a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, a neutral person. the NPCs will remember your decisions and actions
and it will affect their dialogies depending how much they trust or like you.

Meanwhile the style of the experience is around the mood of an adventure game.
Very basic moving controls, going through puzzling situations, examining items and landscapes and stuff.


Controls
Very simple controls. W,A,S,D movement, itema nd action selections, left click for action.
Using your cursor will help you look and investigate the places and items you want, aiming to kill zombies and generaly perform actions.


The Story
If you also are a fan of The Walking Dead, then your most def need to check this game cos then you know
how awesome this zombie plot can be.
If you are not then 2 things; either watch teh series first - cos the game contains a few spoilers
or if you don't like the show just check teh game as a piece in your zombie fan collection.

A warnign though. This is no happy candy smiley story here. We are talking about drama and crazy plot spins.
If you like drama combined in a zombie story, then you will love this story for sure.

The Characters
Quite a number of characters to meet in the game. The story leads you right to them anyway.
The voicing is simple and nice. Each 'person' in the game has its own character and background story.
You will have to interact, take decisions, gain their trust of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• them up. make friends or enemies.
it was interesting for me going through the game, talking to all the characters,
finding out about their motivations,
trying to seek alies while in the middle of that survival horror you are places in.

value/time
The developers were smart enough to bring you the story in pieces.
This way you still feel the need to see more and you never get bored.
ATM there are 3 out of the total 5 chapters of the game available, each comes as a form of a free autoDLC update
allowing you to continue from where you left last time.
The game is worth the while for zombie fans and fans of the specific comic or the show.
I'm not sure how much it will last in time, probably not for much longer.

The tv show is going to open the 3rd season soon and seems like there's a lot more ahead to see.
So game developers will probably just end our game story at teh 5th chapter,
and leave the ground free for Activisions FPS The Walking Dead game, coming (as said) on summer 2013.

conclusion
so yeah. recommended depending your tastes.
for my tastes this game is TOTALLY RECOMMENDED.
hope this review helped you.
check screenshots and trailers if you like.
also check this gameplay vid in the link bellow with little to no spoilers inside,
it will help you take a look of what this is about.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iXYMcPlUKh8

reviewText: I've actually had this game for quite some time, but never really bothered to play it, due to a combination of not having seen the show and not really knowing what the game was even about. Finally I forced myself to stop procrastinating and pulled up the first couple seasons of the show on Netflix. Now that's another story entirely, but it pushed me to give in and boot up the game.\nThe first thing to note is this game is EXTREMELY story-driven. There's little walking around and even less controllable combat. But that doesn't matter, because the story is amazing. The storyline and dialogue are very interactive, and at least half of the dialogue choices you make influence something in the game, whether it be how someone else feels about you, or a friend's fate. Excellent voice acting and music only add to the story, which, like the show, puts you on a roller coaster of emotions from anger to fear to sorrow. My only complaint is the texture quality is rather low in areas, but that can be overlooked. I very much enjoyed this game.

reviewText: The Walking Dead is a true masterpiece, among the best of it's kind. You play as Lee, who has been knocked unconcious by a car crash, only to wake up in a post Zombie Apocalyptic world. You go on to find Clementine, and it's all uphill from there. It's an emotional game, but not too emotional to take away from the action, which this game portrays nearly flawlessly with it's unique artstyle. I won't spoil any points in the game, but you will definitely be on edge throughout the story! If you're looking for a game that you will want to keep coming back to, just to see how many different outcomes you can have, this is your game. Just about every playthrough is different in some way or another, which adds a lot of replay value to the game. I can't help to recommend this game, and I hope that you have as much fun playing this game as I have.\n\nRating: 9.5/10

reviewText:
Rating: 10/10

The Walking Dead (Season One) is an adventure game following Lee Everett, as he works with survivors he meets along the way to stay alive in the outbreak of a zombie apocalypse. The story is split into five episodes. Each episode has five points where you'll have to make a big decision with two choices, and these decisions will alter the story in subsequent decisions and episodes. As an example of the quality of storytelling, there are no complex puzzles or difficult quick time events (QTE). The entire game focuses on the story and their effect on character development.

The game series, much like the graphic novel and television series, is really about exploring how humanity copes with moral ambiguity and survival in the direst circumstances. There's a constant tension between the three elements of short term survival risk, moral principles, and long term group cohesion. The morality behind decisions and their intentions are ambiguous, even as their consequences are revealed. Much of the time you'll engage in hypotheticals, wondering whether the outcome would've been different if you made the same gamble in the future, especially when your decision was based on good intentions and unwittingly backfired. Often you'll have no good options, only those terrible and worse.

You'll meet characters that surprisingly hold their own as stalwart and capable group members, whilst others are clearly overwhelmed and become nihilistic or panic, putting the group or even themselves in danger. Powerful egos can clash when, out of genuine selflessness, a few members feel passionately that their ideas provide the best chance of survival for everyone. It's up to Lee to try to massage the group politics to ensure everyone gets along, but this won't always be possible. Not everyone is as noble or trustworthy, and few are as they first appear. You'll meet some truly despicable people, yet most 'villains' you'll encounter won't be unambiguously evil, but simply did what they thought best in a difficult situation and fell short of the task‚Äîtheir true failure wasn't malicious intent but incompetence.

As you'll quickly discover, the story centres on the relationship between Lee and Clementine, whilst other non-player characters (NPCs) are of peripheral significance. The only complaint is that the character Clementine is a hair's breadth away from being a clich√©d Mary Sue. Her only limitation is her young age, and even then she displays remarkable courage and maturity. (For those unfamiliar with the term, a Mary Sue" is a character who is ideal and lacks any real flaws.) However
date: this doesn't make Clementine any less endearing and she is widely considered the most beloved character of the series.\n\nThe ending made me tear up‚Äîand I have quite a stony heart."

reviewText:
First off, it's important to realise that this isn't an action game where you beat the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of zombies. It's more like watching episodes of The Walking Dead, making decisions for the character and thinking on your feet. Essentially, it's a story based game, which is really, really enjoyable, if you love The Walking Dead.

Your character is Lee, a guy who got in some trouble with the police when the apocalypse hit. He meets a little girl, Clementine, and the pair embark upon a journey together, meeting different people along the way. The story itself is absolutely captivating, and rest assured, even the most indifferent of people will shed a tear by the end of this game. The story changes completely depending on which choices you make, which is really difficult for somebody as bloody indecisive as me, and I had to restart sections frequently because I'd felt my choice had been wrong. It's moral led, which makes it even more challenging, as you have to make difficult decisions about food sharing, lying to people you like and ultimately, saving people. The game is extremely engrossing and you can't help but get emotionally involved.

This was the perfect 'Sunday' game for me. A game you can ultimately enjoy playing when you're feeling a bit rough from all the alcohol you had the night before (ahem). It is involving, enjoyable and tests your survival instincts - not just finding food and shelter, but also your manipulation or capitulation when dealing with other people. I absolutely recommend it, especially if you're a fan of the TV series or comics.

reviewText: I've actually had this game for quite some time, but never really bothered to play it, due to a combination of not having seen the show and not really knowing what the game was even about. Finally I forced myself to stop procrastinating and pulled up the first couple seasons of the show on Netflix. Now that's another story entirely, but it pushed me to give in and boot up the game.\nThe first thing to note is this game is EXTREMELY story-driven. There's little walking around and even less controllable combat. But that doesn't matter, because the story is amazing. The storyline and dialogue are very interactive, and at least half of the dialogue choices you make influence something in the game, whether it be how someone else feels about you, or a friend's fate. Excellent voice acting and music only add to the story, which, like the show, puts you on a roller coaster of emotions from anger to fear to sorrow. My only complaint is the texture quality is rather low in areas, but that can be overlooked. I very much enjoyed this game.

reviewText:
I'll try to write this review without giving too many spoilers.

The Walking Dead takes place in the same universe as the comics and TV show, but it is an entirely new cast. I think this is probably for the best, because a lot of games that try to recreate a movie exactly fail miserably.

You are placed in the role of Lee Everett, who at the beginning of the game is in the back of a police car on his way to prison. Very soon after the zombies start popping up, you meet Clementine, an eight year old whose parents were away in Savannah when the outbreak happened. Obviously her motivation is to find her parents, and Lee's motivation is to protect her at all costs.

A theme that pops up on a fairly regular basis is the effect that all of this apocalypsness can have on the people who are living through it. This is conveyed several times by showing Clementine seeing something awful happen.

The gameplay is driven by quicktime events, puzzles, and choices.
The quicktime events only occur when you have gotten grabbed by zombies or are otherwise in immediate danger. They aren't ridiculous, mostly just mashing Q and then hitting E to finish it off.
Obviously the puzzles take place in between high-action parts of the game, and usually involve figuring out how to open this door to get this item which you need to complete this task. Oftentimes the areas with puzzles also provide a nice opportunity to chat with other members of your group and get to know them better.
Speaking of the characters, they are the ones that drive the story, and almost all of the choices you have to make have some direct effect on the members of your group. Some are blatant save person A or person B
date:
but others are more subtle ones that depend on dialogue options or how you decide to divvy up the dwindling supplies. The screenshot above is of me deciding to chop off a guy's leg to free him from a bear trap; I didn't fully realize it at the time, but I could have chosen not to do it. I was just doing what I thought was necessary. I tried everything else first, I swear.
The fact that the consequences of your actions are not immediately apparent is what really sells the sense of realism for me. For example, after I lost a certain character, I spent a long time (outside of the game during my real life, mind you) analyzing all of the choices that I had made leading up to their death. I was trying to think of a way to save them, but I'm still not sure if I could have done anything. The fact that I don't know if the event was scripted or happened because of my choices really shows you how well it is doing its job. I am probably not going to go back to try to change that moment, because I feel that that would cheapen the experience.

The suspense ramps up during the fourth episode, and the finale absolutely blew me away.

The 400 Days DLC serves to bridge the gap between the original game and Season 2. It introduces several new characters who will appear in Season 2; they are playable in this DLC, but I do not think that they will be playable in Season 2.

There are five characters, and you can play their stories in any order. They all take place within a couple hundred days of the zombie outbreak. They also occur relatively close together, so some common characters and locations appear in multiple chapters.

The decisions you make in each person's story determines the decision they make at the end of the episode. This in turn will affect where they are and who they trust during Season 2. Interestingly, almost none of the decisions from Season 1 have an impact in 400 Days, though they will undoubtedly have a greater impact in Season 2.

Obviously it only makes sense to buy 400 Days if you are planning on playing Season 2. If you are as invested in The Walking Dead as I am though, it's pretty much a no-brainer and well worth the $5.

reviewText:
Just an amazing and extremely sad story.
If you are not playing this game because you don't like the walking dead tv series well I don't like it either! Yes I watched all the seasons and I think the whole story is crap, how the characters behave, they all act like idiots or teenagers with a lot of hormones on them, everything that happens is stupid and you can't believe it I cannot feel attach or care with any of the characters because they are idiots and do stupid things, they are always putting themselves on risky situations for nothing. Here in the game on the other hand it's just as real as it gets (well sometimes you will find silly things but they are very scarce throughout the game), your main protagonist acts like a real human ADULT guy and the choices you made are really hard ones and they do carry consequences in both long and short term. You will end up caring for the characters.
You will hate some characters and love others, but all of them behave like real people!
The voice acting is superb!
This game is a must game, BUY IT you won't regret it.

The bad: Well the game is very poor optimized, don't know if it's the engine or what but it will hang between scenes for a few seconds, it's really annoying.
The save system is not the best either, it will save from time to time (always on the same parts) so lets say you made a choice but you dont like it and want to load and try it again...well bad luck for you, sometimes you will have to play 30min...
You can't skip the dialogs. (in a game like this with a lot of choices it's a must!)
The DLC is very short!
Last and I don't know if this is a bad thing (it was for me) the dialog options sometimes goes too fast, there are times when you don't have time to read what's on the screen but you need to take an action or the game will do it for you, lets say you need to read 4 lines in 3 seconds. (most of the time the games picks to not say anything at all on those cases) Happened to me 1 time on the entire game but It felt like the game was forcing me to take an answer and maybe with more time to think about it I would picked other and not that one.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is a story rich game, the protagonist of the game is Lee Everett, who is a convict heading to jail, soon enough, he discovers that the entire world has some type of zombie infestation. He then has a second chance of survival.

The Walking Dead's characters are amazing with unique personalities and plans. Some characters will attempt to stop you and become your enemy, and others will fight by your side and stay with you through-out the entire game.


The Walking Dead is a pure genious game that deals with extremely heavy emotions, I bet everybody at least pushed out one tear at the end of the game.


I would reccomend The Walking Dead to all of my friends, it is an extremely well-done and memorable game.

reviewText:
Graphics
The game is designed in a Cell Shading technology engine.
Everything is simplified and realism is a matter of perception.
For me personally; I'm a crazy comics fan, my dream is to make a comic book myself once in the future.
Having checked the comic of the original The Walking Dead story,
I say the game looks imspiring and I really liked it.
The environment is simple enough to let your eyes go through the areas,
and detailed enough to set up teh perfect mood for teh perfect moments.

It's nothing like Borderlands I can tell you that. You may check trailers and you will understand.
What we got here is a realistic comic story coming alive through animation.

however, i noticed some bugs. not sure if its cos of my rig's age, but i noticed some very few bugs in the game.
like a door animation missplacement once, or a face animation that was supposed not to be talking but the mouth was animated if it did.
But well.. IMHO those were completelly minimal stuff to me. bugs exist in all games anyway so.


Music and sounds
Music enough to let you concentrate on what you have to concentrate on.
Pretty much is there, but doesn't take your attention away.
No special soundtrack selections though no.
Sounds and sound effect are pretty neat. Everything is simple and cool.
Zombie sounds are pretty as amazing as i expected.

Gameplay
The game is focuses on a story, passing through your monitor's screen like a movie.
The developer's said what you do matters on what happenes next, and they give you dialogue selections.
BUT don't get it wrong. The story WILL take you into direct events and you will just have to follow that line.
The only reason they give your those dialogue and action selections is to form the herp's character
as you wish and affect the way the other characters see you and talk to you later on.

You can be a good guy, a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, a neutral person. the NPCs will remember your decisions and actions
and it will affect their dialogies depending how much they trust or like you.

Meanwhile the style of the experience is around the mood of an adventure game.
Very basic moving controls, going through puzzling situations, examining items and landscapes and stuff.


Controls
Very simple controls. W,A,S,D movement, itema nd action selections, left click for action.
Using your cursor will help you look and investigate the places and items you want, aiming to kill zombies and generaly perform actions.


The Story
If you also are a fan of The Walking Dead, then your most def need to check this game cos then you know
how awesome this zombie plot can be.
If you are not then 2 things; either watch teh series first - cos the game contains a few spoilers
or if you don't like the show just check teh game as a piece in your zombie fan collection.

A warnign though. This is no happy candy smiley story here. We are talking about drama and crazy plot spins.
If you like drama combined in a zombie story, then you will love this story for sure.

The Characters
Quite a number of characters to meet in the game. The story leads you right to them anyway.
The voicing is simple and nice. Each 'person' in the game has its own character and background story.
You will have to interact, take decisions, gain their trust of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• them up. make friends or enemies.
it was interesting for me going through the game, talking to all the characters,
finding out about their motivations,
trying to seek alies while in the middle of that survival horror you are places in.

value/time
The developers were smart enough to bring you the story in pieces.
This way you still feel the need to see more and you never get bored.
ATM there are 3 out of the total 5 chapters of the game available, each comes as a form of a free autoDLC update
allowing you to continue from where you left last time.
The game is worth the while for zombie fans and fans of the specific comic or the show.
I'm not sure how much it will last in time, probably not for much longer.

The tv show is going to open the 3rd season soon and seems like there's a lot more ahead to see.
So game developers will probably just end our game story at teh 5th chapter,
and leave the ground free for Activisions FPS The Walking Dead game, coming (as said) on summer 2013.

conclusion
so yeah. recommended depending your tastes.
for my tastes this game is TOTALLY RECOMMENDED.
hope this review helped you.
check screenshots and trailers if you like.
also check this gameplay vid in the link bellow with little to no spoilers inside,
it will help you take a look of what this is about.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iXYMcPlUKh8

reviewText:
This game is all character development. If you think there's going to be a lot of action, you're wrong. The gem of this post-apocalyptic wasteland is the time you spend bonding or identifying with the characters. The story moves forward and forward, and only one thing remains constant in this game; Lee and Clementine's bond. Above all else, think about Clementine, because Lee is there with his manly soothing voice.

In all seriousness, the game is GREAT. A lot of solving puzzles, defusing situations, and learning how each person stands in a situation. There are only a few hard choices compared to the second season, but assuming you choose the right choices, this ride of a game will take you from neutrality to empathy, to sadness, and then just misery. You're going to be flat-out bawling like I did when I finished this. The 400 Days Expansion is also worth its money, because it too affects the second season and any person that plays this game and finishes will crave more anyhow. This game is well done by TellTale, and always remember:

Duck is a detective.

reviewText:
Wow what a gem this game is.  You play as Lee a man with a questionable past thrown in at the deep end at the start of a zombie apocalypse, at the start of the game you meet Clementine, a little girl alone.  Throughout the game Lee and Clem meet all sorts of characters and together try and survive in a world gone mad.
The Storyline is dark in places and full of twists and turns but i felt myself constantly wanting more, it was like a book i couldnt put down chapter after chapter.
There are lots of great things i can say about this game, the character development is some of the best i've seen in any game.  The dialogue is perfect, it really gives each character a personality and you get the feeling these people really exist.
With every conversation i found myself not just trying to say the right thing but voicing my own opinion as if i was the main character i was playing (Lee).  From dilemma's to arguements to simple discussions and decisions this is a game that will make you wonder a second later if you did or said the right thing.  The fact that almost everything you say or do has a lasting effect and moulds the game to your decisions amazes me.
The quicktime events are quite simple at times but then it really catches you off guard at other times where you near enough need lightning reflex's.
I've never been a fan of cell shaded games but this is just something else, graphically it looks fantastic.
By the end of chapter five i didnt want it to end, i felt a real deep connection to each of the characters, even more so with Lee and Clementine.
Telltale did a fantastic job with this game and really can't wait for future installments of this series.
9.5/10

reviewText: Being the Game of the Year 2012, The Walking Dead may not of been the first game by TellTale, but damn sure was nearly the best one they have made. The game puts you into the role of former university teacher turned murderer Lee Everett, along your travels you find a girl named Clementine, and from the moment when you find a scared little girl, the bonding started. Spanning 5 episodes, you see character devolepment and emotions and CHOICES you will have never seen in a video game. The story is styled by how you play, how you react to things, what you say, what you do, how you do it, when you do it! This game is rich in story, full with interesting characters and really tested my trust in the characters. Having a little 8 year old girl in my care, trying to find my parents, TRYIN' TO SURVIVE the zombie epidemic acted as your moral compass, Stab this man and you find Clem horrified. Do something unhumane and unusual would scare Clementine. Try and make everyone feel safe and telling everything ok might calm her down, but will scare her later when it is not...

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is one of the most brilliant things I have ever played. I've never been a fan of point and clicks, but my god, the story of this game. Never has so much emotion, tension and terror been wrote so well into a video game like this. This game made me cry, it made me make unspeakable decisions, and it did what no over game has ever done; it made me care about the characters Lee was with, as though they were my own freinds. My own family. I never gave up on them, and as I played the game further and further I felt everything slipping out of control till the inevitable end. And the thing I know is that it didn't all have to end like that. I could've saved people, and while I was playing I kept asking myself would it have been different and better for the characters if I had made choice A instead of choice B at point X in the game. This game makes you think about the world we live in, and it makes you feel overwhelming emotion toward the most real, most compelling, most engaging characters I have ever met in a game. I am in love with this game.

I knew these characters for no more than 15 hours, yet they felt real to me. I genuinly did care about them. I can definatly see myself playing through this game again, trying out different choices, and seeing different paths.

10/10 Telltale are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing writing wizzards.

reviewText:
This game was the first game of telltale I have ever played but after playing this game I become a hugh fan of this company. This game is a story base game, throughout the entire story you are making choices ( sometimes big and sometimes small). The story can be very emotional and make you attached to almost all the characters you talk with.
In the zombie apocalypse word no one is safe, not even you, this results for a few epic moments of character deaths.
Your way of play-through can result characters death or even save their life, there are also other choices that are hard to get, a moral ones, this game make you peel like you are actually inside the game and not just playing it.
To conclude this game is very good and they managed to do the end of the story even better than the rest of the story. This game will make you want to play the 2 season of this game and even try telltale other games and maybe will even make you cry.

My score: 10/10 -Perfect game.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is probably one of the best games I've played in a long time. The story telling is great, characters are real and memorable, and has unique art style and gameplay. This is a must have game.

But let's talk about Ben, one of the characters in your group. Ben is the dumbest piece of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• I've ever seen in a game. He is the epitome of what a stupid teenage boy is and can aspire to. His actions are directly responsible for the deaths of many characters in The Walking Dead. He was utterly useless at all tasks given to him to perform; a monkey could've done a better job than he did.

Spoiler here, but I'm utterly ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing appalled that 66% of players refused to let Ben fall to his death at the end of episode four. I'm utterly disgusted on why 66% of players would continue to bring this complete numbskull with them in their journey in the post apocalyptic world of The Walking Dead.

Long story short, Ben is a stupid piece of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. I take that back, stupid is an understatement, Ben is the world's biggest idiot, failure, and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-up in general.

reviewText:
Que su aspecto caricaturesco no te impida jugar a uno de los juegos mas logrados de los ultimos a√±os, contando una historia atrapante desde el primer minuto y cuyo final perdurara contigo mucho despues de que los creditos finalicen.
The Walking Dead le hace justicia tanto a la serie televisiva como a los comics originales, narrando la relacion entre dos de los personajes mas entra√±ables que he visto, posicionandolos en un contexto post-apocal√≠ptico y obligandonos a tomar decisiones de peso para el transcurso de la aventura.
Su aspecto epis√≥dico nos deja siempre con ganas de una cucharada mas de su irresistible mundo, y al finalizar la experiencia no dudar√°s de que has presenciado algo sin precedentes, y no hablo solo de las lagrimas que derramar√°s (y te aseguro que lo haras) , sino de la calidad que logro alcanzar una simple point-and-click adventure.
Por eso, y mucho mas, me saco el sombrero ante Telltale Games. Hazte un favor y juega esta joya de los videojuegos modernos, que no por nada fue la ganadora del Juego del A√±o 2012.

Valoracion final: Una aventura sin igual en la cual tus decisiones afectan no solo al mundo a tu alrededor

reviewText:
Good game, nice story, responsive controls. It pretty much got everything right. I specifically enjoyed the time aspect of the conversations. Opposed to other point and click adventure games, you can't take too much time before selecting what to say next, it tries to emulate a realistic conversation by putting pressure on the player.

Which is interesting and it pulls it off pretty nicely.

Graphic wise it's decent. Not bad but not amazing either. The cell shaded textures look nice but some of them are visually pixelated, especially when the camera gets up close. The animations weren't impressive either, however the game excels in gameplay and decision making.

You will be often times surprised by a very difficult choice that you have to make... all that under the time pressure.

I recommend this game, it was a good experience!

reviewText:
So, firstly when I saw this title I thought it will have sam plot as TV series. I was wrong.
This game really shows, how cruel can be people when they are in danger. Greedy and awful.
This game shows the other side of human visage. It tells beautiful story of survivior- Lee and his ward- Clementine.
I just could not stop playing when I bought it. Unfortunately I haven not got internet connection, so Steam statistics show just 5.8 hours. But for real, I ended it two times and both times it was very sad but beauty story.
I think everyone should try playing that title, even if you do not like 'point and clicks'.
This is not normal 'PnC', this is like interactive movie, where you decide, what will happen next.
That is why I hardly recomend this game. Telltale- good job ;)!

Pros:
-Plot (whole history is awesome)
-Moral choices (you can decide about almsot everything)
-Optymalization (game works really good, even on older PC's)

Cons:
-Lots of choices do not change game much (also lots of them do not change anything)
-Gnere (this is individual but some people hates 'Point and Clicks'

My rating:
7.5 out of 10

reviewText: To begin, I don't play point & click style games, just not my thing, however... Being a fan of the walking dead, I've debated getting this for ages, and seeing it in a bundle, I finally gave in and got it. The gameplay itself isn't really exciting, the controls felt weird to me in a few situations, and the choices I made in the game felt really minor for the most part. As far as I can tell, my choices simply alter the relationships between the characters, with no significant impact on the stories outcome. That being said though, the story for this was truly amazing, and that's more then enough. If I were to sum up this game in a single sentence it would be...\n\nThis is a must watch interactive movie for any TWD fan.

It seems kind of pointless writing another review for this game that pretty much everyone already knows is brilliant. But, I might as well just add another one, because it had such a massive impact on this.

The Walking Dead isn't a game that's strong with regard to mechanics its strong when it comes to story telling and character development. This is a game that will have a huge emotional impact on you and its going to stay with you for a while afterwards.

More praise about the game can be found in my review of it on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2013/03/the-walking-dead.html.

reviewText:
This will be a short review, because there's not too much about this game I can say that will not spoil this game. Based off Robert Kirkman's critically acclaimed 'The Walking Dead' comic book series, this game is a point-and-click narrative adventure; you control a character named Lee, who has to fight to protect a young girl named Clementine in the wake of a zombie apocalypse.
Told over five episodes, TWD is played out like a typical point and click adventure; click on items, click on dialogue bubbles and click on areas to make Lee move. You'll rarely be in direct control of the action, but this is a strength rather than a weakness. You're a viewer of a cinematic masterpice, along for the ride, who chooses Lee's every word and makes every decision for him. The decisions you make will affect your relationships with other characters and ultimately affect the way Clementine views you and acts the way she does. The voicework and visuals is phenomenal, and allows you to experience the game just the same as a film or a television series. The story is brilliantly told, and you'll find yourself genuinely caring about the characters as events unfold, which is a damn marvel in today's gaming industry.
The Walking Dead is a unique and entertaining game, with emphasis on narrative and character development unlike any other game I've ever played. You'll remember the ending long after you finish the game, which only serves to demonstrate the quality writing exhibited by Telltale. 10 / 10

reviewText: The most impressive adventure game I've ever played.  It's a few grammar mistakes and video glitches from being perfect, but it's a masterpiece from beginning to end.  It does a remarkable job with character expressions of emotions and sentiment.  Couple this with great camera use and angles, and excellent audio acting, and the characters really come to life.  Really.  I actually felt for Lee, and wanted Carley around, and grew to dislike Kenny, and cared for Clementine.  This game really tugs on emotional strings.  Especially when the decision-making moments arise.  It's a gritty game with many memorable moments.  Some events I still can't believe.    And what a mighty end.  I'm still cringing in loneliness and my bones are still chilled.  This is story-telling at its finest.\n\nA masterpiece, for sure, even in its' minor glitchy condition.
