reviewText:
Here is an immersive game that will  get you so absorbed into the storyline.

(To anyone who hasnt played yet, this is a BIT of a spoiler. It is in the demos and trailers anyways so not really a spoiler)
It starts out with the main survivor Lee Everett heading to prison for murdering his wife. Along the way, the careless sheriff driving him does not see a walker on the road and well, sh** happens. (You can start reading now :) )

From here on, I practically never got bored. I listened carefully and read the lines spoken from the characters. There were lots of emotions flying about and none were left out. Love, contempt, sorrow, and joy is mixed in the story along with shocking results from each part of the episodes. I love the game and I haven't gone through all of it just yet. The next season is coming out in about a week from now. To anyone reading this review and trying to decide whether to like this review or not with their twitchy finger, I'd rather you buy the game. Play it as much as you can BEFORE the next one comes out. Then preorder that one. Or buy it then play it. The game will not let you down and the next season won't either. Keep in mind that Telltale games release EPISODES for the game. You buy the game and you get to recieve the episodes (for free of course) but most of the time the episodes are released once a month.

It is also the same concept with The Wolf Amongst Us". Which is also highly recommended and I will do a review on once over 50% of progress is accomplished.

This game is worth the money. Especially when the story probably goes for more than 9 hours even if you tried to skip through the entire game. It is immersive
recommended: and packed with emotions that keeps the gamer's eyes on the game. Unless the game of course cries about graphics and goes to play Crysis or some random FPS game like COD.\n\nThanks for taking the time to read this review. Have a good game session!"
hoursPlayed: December 7, 2013

reviewText:
*For Those Of You Looking For An Honest, Detailed Review*


Gameplay: For those of you that don't know, this game is more of an interactive movie, as opposed to a fully imersive game, but that doesn't make it any less interesting. Some people say that you're decisions do not actually impact the story which is kinda true and kinda false. The decisions that do impact the game tend to be a 2-choice decision usually deciding which people survive and those that don't. Other conversations that have 3-4 options tend only to result in slightly varied dialouge which all end up at the same conclusion. Also, your answers to those impacting" questions will be re shown at the end of each episode showing what percentage of other players made the same decision as you. Kind of a nify addition.

Controls: I actually streamed the game to my laptop from my desktop
date: and played it in bed with a controller. This game is perfect with controllers considering that most of the time you're not pressing more than one button at a time. On occasion you'll have to aim and shoot quickly
recommended: but it's not nearly as fast paced as an FPS.\n\nStory: Ohh.... THE FEELS.... This story

reviewText: Captive, mindblowing, neverseen before, cruel, emotional and full of difficult decisions... The Walking Dead combines an emotional unique storyline with some unimportant click 'n'point adventure elements. It may not be a game, more a movie where you face life-and-death decisions. Sometimes a bit too slow, a bit walking too dead, it's a mere stunning, unique computer game experience that I have to recommend highly to everyone able in supporting some very disgusting, scarry moments. The 3D Vision support is very good and makes the whole adventure even more immersive. There could be some starting problems with the Steam version. Watch out. Overall 8/10.

reviewText: I  wouldn't really call this a game, it's more of an experience. Despite the phenomenal experience it provides, i cannot recommend purchasing this product for the full retail price simply because there is little replayability. Think of it as a TV show, how many times can you watch it before you are completely sick of it? That being said it is definitely worth playing through atleast once. It is an experience you won't soon forget. Your heart will fight your mind as you struggle to make the right decision in many situations. It's not as important, but the art and sound is incredible aswell.

reviewText: Wow, why don't you own this yet? While somewhat lacking in the puzzle solving elements which are a staple in most point and click adventures, Telltale focus on creating an incredibly immersive story with characters you actually care about. Some of the choices you have to make in this game will really hit you hard and has genuine repercussions instead of just black or white, along with some truly shocking moments throughout the five episodes. I haven't enjoyed a game storyline this much since Deus Ex: Human Revolution. I've not really been a fan of Telltale's games in the past but what they've achieved with The Walking Dead is nothing short of amazing.\n\nThis is my first delve into The Walking Dead universe and I was just hooked from the start right until the end. You'd be doing yourself a great disservice by not picking this game up as you are in for such a treat. Highly, highly recommended!
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is not the perfect interactive novel but what Telltale's The Walking Dead is a classic tale of human survival whose foundation is built on solid voice acting, great visuals and masterful writing that conveys the difficulty and emotion of human interaction when the sh*t hits the fan like no other work in it's genre that I've experienced.\n\nOther notes. 1) After each episode I didn't watch Up Next on The Walking Dead".  No option to turn this off.  2)  Turn on Detect Selectables and Turn off Story Notifications.   Pixel hunting is not what this is about.  3) There are a few sequences where the lack of inverted controls can cause issues for people that are not comfortable with non-inverted controls in the first person.  4) If you're not a fan of this genre play it anyway

reviewText:
IntroductionThis game... wow... this game sure puts you on an exciting rollercoaster of emotions. The Walking Dead by TellTale Games, is a must-have game that needs to be in your steam library. I mean honestly, you and everyone else who doesn't have this game, should be throwing money at it.

AtmosphereThe atmosphere in the game is simply astounding. If you decide to go heavy into this game (which you should, to get the most out of it), in tense moments of the game, you really feel it along with the characters. I found myself shedding a tear or so when something bad happens/happened. And at the end, oh boy did I turn into a fountain. Honestly, if you didn't shed a single tear at the end, congratulations! You're a psychopath.

ChoicesChoices in this game are very impactful. Sometimes not so much, but a majority of them are. I won't spoil anything, but just be ready to make not only tough decisions, but fast ones as for most of the choices you have a certain time limit, which varies in length.

MusicWhat kind of music is to be played when and where is simply gorgeous. To me, music can make or break a moment, deciding the factor whether you couldn't care less, feel horrible for the character, or be happy like the sun.

RelationshipsTo kind of go along with the choices section, there are so many different relationships you can have with people. You can befriend Larry, or be an enemy with him, and so goes for Kenny and everyone else.

NegativesThe only thing I can really put down about this game is some of it's realism and glitches. (yes, I know that it's a zombie apocalypse and it's not real, just a game der da duh), For example, at the start when Lee slips on some blood, the blow his head takes (giggity) should have killed him or immobilized him for a while. There are also some continuity errors such as I only got one bullet left!" then shoots three bullets.

PlotThe plot of "The Walking Dead" is great. It's involving and it's alot easier to remember since you're the one making the plot. This is just a quick
date: and basic run-down. (no spoilers ahead) You start off as Lee. He's on his way to prison when they are involved with a car crash. a little girl saves him and from then on they fight for survival.\n\nConclusionOverall
recommended: I would highly reccommend this game to anyone a fan of story-based games
hoursPlayed: a point-and-click adventure or a fan of "The Walking Dead" television show or comic books. 9/10."

reviewText:
Clementine is the best video game character ever.

I honestly never got into point and click games that much and probably never would have even played this had it not been for getting Episodes 1 & 2 as part of Playstation+ one month. So glad I did. reviewText:
Loved every part of this game.
Some people may argue that your choices don't actually matter, and I'd say they are not wrong... But they are not right either. The choices you make in the game may not have an impact on the end itself, but it will have an impact on how the story gets told to you. Will you become a respectable man, or will you be an ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• throughout the entire game? The choice is yours.

What does matter here is the travel, and not the destination.

The graphics are enjoyable; you really feel like you're part of the original comics universe. The game developpers also had the good idea to create their own story and not simply take the comics story. This is not a simple adaptation of the comics books, this is a parallel story which does not make some fan services; the references to the books are smart and really not invasive.

All in all, this is a simple, yet very enjoyable story-driven point-and-click, merging some humor and a lot of drama in a good and smart enough interactive story.

Turn the lights off, and play it alone or with someone else, and discuss about the choices you should make or should have made.

A must play!

reviewText:
Captivating and hard hitting.

This is the second time that I had finished Season 1 and I must say, it tugs no less on the feels! The foundations of the game are making friends, making enemies, sustaining friendships, surviving and looking after a little girl... all whilst the world falls apart around you.

It is a hybrid point-and-click game with FPS (First Person Shooters), QTE (Quick Time Events) and limited freedom sections where you can walk around. The main mechanic is dialogue. You choose your response and statements to people which can have different outcomes which makes you think about what you say. You mostly have limited time to reply, so it can be a real adrenaline rush trying to answer emotionally.

Overall, I would not rate this game out of 10. What I would say though is that it is an experience that you should not think twice about going through.

reviewText:
Based on the Kirkman graphic novels rather than the TV show, Telltale's The Walking Dead represents a shift in tone for the company, from comedy adventure game necromancers to gut-punching best-of-a-bad-situation simulators!

The focus is on a strong narrative that runs through the season, with hard decisions & character development front and centre. Gameplay mostly consists of mild (often guided) exploration, rudimentary inventory management and in-context quick-time events, which serves its function of moving the story along between locations and disasters.

If you are a fan of any facet of The Walking Dead (TV or graphic novel) then this is indispensable.

reviewText:
This game is a master piece.
The graphics are comic like, sticking to the roots of The Walking dead - a comic book origion.
In this game, you play as a man named Lee who looks after a little girl called Clemintine. You and Clem are the main characters and fight zombies (aka walkers/geeks) and the odd human to survive.

There are 5 episode and an added 6th, which is DLC. Each episode is quite long, so there is a fair amount of playing time, especially if you explore everything, which you will as this game is amazing.
The game is tailored around YOUR decisions and can have multiple plots and can result in a different person from your group being killed due to your decisions.

It can be classed as a point and click game, but you can move around using WASD and shoot walkers when needed.

Good points:
-Runs well due to comic like graphics, especially on mid-range PCs like my own.
-You develop feelings for Lee and Clem due to the nature of the game, you end up making every decisions based on keeping Clem happy & safe. Of course there's the option of being a jerk to her....
-The story is immersive and the soundtrack can give goosebumps.
-Cheap considering blockbusting titles can be ‚Ç¨60. This is a steal.

Bad points:
-Slow readers might struggle at making decisions as there are many quick time events, ran by a timer with 3/4 decisions.
-Killing my social life :)

10/10, cannot praise enough!

reviewText:
Having completed the story only minutes ago, I can barely see enough to write this review.  The tears, make them stop! Brilliantly executed storyline.
Fantastic game.  More of an interactive movie than a game and a damn fine one at that.

I admittedly was a bit jaded from the TV series partly because (in my very humble opinion) I liked so few of the characters.  Thus, I held off on trying this one out even though I bought it well over a year ago.  If only the show was as well written as this game.  It was near perfection!

Some of the choices you're forced to make are just gut wrenching.  The game was far more disturbing than I imagined it would be and that factor only contributed to the experience.

Very much looking forward to season 2.  I need a few days to recover because my feels are damaged, badly.

Play this, you won't regret it.  Huge props to the developer!

date: the other dies and the story goes in a different direction and encourages replaying the game! Right? Wrong. Not twenty minutes later

voteText: I'd be promoted with a choice and the inevitable would eventually happen. I finished the game with a bad taste in my mouth.\n\nThat is until I saw a discussion online about Kenny
helpfulPercent: one of the characters. The thread started off with someone saying how awesome Kenny was.He always had your back

reviewText: This game is absolutely amazing. But not by standards of games you are used to. This isn't one of those -Grinding, beat up the enemies repeatedly, level up, or run through enviroment kind of games... this is an emotionally involved decision driven game. There are many options for discussion and relationships with characters. Most everything is a cutscene with a choice in between, and there are small puzzles between discussions and a lot of button mashing. The graphics are also unique and most people would struggle to get used to them this day in age, but I don't. I love this game with all my heart, it's amazingly genuine and full of incredible characters that each vary and all feel realistic and sincere. I for one do not call this game boring for its unique gameplay, or ugly for its unique style. So please, try this game, give it a chance, and be in for the experience of your life.\n\nMy total hours played should just tell ya.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is an absolute must-have game for anyone who likes a good story.

So what is it? Essentially The Walking Dead is an episodic point-and-click adventure game with action sequences. More importantly, it's a captivating and touching story of a man and a little girl trying to survive a zombie apocalypse.

The puzzles are straightforward, the action sequences are very easy, there's no real challenge to be had in this game - and that's a good thing. The Walking Dead is ALL about the experience, and that experience is sensational. You make decisions for your character that influence not only the events in that episode, but also the overarching story. There are some grueling decisions to be made and you don't have all day to decide, which adds a lot of tension to the scenes.

If you've seen the TV show or read the comics then this will be an even better experience. The game takes place prior to the TV show but in the same area, with locations and characters from the TV show making cameos, albeit with different voice actors.

The 400 Days DLC is a sixth episode that is mostly unconnected to the original season. You play as five different characters in short stories that come together in a final arc. It's worth your while, but not as long as the other episodes and the actual ramifications of your choices in the DLC won't be felt until season 2.

TL;DR:
Buy it now!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fantastic writing and a great story. However, your actions don't really matter. The ending is the same no matter what choice you make. The same characters will die. And so on and so forth. Walking Dead has an illusion of choice and much of the dialogue is written and voiced in a way that no matter what response you choose, their reply is adequate. Still, if you want a fantastic story with great dialogue and voice acting, I recommend it. It's a powerful, emotional game.

reviewText: Telltale's The Walking Dead is based on the canon of the hit TV Show and graphic novel series.  It is a point-and-click adventure game with quicktime elements - and it's a very good one.  The narrative, storytelling, and characterization is top notch and if one can refer to a story as heavy" this game is more like having a pickup truck sitting on your chest.  It's a prime example of interactive storytelling and is an excellent model of how you can use the gaming medium to convey a story to an audience - even the camera angles it utilizes were wonderful
date: from staring at your reflection in a puddle as you beat someone's brain in to adding tension by having a skewed angle while you climb a ladder.  The game did have some pitfalls that comes with the point-and-click genre that it didn't avoicd unfortunately - repeatedly viewing things instead of acting on them/with them
recommended: repeating dialogue options accidentally without the ability to skip them
hoursPlayed: a few character and graphics glitches (I vividly remember speaking to an invisible Vernon and Kat cradling an invisible Duck in her arms) but besides a 4th wall breaking comic intervention these small negatives don't detract too much from the story as a whole.  The plot is very adult in nature and the gore and heavy themes are what you'd expect from a "Walking Dead" branded product.  What I found most interesting was the "illusion of choice" that seemed to be woven throughout the game.  Many people complain that every dialogue option and every choice you make should have an effect on the outcome of the game and many do; however
voteText: there are more than several situations in the game where no matter what you do something is going to go down in a certain way - many times in a way that could shock you.  As such
helpfulPercent: I recommend playing this game by the seat of your pants
votesHelpful: don't reload
votesTotal: don't try again.  It's a more rewarding experience in the end since probably that one thing you didn't want to happen is going to happen regardless of what actions you take.  This can be seen as a pro or a con depending on your personality.  I find it a plus
votesFunny: as it allows Telltale's writers to weave a tighter narrative that has a much larger effect on the viewer than if everything turned into sunshine and rainbows for you (which is not going to happen anyway).  Leave it for a second playthrough if you must
commentsCount: but imagine this game as more interacting with a movie that you can steer around as you please to explore the world and interact with the characters in.\n\nSPOILER FOLLOWS - Finally the ending wasn't too fulfilling to me
column16: it almost seems like Telltale was holding back for a future release.  I would have liked to see how your 'parenting' options throughout the episodes effected Clem
column17: and allowed you to see what kind of person she becomes after the credits roll.  Even if her actions post ending were in a montage format that would have been fine
column18:
allowing you to see if Clem can survive in this world with the lessons you've taught her. /SPOILERS

Pros:

Great storytelling (narrative
column21: "whole-package"
column22: etc.)\nHeavy
column23:
adult themes

Cons:

Minor point-and-click pitfalls
Ending didn't "wrap up" to my satisfaction
Some characters (while good) felt a little static or seemed to be only "plot-devices"

Even though I wasn't too impressed with the ending and the cons *appear* to outlist the pros this game is definitely worth a playthrough.  The story is great and this game is a great entrance for any gamer into interactive storytelling and what poing-and-click adventure games can be. B+"

reviewText: Oh my God, this is one of the best  zombie games I've ever played.  When I first saw that it was  developed by Telltale games I though it would be a  just a bog standard point & click adventure game, which it turned out not to be;  it's sort of half way between a p&p and a  third person action game (with some first person viewpoints).    I was immediately  struck by the art style which reminded me a lot of Borderlands and Street Fighter 4 in its   pseudo cartoon - watercolour washed   graphics.  The voice acting is brilliant accentuating  the  emotions that run throughout the game which are very powerful.   The way you choose to play the game, i.e. your  actions and choices affect how the story plays out across the entire series, making this  a game that has loads of replayability potential.\n\nI never thought I'd be saying this about   an adventure game, but I've enjoyed playing this more than other zombie games e.g. Left 4 Dead, Dead Island and the Resident Evil  franchise.

reviewText:
Fantastic writing and a great story. However, your actions don't really matter. The ending is the same no matter what choice you make. The same characters will die. And so on and so forth. Walking Dead has an illusion of choice and much of the dialogue is written and voiced in a way that no matter what response you choose, their reply is adequate. Still, if you want a fantastic story with great dialogue and voice acting, I recommend it. It's a powerful, emotional game.

reviewText: The Walking Dead sits firmly in what is the experience of this story told across graphic novels, the TV series, and this game. The game mechanics remind me, in a good way, of my childhood experiences with Choose Your Own Adventure books; the most notable difference that the choices not only affect your outcome, but the outcome of those that are surviving with you as well. TellTale's art style and storytelling are top notch, and the experience is worth the price of admission, in my opinion. They are definintely setting the bar for episodic game entertainment.

reviewText: I played this game many moon ago when it released on 360 and recently purchased it on STEAM to play through once again. It is one of my personal favorite games. While having zombies in it, the fun doesnt come from cracking their heads (although there is plenty of it). The game is based around the relationships and interactions you have with the NPCs through the decisions you make during tough situations. You will both make and burn bridges with characters. You only hope you didnt side with the guy that gets killed ten minutes later and are stuck dealing with the guy you sided against for rest the game. As you will find if you play the game, the living can be much more dangerous than the dead. 12-15 Hours (more if you buy 400 days" episode) playthrough depending on how much stuff you examine. reviewText: Let's begin by saying that The Walking Dead isn't so much a game as an interactive choose your own adventure" book. There are a few action sequences but for the most part you are interacting with the different characters you meet and making decisions about what you should do at different decision points. These decisions have repercussions on what happens in the story.\n\nAs a game it isn't very entertaining to be honest. As a story it is both bleak and potentially inspiring depending on how you look at it. Had I paid full list price I would have been greatly disappointed in both the game play and the length of the game. However
date: on steep sale this isn't a bad way to spend 8-10 hours or so. Just don't go into it expecting a happy ending or really even closure to the story as this is "Season 1" of a longer story arc."

reviewText: Perhaps one of the best stories I've had the pleasure of experiencing in quite a few years. Especially amongst the zombie horror genre. TellTale have done a wonderful job in crafting a provocative story that yanks at the strings of your heart whenever it can. Forcing you to make tough decisions within a very short time, that often have dire and unforseen consequences. It's a beautifully woven tapestry of choices which can create varying and unique stories between each individual's playthrough. To top it all off, it has one of the most satisfying and emotional endings I've seen to date. It's hard to understate just how much the relationship that Lee and Clem develops can affect you as the player. For me it drove me into the role of a father figure trying to protect his daughter. And I imagine it can and will do the same for many others.\n\nWith all the praise I can give to the writing and story, I do have to point out a critical flaw with the game. In that, it's not much of a game at all. Point and click adventures have always been rather awkward for me, since they always just feel more like an interactive movie to me. And this can at times deter from your enjoyment of the story. A number of times I found myself hovering over my mouse or keyboard, just waiting for that inevitable quick time event. And as a result I felt myself growing somewhat detached from whats going on, which broke the immersion for me somewhat. But then again, this would not work as just a rolling movie either. As it is the decisions and choices that you make that help add a level of involvement to the story. Making it much more personal, as what happens is because -you- chose for it to happen. reviewText:
The Walking Dead is an absolute must-have game for anyone who likes a good story.

So what is it? Essentially The Walking Dead is an episodic point-and-click adventure game with action sequences. More importantly, it's a captivating and touching story of a man and a little girl trying to survive a zombie apocalypse.

The puzzles are straightforward, the action sequences are very easy, there's no real challenge to be had in this game - and that's a good thing. The Walking Dead is ALL about the experience, and that experience is sensational. You make decisions for your character that influence not only the events in that episode, but also the overarching story. There are some grueling decisions to be made and you don't have all day to decide, which adds a lot of tension to the scenes.

If you've seen the TV show or read the comics then this will be an even better experience. The game takes place prior to the TV show but in the same area, with locations and characters from the TV show making cameos, albeit with different voice actors.

The 400 Days DLC is a sixth episode that is mostly unconnected to the original season. You play as five different characters in short stories that come together in a final arc. It's worth your while, but not as long as the other episodes and the actual ramifications of your choices in the DLC won't be felt until season 2.

TL;DR:
Buy it now!

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is the prototype game in the industry that shows that storytelling and characterization in video games can easily match those we see in movies or television series. Your choices matter here more than anywhere else and can lead to devastation or salvation when you expect it the least. The well written story and your attachment to the characters - main or supporting - will keep you moving forward and make you question every decision you've made before. It's a game of 'what ifs...'.

The story begins right on the first day when the epidemic starts. The main character is Lee Everett, who is on his way to jail in a police patrol vehicle when they hit a zombified humanoid they'll refer to as 'Walkers'. After a bit of wandering in a forest we meet Clementine, the eight year old girl whose nanny has also been turned and her parents are cut off in the faraway Savannah. The two start bonding right after they meet and Lee tries to look after her the best he knows. It's a really an emotionally powerful relationship from the gecko that only gets deeper. The game never tries to be unrealistic about the characters and their motives. Their goal is to survive no matter what, and I mean no matter. Not to find out what has happened or get some kind of cure. No. This makes it so interesting, you aren't Superman nor an action hero with unlimited bullets. The characters are real, everyday people that care about their families and themselves.

The game has an episodic character. It has 5 episodes each lasting around 2-3 hours that adds up to a total of 12-14 hours of gameplay. Your choices move the story forward and the game sometimes hits you with an impossible choice that will make you wonder minutes after it. Sometimes it's really hard to make a choice, but sometimes it might not even matter in the end. You just never know when somebody steps in and changes everything. It's a great balance of making up your mind and not knowing what would've happened if. What is spectacular about the game that the other characters have their own stories and plans too, and it might not tally with your's. The rest if the cast isn't there to make your life comfortable. They aren't soulless vessels that obey everything you say. They can act on their own, even if you don't like it and often confront your choices.

As a Telltale game it has a comic book character that is unquestionable unique, but hardly state of art. Neither artistically nor technically is a phenomenal game, but it has its own tone. It has other problems too. Frame-rate drops are annoying and camera angle changes can result in a momentary freeze of screen. On the audio front the situation is much better. The music and the voice acting is top notch, that supports the deep and emotional story.

Telltale has hit the mark with The Walking Dead: Season 1. It's a spectacular point-and-click game where puzzles are secondary to the story. Yes, there will be times when you have to ask questions like, 'how to make this happen?' or 'how to make that work?', but those are only evanescent. The real question that you'll ask all the time is 'what is the right decision?' But you'll find out that there isn't one. It's a cruel world where everybody tries to survive and some tries to retain their humanity. If you're trying to find a superb interactive story, look no further, because The Walking Dead is a must have experience.

Rating: 84/100; Replay Value: 5/5; To Beat: 12-14 hours.

reviewText:
Loved every part of this game.
Some people may argue that your choices don't actually matter, and I'd say they are not wrong... But they are not right either. The choices you make in the game may not have an impact on the end itself, but it will have an impact on how the story gets told to you. Will you become a respectable man, or will you be an ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• throughout the entire game? The choice is yours.

What does matter here is the travel, and not the destination.

The graphics are enjoyable; you really feel like you're part of the original comics universe. The game developpers also had the good idea to create their own story and not simply take the comics story. This is not a simple adaptation of the comics books, this is a parallel story which does not make some fan services; the references to the books are smart and really not invasive.

All in all, this is a simple, yet very enjoyable story-driven point-and-click, merging some humor and a lot of drama in a good and smart enough interactive story.

Turn the lights off, and play it alone or with someone else, and discuss about the choices you should make or should have made.

A must play!

reviewText:
Lee Everett, the game's protagonist, has been jailed for murdering a state senator who had an affair with his wife. Just as he thinks his life is over, he embarks on an adventure of betrayal, mistakes, and death.
This was probably one of the best games I have ever played. Telltale have built the characters remarkably, almost as if they were real people, they give them a human-like trait of how different people react to things.
The game is set out like a TV show, you get episode 1, episode 2 ect. and at the end of the epsode it gives you a perfect cliff-hanger of the next episode
The soundtrack was top notch, I can't write this review without commenting on the soundtrack, it was almost exactly like the sound in your head in situations in real life, I know it sounds confusing but if you listen to the soundtrack you will fully understand me.
The graphics were great also, it had a nice comic-y feel to it, even though I've never read The Walking Dead comic book. Although to me it was like a comic book, don't get me wrong, it was like a comic book came to life. It had great detail and shading were it needed it.
Now, if you are looking for gameplay, don't expect anything more than clicking, wasd and the occasional q when you are not in a conversation, when you are, you use 1234 or scroll to select your option. The majority of this game, is basically an interactive cutscene, although it's not the tiresome type of cutscenes you get in some games that you wish you could skip (hopefully some of you reading this know what I'm talking about), your choices make your experience different to the other, whether it is in the next couple of conversations or in episodes ahead.
I would reccomend this game because of the storyline and how the game 'puts you' in the story, and how successful the game is on changing the affect on how you feel. It is definitely worth the price.

reviewText: This game is one of the best games I have ever played. It doesn't treat you fair. Not by a long shot.  You feel the weight of every step, of every decision, you have to loosen every screw and push yourself to the limit. And at the end, you will find yourself staring into the screen at 4 a.m. in the morning feeling  like a real zombie apocalypse survivor - you will wonder if you could have done anything differently to save those you came to love. It will leave you gasping with tears in your eyes. This is how a story in game should look like. This is how games should make you feel.

reviewText:
Amazing game. If you want a game with a lot of action this is might not be for you, as it is based heavily on dialogue.  While you'll still trigger the same events in the game no matter what your choices, it is still nice to play a game that makes you feel responsible for your actions. This is easily a must-have, even if youre not a fan of any other Walking Dead media. I only have 2 main complaints though people yet to buy this game should look out for.

1. Technical issues. They happen, although most won't notice them unless they know it's coming.
2. Full season. Basically, you can't buy 1 episode and see if you like it, then buy the rest. Instead you have to buy the full season. If it's on sale for $6 something this won't matter, buy it. If you're considering getting it for full price (Which it's worth) you should have a full idea of what you're getting into.

But I digress. These are really only small complaints in what is easily one of the best games of 2012 and an essential to anyone who is looking for a good story where they truly affect the people around them. 9.5/10

reviewText: Perhaps one of the best stories I've had the pleasure of experiencing in quite a few years. Especially amongst the zombie horror genre. TellTale have done a wonderful job in crafting a provocative story that yanks at the strings of your heart whenever it can. Forcing you to make tough decisions within a very short time, that often have dire and unforseen consequences. It's a beautifully woven tapestry of choices which can create varying and unique stories between each individual's playthrough. To top it all off, it has one of the most satisfying and emotional endings I've seen to date. It's hard to understate just how much the relationship that Lee and Clem develops can affect you as the player. For me it drove me into the role of a father figure trying to protect his daughter. And I imagine it can and will do the same for many others.\n\nWith all the praise I can give to the writing and story, I do have to point out a critical flaw with the game. In that, it's not much of a game at all. Point and click adventures have always been rather awkward for me, since they always just feel more like an interactive movie to me. And this can at times deter from your enjoyment of the story. A number of times I found myself hovering over my mouse or keyboard, just waiting for that inevitable quick time event. And as a result I felt myself growing somewhat detached from whats going on, which broke the immersion for me somewhat. But then again, this would not work as just a rolling movie either. As it is the decisions and choices that you make that help add a level of involvement to the story. Making it much more personal, as what happens is because -you- chose for it to happen. So you have to deal with the benefits and consequences of your decisions. There is no Good" or "Best" ending in this game. Only "Your" ending. There's no scoreboard for how many survivors you met/killed
date: how many Walkers you decapitated. It's a mature story that's meant to be enjoyed as just that
recommended: a story. If this is what interests you
hoursPlayed: then I can't in good conscience let you go without recommending The Walking Dead whole heartidly. If you're looking for another zombie game though
voteText: I'd suggest you move on. This is one for a mature audience.\n\n10/10 from me."

reviewText:
NOTICE: This review was originally written for the Xbox 360 version of the game and may not entirely reflect the PC version. The full, unedited version of this review may be viewed HERE[www.trueachievements.com].


Walk a Mile in Their Shoes

Telltale Games is no stranger to adventure games, and The Walking Dead is no stranger to success lately. A rapidly growing zombie mythos, The Walking Dead has hit the media trifecta with this game: literature, film, and gaming. But can this last piece of the puzzle equal the overwhelming acclaim of its other pieces?

Telltale's five episode series is self-admittedly more in tune with the Walking Dead comic books, and does not branch off of the television show. While set in the Walking Dead mythos, the plot and characters are original and unique. Furthermore, you do not even have to be a fan of the series in any form to appreciate this riveting, nerve-wracking journey. This review contains no spoilers but concerns the series as a whole, not the individual episodes. The review is broken up into segments with concise summaries immediately following each.

Graphics
Pros:
-Decent graphics for the price
-Style is reminiscent of comic series
-What little user interface there is, is partially customizable to tailor to your playstyle

Cons:
-Nothing spectacular, no stand-out locations, just-enough-for-the-job visuals

Sound
Pros:
-Voice actors exceptionally well suited for their respective characters
-Script and acting for bulk of game is captivating

Cons:
-Cannot skip dialogue, meaning thorough players will rehear a lot of potentially bland script

Plot
Pros:
-Huge focus on plot leads to a captivating drama
-Player choices can shape character opinions, dialogue, and cutscenes
-Each episode delivers a powerful punch of plot, but also contributes to the plot as a whole

Cons:
-Hard pressed to think of any

Gameplay
Pros:
-Gameplay choices lead to a plot tailored for you
-Rewind feature makes it possible to second-guess your choices, if unhappy with outcome
-If connected to the internet, choice synopsis at end of each episode compares you to others
-Control over dialogue, ‚Äústruggle‚Äù sequences, and suspenseful sequences immerse the player
-Simple enough to be enjoyed by casual Walking Dead fans looking to enjoy this title
-Few to no glitches or bugs

Cons:
-Hardcore adventure players may not be satisfied with the puzzles, or lack thereof
-Players not fond of visual novels may dislike the large focus on dialogue and plot
-Slow readers may struggle with timed dialogue choices

Length/Replay Value
Pros:
-Although short, delivers a powerful gaming experience

Cons:
-Not the best money-to-hours ratio
-Very little replay value (full game ‚Äì players may use rewind to experience different choices)

Total Score: 8.2/10

recommended: in the purest way I've ever seen a game execute it. It still clings a little too much to the pace-killing puzzles of the Monkey Island era

helpfulPercent: you spend most of your time talking to people and watching cutscenes. Many cutscenes involve quicktime events to reenforce that you have to take account of your actions and promises. Have you promised to shoot someone? The game puts you back in control and expects you to pull the trigger with a mouse click. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• a guy in your party? You better defend yourself by smashing Q when he jumps on your throat.\n\nDialogs are often timed too to add to the tension

The writing of the dialogs and the voice acting are excellent and create believable characters.\n\nThe game is very consistent and not only respects your choices

column16:
the game generally does a very good job at keeping the Fourth Wall intact once you've become used to the quicktime events.

I think games are still figuring out how to perform incredible storytelling and The Walking Dead delivers an experience that I'm looking forward to see serving as an inspiration for a new generation of adventure games. I recommend this game wholeheartedly to everyone who is not ashamed of crying in front of a computer screen.

reviewText: Telltale's The Walking Dead is based on the canon of the hit TV Show and graphic novel series.  It is a point-and-click adventure game with quicktime elements - and it's a very good one.  The narrative, storytelling, and characterization is top notch and if one can refer to a story as heavy" this game is more like having a pickup truck sitting on your chest.  It's a prime example of interactive storytelling and is an excellent model of how you can use the gaming medium to convey a story to an audience - even the camera angles it utilizes were wonderful
date: from staring at your reflection in a puddle as you beat someone's brain in to adding tension by having a skewed angle while you climb a ladder.  The game did have some pitfalls that comes with the point-and-click genre that it didn't avoicd unfortunately - repeatedly viewing things instead of acting on them/with them
recommended: repeating dialogue options accidentally without the ability to skip them
hoursPlayed: a few character and graphics glitches (I vividly remember speaking to an invisible Vernon and Kat cradling an invisible Duck in her arms) but besides a 4th wall breaking comic intervention these small negatives don't detract too much from the story as a whole.  The plot is very adult in nature and the gore and heavy themes are what you'd expect from a "Walking Dead" branded product.  What I found most interesting was the "illusion of choice" that seemed to be woven throughout the game.  Many people complain that every dialogue option and every choice you make should have an effect on the outcome of the game and many do; however
voteText: there are more than several situations in the game where no matter what you do something is going to go down in a certain way - many times in a way that could shock you.  As such
helpfulPercent: I recommend playing this game by the seat of your pants
votesHelpful: don't reload
votesTotal: don't try again.  It's a more rewarding experience in the end since probably that one thing you didn't want to happen is going to happen regardless of what actions you take.  This can be seen as a pro or a con depending on your personality.  I find it a plus
votesFunny: as it allows Telltale's writers to weave a tighter narrative that has a much larger effect on the viewer than if everything turned into sunshine and rainbows for you (which is not going to happen anyway).  Leave it for a second playthrough if you must
commentsCount: but imagine this game as more interacting with a movie that you can steer around as you please to explore the world and interact with the characters in.\n\nSPOILER FOLLOWS - Finally the ending wasn't too fulfilling to me
column16: it almost seems like Telltale was holding back for a future release.  I would have liked to see how your 'parenting' options throughout the episodes effected Clem
column17: and allowed you to see what kind of person she becomes after the credits roll.  Even if her actions post ending were in a montage format that would have been fine
column18:
allowing you to see if Clem can survive in this world with the lessons you've taught her. /SPOILERS

Pros:

Great storytelling (narrative
column21: "whole-package"
column22: etc.)\nHeavy
column23:
adult themes

Cons:

Minor point-and-click pitfalls
Ending didn't "wrap up" to my satisfaction
Some characters (while good) felt a little static or seemed to be only "plot-devices"

Even though I wasn't too impressed with the ending and the cons *appear* to outlist the pros this game is definitely worth a playthrough.  The story is great and this game is a great entrance for any gamer into interactive storytelling and what poing-and-click adventure games can be. B+"

reviewText: Fantastic game with an even more fanatastic story. Highly recommend anyone to buy and play this game.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is the prototype game in the industry that shows that storytelling and characterization in video games can easily match those we see in movies or television series. Your choices matter here more than anywhere else and can lead to devastation or salvation when you expect it the least. The well written story and your attachment to the characters - main or supporting - will keep you moving forward and make you question every decision you've made before. It's a game of 'what ifs...'.

The story begins right on the first day when the epidemic starts. The main character is Lee Everett, who is on his way to jail in a police patrol vehicle when they hit a zombified humanoid they'll refer to as 'Walkers'. After a bit of wandering in a forest we meet Clementine, the eight year old girl whose nanny has also been turned and her parents are cut off in the faraway Savannah. The two start bonding right after they meet and Lee tries to look after her the best he knows. It's a really an emotionally powerful relationship from the gecko that only gets deeper. The game never tries to be unrealistic about the characters and their motives. Their goal is to survive no matter what, and I mean no matter. Not to find out what has happened or get some kind of cure. No. This makes it so interesting, you aren't Superman nor an action hero with unlimited bullets. The characters are real, everyday people that care about their families and themselves.

The game has an episodic character. It has 5 episodes each lasting around 2-3 hours that adds up to a total of 12-14 hours of gameplay. Your choices move the story forward and the game sometimes hits you with an impossible choice that will make you wonder minutes after it. Sometimes it's really hard to make a choice, but sometimes it might not even matter in the end. You just never know when somebody steps in and changes everything. It's a great balance of making up your mind and not knowing what would've happened if. What is spectacular about the game that the other characters have their own stories and plans too, and it might not tally with your's. The rest if the cast isn't there to make your life comfortable. They aren't soulless vessels that obey everything you say. They can act on their own, even if you don't like it and often confront your choices.

As a Telltale game it has a comic book character that is unquestionable unique, but hardly state of art. Neither artistically nor technically is a phenomenal game, but it has its own tone. It has other problems too. Frame-rate drops are annoying and camera angle changes can result in a momentary freeze of screen. On the audio front the situation is much better. The music and the voice acting is top notch, that supports the deep and emotional story.

Telltale has hit the mark with The Walking Dead: Season 1. It's a spectacular point-and-click game where puzzles are secondary to the story. Yes, there will be times when you have to ask questions like, 'how to make this happen?' or 'how to make that work?', but those are only evanescent. The real question that you'll ask all the time is 'what is the right decision?' But you'll find out that there isn't one. It's a cruel world where everybody tries to survive and some tries to retain their humanity. If you're trying to find a superb interactive story, look no further, because The Walking Dead is a must have experience.

Rating: 84/100; Replay Value: 5/5; To Beat: 12-14 hours.

reviewText:
I have been a walking dead fan for a few years, but when this game came out about a year ago I did not pick it up. Only recently I got it on sale. WORDS CAN NOT EVEN EXPRESS HOW AMAZING THIS GAME IS. The best part about the game is that it's not just about the zombie killing. There is little to no gameplay, but that is what makes the game so great. The game often has you make decisions in the heat of the moment so you need to think about all the possible options and how they will effect the story line in the future, and how other characters will respond/ react to your decisions. it is so amazing to see how the story unfolds based on the decisions you make. Often you may regret them but thats the whole beauty of it. Another aspect of the game I love is the graphics. Although they are nothing that great they remind me like a comic book. The walking Dead essentaly puts you in the middle of an episode of the show so it's cool to decide what you will do, it's like the choose your own adventure books we all used to read back in grade school! All in all I enjoyed playing the game and would often find my self staring at the screen in shock or cussing at myself for a crappy decision. Im so glad they actully made a good Walking dead game (i'm looking at you survival instinct) and I cant wait to purchace season two when it gets on sale.
PLAY THIS GAME MUCH FEELS VERY DRAMA

best ever 10/10

reviewText: A good story is that one that evokes you with different reactions and feelings, and let me tell you, this game definitely gives you that. With a different pace and style than many games, this exquisite piece of game will give you such an experience that you don't get in many titles, especially on the Zombie/Survival genre. Based on your actual desicion making, your first experience will give you a sense of responsibility for every action you take, and will sumerge you into the story and develop a sense of caring for every character. Being a huge fan of The Walking Dead comic series, this game really got to me on the story level and I definitely recommend every fan of the genre should try it at least once.

reviewText:
Lots of nice situations, often times without the option you would want.. but what do you expect - and it all goes down alright for the sake of story.
The game is quite good, quite lengthy and the final chapter quite impressed me. I enjoyed it as a whole and I recall a lot of it despite playing the 5 seasons over approximately 18 months.

There are some great characters and some great situations. The game holds your hand a lot, but it's mainly a story-telling experience anyway - the only issue I had with the gameplay was the lengthy *actions* that can trigger if I clicked something twice, which you might do if you think that your character (Lee) might have the same insight you have (not often the case). Nonetheless, the game is fun and I recommend you play it, though probably picked up on a good sale tbh.

My biggest peeve was that a good number of episodes were driven by character interactions between your group, but the game never presented me with the option I wanted (namely who I should be accusing). I found it weird as much of the game was about managing relationships AND ACCUSATIONS, but the time that I most wanted to accuse somebody of the poison that saw massive change (and the loss of the single group member that I wanted to keep), there was no option to remove the single most destructive group member (my opinion for a while before that happened, and ultimately proven by the end of the game to be your *worst* team member).


I hope Telltale Games grow a pair and tell their funding groups that they want to make a more ambitious game. From what I've heard, they may already have done so.

reviewText: Oh my God, this is one of the best  zombie games I've ever played.  When I first saw that it was  developed by Telltale games I though it would be a  just a bog standard point & click adventure game, which it turned out not to be;  it's sort of half way between a p&p and a  third person action game (with some first person viewpoints).    I was immediately  struck by the art style which reminded me a lot of Borderlands and Street Fighter 4 in its   pseudo cartoon - watercolour washed   graphics.  The voice acting is brilliant accentuating  the  emotions that run throughout the game which are very powerful.   The way you choose to play the game, i.e. your  actions and choices affect how the story plays out across the entire series, making this  a game that has loads of replayability potential.\n\nI never thought I'd be saying this about   an adventure game, but I've enjoyed playing this more than other zombie games e.g. Left 4 Dead, Dead Island and the Resident Evil  franchise.

reviewText:
It's tough to explain just how hard The Walking Dead is. Progression is simple, the puzzles smart and logical, and the controls are barely more complex than your average point-and-click ‚Äî but it's hard nonetheless. The difficulty arises not from the actual game itself, but from the choices it forces you to make as a player. You will make mistakes. You'll wish you could take them back, but you can't. This is the world your characters live in, and the choices you make can't be unmade, only lived with.

It's rare to see a game so focused on the psychological aspects of its design. There are few moments in The Walking Dead where your skill as a gamer or your ability to survive will let you stand apart from the average player. Instead, what defines your experience is not how well you carry out your actions but how well you decide what course of action you are going to take. And nothing is more frightening, more difficult, or more powerful than knowing there is nothing you can do to change the consequences of your mistakes.

All you can do is hope that the choices you make are the right ones, and carry on.

reviewText:
‚ÄúSo, you think you‚Äôre strong, right?

You think you can last longer, take more pressure. You know what‚Äôs best for yourself as well as for the people around you. Right?

Right. Let‚Äôs put you to the test.‚Äù

That‚Äôs what The Walking Dead is essentially about. What we‚Äôre looking at is‚Ä¶ ‚Ä†checks her game record‚Ä† ‚Ä¶a 14-hour game-movie-story. For most people this will be an exceptionally intense experience. This is far less about standard gaming than it is about storytelling, & the story being told will put you through a handful. That‚Äôs what it means to do.

As the story unfolds you‚Äôre confronted with many decisions, most of which are neither easy to make nor to be taken lightly. Nearly all of them you have to make under genuine pressure. The game doesn‚Äôt judge; this is up to yourself. It, however, observes carefully. Even though not all of your decisions seem to have a massive & immediate influence on what happens next, everything you do is noted.

The Walking Dead as a story has quite a radical way of handling its protagonists. Something similar you might get to see in a horror movie‚Ä¶ The game doesn‚Äôt make much of an effort to wait for you to catch up. The pressure is on everyone; on the people inside the story as well as on you, the outsider playing the game. It‚Äôs a good thing that there are several chapters/episodes, & finishing one of them does not, immediately push you into the next. So you get breathers. Time to think, time to look back, even a chance to actually go back in time & do things differently if you so decide. It‚Äôs still furiously intense, fiercely confrontational. If you make your way through this & it makes you feel like you just got pushed through a mixer, don‚Äôt worry; everything‚Äôs purrfectly fine.

So you think you‚Äôre strong. Right? You think you‚Äôre a toughie, a hero, a leader. Right?

Then go ahead, try this. You'll have to prove it to this story.


-‚Ä†kali

>bought the walking dead
>played through the first 2 episodes and half of the 3rd

reviewText: This game is absolutely wonderful. I'm a big fan of TWD, both the comics and the show, and this certainly lived up to expectations. Even though I told myself throughout my whole first playthrough not to get attached to any character (because seriously, it's The Walking Dead - we all know what happens to our favorite characters), I still did and the ending still pretty much ruined my life.\n\nWhen playing through this, I definitely recommend not going back to change anything your first playthrough. Even though I hated some of the choices I made at the time, it definitely made the whole experience more enjoyable. I recently replayed it on a different save right before the release of Season 2 just to see where other choices would have gotten me and it was just as amazing the second time even though I knew everything that was going to happen.

reviewText: The Walking Dead is not another zombie game, it's a game that happened to have zombie apocalypse in it but main focus is on characters. Game explores interactions in a closed group of people and you often are forced to make hard decisions whenever you like it or not. What i noticed early on that not every stranger you meet in game is honest or open with you. Often you'll be faced with situations that requires somekind of trust and you just cannot trust someone for whatever reason. Everything you do or say has consequences in one way or another and sooner or later you'll have to face them. At the end of every chapter you get little chart showing your choices and what other players picked.\nMain protagonist is Lee. A black guy who has a secret which he (you) can reveal to the rest of group or not. Lee early on in the game finds a little girl Clementine. After Lee finds Clem he promises her to find her parents and they travel together from then on. Even though Lee isn't Clementine's dad he sure does care about her like it's his own daughter, giving her symphaty and tips when she need it. The game is worth to play just to see how those two interact. Also note that Clementine isn't boring nor annoying for a child character. Possibly best portrayed child character ever in video games.\nOverall I'd give this game 10/10 even though this doesn't feel like a real" game but I have to question what is a game? This is exemplar of "chose your own adventure" book. Story has great pacing
date: nice soundtrack and tension where it's needed. It is unbelievable how good this game story is so I highly recommend to play it for everyone even those who don't play many games.\n\n"

reviewText:
T_T What a journey....

Here's the game divided into segments.

- Graphics 10/10
Telltale using a comic style graphic design was the perfect choice for what it offers and it fits the mood.

- Storyline 10/10
Anyone who has played this game has had one of those moments where they tear up even just a little. The walking dead game was a joruney and a rollercoaster of emotions through out the whole 5 episodes. It has it's plot twists and a sad but beautiful ending that will make you want to try the season 2 of the walking dead which I suggest you buy. This game's story mode alone made the full price worth it.

- Options 9/10
I wish there would be more graphic options for the game and some more gameplay options but other than that it's good. Offers the obligatory subtitles option and plenty of options regarding hints and help.

- Controls 8/10
I had moments of frustration when I got couldn't move the camera to the way I was going and the keyboard controls in general in my opinion are weird. I definitely suggest using a controller for this one.

- Gameplay 9/10
As much as I liked the story the gameplay makes the game unique in it's own way and makes you want to play more of it.
The choices you make in the game, the lines you choose, the people you trust make up the ending. There need to be more games in which you choose the path you take, will you go with the whole group or go alone? Will you kill this guy or walk away? It all matters, and that is what I like about this game. I expirienced a glitch at one point where I couldn't connect to the game even though it's a singleplayer game what fixed this issue was before clicking start upon launch I pressed Alt+Tab and it worked like a charm.

- Final Verdict 10/10
This is a must play game for everyone, I recommend this game for any gamer to try at sometime in their life.

reviewText: I have never felt the urge to cry or feel so emotionally involved in a movie, book, or video game, until I played The Walking Dead. I have also never played a game where I felt so connected in its fictional characters' experiences.  It is a very depressing, emotional, and truly immersive video game like no other. It shows the possible but very unpleasant decisions humans have to make in very bad situations, yet  it also shows us how we can still hope and choose to do good for each other, regardless of the unfortunate experiences that happen to us.\n\nThank you Telltale Games for giving me really good video game experience to remember. I will definitely look forward to more of your games, and The Walking Dead Season 2. Now I can't wait to play The Wolf Among Us that's waiting for me in my Steam library.

reviewText: Telltale's The Walking Dead is based on the canon of the hit TV Show and graphic novel series.  It is a point-and-click adventure game with quicktime elements - and it's a very good one.  The narrative, storytelling, and characterization is top notch and if one can refer to a story as heavy" this game is more like having a pickup truck sitting on your chest.  It's a prime example of interactive storytelling and is an excellent model of how you can use the gaming medium to convey a story to an audience - even the camera angles it utilizes were wonderful
date: from staring at your reflection in a puddle as you beat someone's brain in to adding tension by having a skewed angle while you climb a ladder.  The game did have some pitfalls that comes with the point-and-click genre that it didn't avoicd unfortunately - repeatedly viewing things instead of acting on them/with them
recommended: repeating dialogue options accidentally without the ability to skip them
hoursPlayed: a few character and graphics glitches (I vividly remember speaking to an invisible Vernon and Kat cradling an invisible Duck in her arms) but besides a 4th wall breaking comic intervention these small negatives don't detract too much from the story as a whole.  The plot is very adult in nature and the gore and heavy themes are what you'd expect from a "Walking Dead" branded product.  What I found most interesting was the "illusion of choice" that seemed to be woven throughout the game.  Many people complain that every dialogue option and every choice you make should have an effect on the outcome of the game and many do; however
voteText: there are more than several situations in the game where no matter what you do something is going to go down in a certain way - many times in a way that could shock you.  As such
helpfulPercent: I recommend playing this game by the seat of your pants
votesHelpful: don't reload
votesTotal: don't try again.  It's a more rewarding experience in the end since probably that one thing you didn't want to happen is going to happen regardless of what actions you take.  This can be seen as a pro or a con depending on your personality.  I find it a plus
votesFunny: as it allows Telltale's writers to weave a tighter narrative that has a much larger effect on the viewer than if everything turned into sunshine and rainbows for you (which is not going to happen anyway).  Leave it for a second playthrough if you must
commentsCount: but imagine this game as more interacting with a movie that you can steer around as you please to explore the world and interact with the characters in.\n\nSPOILER FOLLOWS - Finally the ending wasn't too fulfilling to me
column16: it almost seems like Telltale was holding back for a future release.  I would have liked to see how your 'parenting' options throughout the episodes effected Clem
column17: and allowed you to see what kind of person she becomes after the credits roll.  Even if her actions post ending were in a montage format that would have been fine
column18:
allowing you to see if Clem can survive in this world with the lessons you've taught her. /SPOILERS

Pros:

Great storytelling (narrative
column21: "whole-package"
column22: etc.)\nHeavy
column23:
adult themes

Cons:

Minor point-and-click pitfalls
Ending didn't "wrap up" to my satisfaction
Some characters (while good) felt a little static or seemed to be only "plot-devices"

Even though I wasn't too impressed with the ending and the cons *appear* to outlist the pros this game is definitely worth a playthrough.  The story is great and this game is a great entrance for any gamer into interactive storytelling and what poing-and-click adventure games can be. B+"

reviewText: This game is absolutely amazing. But not by standards of games you are used to. This isn't one of those -Grinding, beat up the enemies repeatedly, level up, or run through enviroment kind of games... this is an emotionally involved decision driven game. There are many options for discussion and relationships with characters. Most everything is a cutscene with a choice in between, and there are small puzzles between discussions and a lot of button mashing. The graphics are also unique and most people would struggle to get used to them this day in age, but I don't. I love this game with all my heart, it's amazingly genuine and full of incredible characters that each vary and all feel realistic and sincere. I for one do not call this game boring for its unique gameplay, or ugly for its unique style. So please, try this game, give it a chance, and be in for the experience of your life.\n\nMy total hours played should just tell ya.

reviewText: I've seen my share of zombie movies and played my share of zombie games without ever becoming particularly impressed by any. Honestly I find most of them outright stupid, and with the zombie hype that has been going on the last few years the genre as a whole mostly leaves a foul taste in my mouth. But somehow I got talked into watching this show called The Walking Dead" and it totally blew me over. Well written
date: great character building and feelings flying all over the board. I found it amazing that something related to zombies could be THAT good.\n\nThen I learned about that this series
recommended: or rather the universe of that series
hoursPlayed: was going to be carried over to an episodic adventure type game by no other than Telltale Games. A company that has helped keeping the adventure genre of gaming alive when it felt almost extinct. As a BIG adventure game fan I have happily supported this company by getting mostly everything they have put out
voteText:
and that was also mainly the reason I got this series as well.

I honestly had very little expectation of how this game series would be as I failed to see how it even would work to transfer the great writing and suspense that I experienced in the TV-series to an adventure type game. Even though I read good reviews of it I kept putting off playing it. I was absolutely certain that it was going to leave me disappointed.

Well
helpfulPercent: finally I got around to play it
votesHelpful: and now I kick myself fo not playing it sooner. I can not believe how good this game is. I don't think I can remember better storywriting in any game I've played before. You really get to know the characters you meet and you get feelings and opinions about them. You're forced to make tough decisions in critical moments and you can never be sure if you did the right thing. Well

You'll find yourself laughing

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is an absolute must-have game for anyone who likes a good story.

So what is it? Essentially The Walking Dead is an episodic point-and-click adventure game with action sequences. More importantly, it's a captivating and touching story of a man and a little girl trying to survive a zombie apocalypse.

The puzzles are straightforward, the action sequences are very easy, there's no real challenge to be had in this game - and that's a good thing. The Walking Dead is ALL about the experience, and that experience is sensational. You make decisions for your character that influence not only the events in that episode, but also the overarching story. There are some grueling decisions to be made and you don't have all day to decide, which adds a lot of tension to the scenes.

If you've seen the TV show or read the comics then this will be an even better experience. The game takes place prior to the TV show but in the same area, with locations and characters from the TV show making cameos, albeit with different voice actors.

The 400 Days DLC is a sixth episode that is mostly unconnected to the original season. You play as five different characters in short stories that come together in a final arc. It's worth your while, but not as long as the other episodes and the actual ramifications of your choices in the DLC won't be felt until season 2.

TL;DR:
Buy it now!

reviewText:
T_T What a journey....

Here's the game divided into segments.

- Graphics 10/10
Telltale using a comic style graphic design was the perfect choice for what it offers and it fits the mood.

- Storyline 10/10
Anyone who has played this game has had one of those moments where they tear up even just a little. The walking dead game was a joruney and a rollercoaster of emotions through out the whole 5 episodes. It has it's plot twists and a sad but beautiful ending that will make you want to try the season 2 of the walking dead which I suggest you buy. This game's story mode alone made the full price worth it.

- Options 9/10
I wish there would be more graphic options for the game and some more gameplay options but other than that it's good. Offers the obligatory subtitles option and plenty of options regarding hints and help.

- Controls 8/10
I had moments of frustration when I got couldn't move the camera to the way I was going and the keyboard controls in general in my opinion are weird. I definitely suggest using a controller for this one.

- Gameplay 9/10
As much as I liked the story the gameplay makes the game unique in it's own way and makes you want to play more of it.
The choices you make in the game, the lines you choose, the people you trust make up the ending. There need to be more games in which you choose the path you take, will you go with the whole group or go alone? Will you kill this guy or walk away? It all matters, and that is what I like about this game. I expirienced a glitch at one point where I couldn't connect to the game even though it's a singleplayer game what fixed this issue was before clicking start upon launch I pressed Alt+Tab and it worked like a charm.

- Final Verdict 10/10
This is a must play game for everyone, I recommend this game for any gamer to try at sometime in their life.

reviewText:
This game will make you afraid.

It will make you laugh.

It will make you cry.

It will make you love.

It will make you hate.

It will make you question your choices, not only in the game but in life itself.

It will make you wonder what could have been.

It will make you realize things you have never thought of before.

If you have never played this game, you have never fully understood the concept of a zombie apocalypse. I'm not sure I understand it fully, even now.

But one thing I do understand is that this is the most beautiful game I have ever experienced.

At times, you may not have fun. You may feel wronged. You may feel cheated. You may feel repulsed. And this game is not for the faint of heart.

But if you ever hope to fully understand yourself, and others, you will play this game.

Play this game.

reviewText:
First of all, if you think that this game is like your traditional point n click game (like Nancy Drew) then this game is not the game your looking for because Telltale Series game are a bit more than just point n click, You control the actions, relationships and dialogoues of the characters in the story.

The Walking Dead is a Telltale Game Series where your decisions affect the flow of the story and not the actual ending itself. You decide what dialogues you see fit for the situation and the actions you choose affects your relationship towards the other characters.

If you want to embody your own personality into the protagonist (Lee Everett) then go for it. You might even know what it feels like to make tough decisions and what it feels to make big sacrifices. This game is not just choosing dialogues but also interacting with the environment. (but not like Nancy Drew)

The story is totally very good. It would make you feel like your watching the series itself. The ending is very sad and touching. It can make you shed tears.

This game is really worth buying but I recommend that you buy it when it's on sale (preferrably a daily deal) so that you'll be able to buy the DLC and Season 2 for a cheaper price.

The 400 Days DLC is not worth its price since it's quite very short for the 5 additional characters but what's good about it is that the actions you chose on Season 1 and 400 days will be carried over to Season 2. That's why it's worth buying Season 1, 400 Days and Season 2 altogether. Overall, it's a great game with a totally touching story. By the way, I'm not a fan of the series but I highly recommend it to everyone.

Story: 10/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 10/10
Music: 10/10

Overall: 9.8/10

reviewText: The Walking Dead is an interesting visual novel/point and click type of game. When I first went into it I thought it was about  talking to my group and trying to change their fates through our interactions. I was horribly disappointing to realize no matter what you do or what you say, the outcome is always the same.\n\nThere is a huge amount of illusion of choice" There is one point in the game where you have to choose between saving this guy or saving this girl. When you save one
date: the other dies and the story goes in a different direction and encourages replaying the game! Right? Wrong. Not twenty minutes later
recommended: the person you save dies anyways. In the end no matter your choice
hoursPlayed: both end up dead. There was no choice! This pattern continued through the whole game
voteText: I'd be promoted with a choice and the inevitable would eventually happen. I finished the game with a bad taste in my mouth.\n\nThat is until I saw a discussion online about Kenny
helpfulPercent: one of the characters. The thread started off with someone saying how awesome Kenny was.He always had your back
votesHelpful: was friendly
votesTotal: sacrificed himself
votesFunny: he was cool. I agreed. However most people in the thread said he was a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•! I was completely in disagreement! They were even listing quotes he NEVER said in the game! That was when it hit me. The events of the game are unchangeable but the characters and the way they interact with you is completely different for each player depending on your choices. Kenny was a nice guy in my game but a jerk in many other people's games. It made discussion about the game a ton of fun since everyone's experience with each character was completely different. Some characters tell some players things other players will never hear them say.\n\nSure the events were out of your control but that kind of game would be a little high budget for Telltale
commentsCount: so I think what they pulled off was pretty well done all things considered. My advice is do NOT go into the game with the thought that you can change the outcome of certain character's gruesome fates
column16: but you can change their personalities
column17: and compare the differences and similarities between your characters and your friend's characters' personalities. Your "best bro" in your game could be your friend's biggest rival or worst enemy!"

reviewText: Oh my God, this is one of the best  zombie games I've ever played.  When I first saw that it was  developed by Telltale games I though it would be a  just a bog standard point & click adventure game, which it turned out not to be;  it's sort of half way between a p&p and a  third person action game (with some first person viewpoints).    I was immediately  struck by the art style which reminded me a lot of Borderlands and Street Fighter 4 in its   pseudo cartoon - watercolour washed   graphics.  The voice acting is brilliant accentuating  the  emotions that run throughout the game which are very powerful.   The way you choose to play the game, i.e. your  actions and choices affect how the story plays out across the entire series, making this  a game that has loads of replayability potential.\n\nI never thought I'd be saying this about   an adventure game, but I've enjoyed playing this more than other zombie games e.g. Left 4 Dead, Dead Island and the Resident Evil  franchise.
