reviewText:
Wow, what a ride this was.

TellTale has done a great job. The writers created a story which was not only captivating but an amazing emotional experience.

The Walking Dead is a comic-book drawn style adventure game in which the choices you make tailor the story you play going forward and continuously shape the people around you and your game play experience.

Every action has consequences and you never can please everyone.

-----------------
-- Gameplay
-----------------
The game mechanics are nice and simple. The story progresses through point-click action and mainly through dialog with the people you encounter.

During the dialogs you will be presented with several choices of answers.
Each answer may or may not have consequences and alters how other people see you, trust you or even start disliking you.

Every now and then you will end up in a heavy story-changing scenario in which the story going forward is altered quite strongly.
You might need to make a choice to save one or another person, run or fight or other difficult choice.
Those choices alter the story quite drastic in places to the extend whereby you might end up continuing your story with different people then if you had made different choices or people start treating you completely different from that moment on.

-----------------
-- The Story
-----------------

The game places you in control of Lee a man on his way to prison as the story begins and has no idea yet what is happening.
As you are trying to deal with the world as it now is you stumble across an 8 year old girl named Clementine who you will decide to help out and team up with.

For the duration of the story your relationship with Clementine and others you meet evolves and are shaped continuously based on the choices you make and how you treat each person.

I don't want to give to much of the main background story away so I'm not going into to much details.
Let's just say, for the rest of the game you and Clementine will come across other people and groups, some highly irritating and disturbed while others are more neutral and well meaning, though you will find it hard to quickly know who to trust and who you can't.

Quite often you will find yourself in situations you wish you could make different choices then the ones presented or make choices you know might not be right but need to be made.

-----------------
-- Summary
-----------------

Personally I can only say that TellTale and the Writes have delivered something very simplistic but yet so wonderful you are feeling you are writing your own story which will grab you, slowly pulling you deeper and deeper into this emotional roller coaster ride and will not let you go.

By the end of Episode 5 you will just find yourself staring blankly at the credits slowly processing this whole experience.
Well, that what it was like for me and I'm already looking very much forward to December 17th to continue on.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough and hope you will enjoy it as much as I have.

reviewText:
If you're thinking about getting this game, you're probably thinking some things like: Uh oh a game based on a book/TV show? That usually doesn't work. Or maybe you're thinking: Point and click? Check please! Or maybe you're not too excited about the month to month episode thing? Or maybe you didn't like some of Telltale's past titles?

And you know what, some of your concerns may even be valid; it really depends on your expectations for this awesome release, so let me try to set some of those expectations. First of all, The Walking Dead game is for and will be loved by--and loved by is a guarantee, graphic novel readers--any true fan of Robert Kirkman's source material. Anyone looking to run and gun down zombies will not get that out of this game. You certainly don't have to have read the book or seen the show to enjoy this game; just be sure that you are planning to get into and be part of a story-rich experience.

The Walking Dead game is no Burn Zombie Burn or some other bash as many zombies' brains in as possible game. This game is a lot more of an RPG than a shooter.

You start the game the day the zombie apocalypse begins concurrently from the start of the comic book series. You play as Lee, and just as in the book (and in the TV show) where the main character Rick was initially thrown into a chaotic journey by himself to find other survivorsthat's you as Lee in The Walking Dead game.

There are plenty of action sequences, but your time in this game is mostly spent literally being a part of the story making some tough (and some not so tough) decisions. It's the tough decisions that will affect how the rest of the game unfolds for you, and you'll have to live with the consequences of every option you choose.

The game does give you the option of rewinding" back to a specific checkpoint
date: and you can go forward from there and choose a different option that overwrites your original decision if that's your style. But I won't do that until I complete the entire series. I tried to make the main character call "the right move" when presented with choice; but there is a time limit when decision time comes
recommended: and sometimes you may regret a hasty decision. For example
hoursPlayed: you'll have to choose one life over another twice during just the first episode
voteText: and I'm not sure that I made the "right" choice in one of those moments. But I will live with my decision until after playing through the entire series just to "keep it real." The game sure does get an A for replay value.\n\nJust as in the graphic novel (and the TV show)
helpfulPercent: the story is much less about zombies and more about what happens to society
votesHelpful: its morals
votesTotal: laws and standards when government is lost and the planet becomes mostly uninhabitable. But this time you don't just watch it unfold on paper or on your TV screen; in this game you're part of the storyyou control your integrity
votesFunny: your morality and ultimately your destiny. And there's real
commentsCount: heartfelt emotion in The Walking Dead game combined with very believable scenarios. Color me a sissy
column16: but I actually got a little misty over one of the decisions that "I had to" make.\n\nThe Walking Dead game is excellentespecially for just a point and click. It's as gritty and graphic as the comic book
column17: and it's very story-rich. The graphics are appropriately very comic-bookesque. I really do feel like I'm part of a different story arc in the freakin' book! Plus anyone clamoring for a Platinum Trophy (or whatever the top achievement for getting all in-game achievements is on your platform) could get an easy one here; all the trophies are unmissable simply by finishing all the chapters in every episode.\n\nThe Walking Dead game is a deep
column18: personal and emotional adventure."

reviewText:
This game will make you afraid.

It will make you laugh.

It will make you cry.

It will make you love.

It will make you hate.

It will make you question your choices, not only in the game but in life itself.

It will make you wonder what could have been.

It will make you realize things you have never thought of before.

If you have never played this game, you have never fully understood the concept of a zombie apocalypse. I'm not sure I understand it fully, even now.

But one thing I do understand is that this is the most beautiful game I have ever experienced.

At times, you may not have fun. You may feel wronged. You may feel cheated. You may feel repulsed. And this game is not for the faint of heart.

But if you ever hope to fully understand yourself, and others, you will play this game.

Play this game.

reviewText: I never was very fond of zombies. I only watched the first and half of the second season of The Walking Dead TV-show and each other (post-)apocalyptic scenario (as War against Machines, Nuclear Holocaust, Alien Invasion or global Eco-Disaster) I prefer over a zombie apocalypse - both in real life and in video games. But if you are interested in a strong narrative and a video game triggering emotions like a great movie would do, then there is no way around Telltale's The Walking Dead.\n\nThe gameplay is minimalistic. You click on already highlighted objects/persons to push the story forward but not to solve any puzzles or riddles or fill your inventory as you may expect from an adventure game. Even Heavy Rain" was more of a game than The Walking Dead is
date: but this is interactive storytelling at its best.\nThe great voice-acting makes all the characters you meet reasonable and authentic. Actually Melissa Hutchison (who speaks Clementine) won the ‚ÄúBest Performance by a Female" at the 2013 Spike Video Games Awards.\nOh well
recommended:
talking about Clementine. Usually children in video games are just plain annoying or they are drawn in an unlikely precocious way acting like adults with their bodyscale set to 0.6. Not so here. I can't imagine the cold-hearted kitty-slaying villain you have to be to not care about Clementine and do whatever it takes to guide her safely through this horror. It broke my heart when we had to part.

So eventually you will figure that all your gameplay- and dialogue choices won't even change the outcome of the story but just how your fellow companions stand towards you and whether if they like you or not. And maybe that is the most important lesson we can distill off The Walking Dead for the upcoming apocalypse ‚Äì both in real life and in video games.

First playthrough: ~15 hrs.

Here is a three episode mini-series from Extra Credits about various topics relating to Telltale's The Walking Dead. (minor Spoilers)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qizgjT4UXa4"

reviewText:
This game is pure interactive story more than anything. There are a few puzzles, some quicktime sequences to keep you on your toes, but more than anything it's a game that sells itself entirely on the strength of its narrative. If that's not what you're looking for, this won't be for you.

Character models and animations are a bit dated, lip-syncing is pretty average, nothing about this game on a technical level really stands out. But as an interactive story, I can honestly say I've never felt so invested in a group of fictional characters before. Everyone is flawed but usually sympathetic, and the protagonist and his constant child companion are some of the most likeable characters in games.

Even if Lee isn't a generic everyman"
date: you learn to very quickly identify with him and see things from his perspective
recommended: and Clementine is perhaps the only well-done child character in any video game ever. She's realistic
hoursPlayed: she's cute
voteText: she's scared
helpfulPercent: and she looks up to you. Every action you end up taking will end up going through the filter of "what will Clem think?"

reviewText:
First of all, if you think that this game is like your traditional point n click game (like Nancy Drew) then this game is not the game your looking for because Telltale Series game are a bit more than just point n click, You control the actions, relationships and dialogoues of the characters in the story.

The Walking Dead is a Telltale Game Series where your decisions affect the flow of the story and not the actual ending itself. You decide what dialogues you see fit for the situation and the actions you choose affects your relationship towards the other characters.

If you want to embody your own personality into the protagonist (Lee Everett) then go for it. You might even know what it feels like to make tough decisions and what it feels to make big sacrifices. This game is not just choosing dialogues but also interacting with the environment. (but not like Nancy Drew)

The story is totally very good. It would make you feel like your watching the series itself. The ending is very sad and touching. It can make you shed tears.

This game is really worth buying but I recommend that you buy it when it's on sale (preferrably a daily deal) so that you'll be able to buy the DLC and Season 2 for a cheaper price.

The 400 Days DLC is not worth its price since it's quite very short for the 5 additional characters but what's good about it is that the actions you chose on Season 1 and 400 days will be carried over to Season 2. That's why it's worth buying Season 1, 400 Days and Season 2 altogether. Overall, it's a great game with a totally touching story. By the way, I'm not a fan of the series but I highly recommend it to everyone.

Story: 10/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 10/10
Music: 10/10

Overall: 9.8/10

reviewText:
Honestly, I can only really fault the game on two things.

No. 1, The fact that a lot of your choices early on feel like they have little/no meaning.  However, as the story progresses, choices definitely feel like they have more impact, endgame especially.

and No. 2, the engine isn't perfect.  For instance, when the player has made several neutral-decisions... but the overall allignment balance may be either to one side or the other, some dialogue choices by the NPC can feel like they came out of nowhere.  This sometimes leads to the overall story feeling a little bit stilted and disingenuous.

However, these 2 drawbacks (at least for me) weren't dealbreakers; the story still flowed fairly well and the whole game I was constantly struggling with what was the right" decision.  Emotions ran high during many of the major turning-points in the story

reviewText:
If you're thinking about getting this game, you're probably thinking some things like: Uh oh a game based on a book/TV show? That usually doesn't work. Or maybe you're thinking: Point and click? Check please! Or maybe you're not too excited about the month to month episode thing? Or maybe you didn't like some of Telltale's past titles?

And you know what, some of your concerns may even be valid; it really depends on your expectations for this awesome release, so let me try to set some of those expectations. First of all, The Walking Dead game is for and will be loved by--and loved by is a guarantee, graphic novel readers--any true fan of Robert Kirkman's source material. Anyone looking to run and gun down zombies will not get that out of this game. You certainly don't have to have read the book or seen the show to enjoy this game; just be sure that you are planning to get into and be part of a story-rich experience.

The Walking Dead game is no Burn Zombie Burn or some other bash as many zombies' brains in as possible game. This game is a lot more of an RPG than a shooter.

You start the game the day the zombie apocalypse begins concurrently from the start of the comic book series. You play as Lee, and just as in the book (and in the TV show) where the main character Rick was initially thrown into a chaotic journey by himself to find other survivorsthat's you as Lee in The Walking Dead game.

There are plenty of action sequences, but your time in this game is mostly spent literally being a part of the story making some tough (and some not so tough) decisions. It's the tough decisions that will affect how the rest of the game unfolds for you, and you'll have to live with the consequences of every option you choose.

The game does give you the option of rewinding" back to a specific checkpoint
date: and you can go forward from there and choose a different option that overwrites your original decision if that's your style. But I won't do that until I complete the entire series. I tried to make the main character call "the right move" when presented with choice; but there is a time limit when decision time comes
recommended: and sometimes you may regret a hasty decision. For example
hoursPlayed: you'll have to choose one life over another twice during just the first episode
voteText: and I'm not sure that I made the "right" choice in one of those moments. But I will live with my decision until after playing through the entire series just to "keep it real." The game sure does get an A for replay value.\n\nJust as in the graphic novel (and the TV show)
helpfulPercent: the story is much less about zombies and more about what happens to society
votesHelpful: its morals
votesTotal: laws and standards when government is lost and the planet becomes mostly uninhabitable. But this time you don't just watch it unfold on paper or on your TV screen; in this game you're part of the storyyou control your integrity
votesFunny: your morality and ultimately your destiny. And there's real
commentsCount: heartfelt emotion in The Walking Dead game combined with very believable scenarios. Color me a sissy
column16: but I actually got a little misty over one of the decisions that "I had to" make.\n\nThe Walking Dead game is excellentespecially for just a point and click. It's as gritty and graphic as the comic book
column17: and it's very story-rich. The graphics are appropriately very comic-bookesque. I really do feel like I'm part of a different story arc in the freakin' book! Plus anyone clamoring for a Platinum Trophy (or whatever the top achievement for getting all in-game achievements is on your platform) could get an easy one here; all the trophies are unmissable simply by finishing all the chapters in every episode.\n\nThe Walking Dead game is a deep
column18: personal and emotional adventure."

reviewText:
Excellent storytelling throughout is where this game is really strong. You do begin to actually care about a lot of the characters which is something most video games are lacking (although admittedly, a lot don't aim for this). This is where the ame truly excels; it will scare you, shock you, make you laugh, probably cry, and in the end you'll just genuinely enjoy it (and after all, isn't that what we all play video games for?).

The decisions you make as you go through are also a big selling point. the developers have clearly worked very hard on this aspect, and your decisions will have a very real effect on the game. The decision points are well designed, with almost all of them being difficult choices that really make you think about what you would do in the situation. You also get a breakdown at the end of each episode of how many other players made the same choices as you, which is a nice touch.

There is also a very unique graphical style to this game, at first it seems a bit strange, and you could almost accuse the graphics of being bad"
date: but it gives a feeling to the game like no other
recommended: which can only be a good thing.\n\nThe gameplay is a bit lacklustre

reviewText:
Right in the feels.

The Walking Dead is an adventure RPG in the vein of old style point and click games. You are tasked with moving the protagonist through a series of puzzles and decisions through a point and click interface.

You meet a lot of characters who all react to you and your decisions in different ways. Decisions you make can result in anything from someone being angry with you to the direct death of a main character. The characters are all memorable. All of them.

The puzzles are fun and not too difficult to solve. The game is more about the other people and how you treat them and acti infront of them.

You should play this game for the story if nothing else. The story is fantastic and the decisions you make hold weight. It's kind of an interactive choose your own adventure book.

The art style is very enjoyable and the writing is some of the best. I can't talk about the plot too much at the risk of spoiling it but I will say that it is a very satisfying story.

I really enjoyed this series of tales and highly recommend you play them!

reviewText:
First of all, if you think that this game is like your traditional point n click game (like Nancy Drew) then this game is not the game your looking for because Telltale Series game are a bit more than just point n click, You control the actions, relationships and dialogoues of the characters in the story.

The Walking Dead is a Telltale Game Series where your decisions affect the flow of the story and not the actual ending itself. You decide what dialogues you see fit for the situation and the actions you choose affects your relationship towards the other characters.

If you want to embody your own personality into the protagonist (Lee Everett) then go for it. You might even know what it feels like to make tough decisions and what it feels to make big sacrifices. This game is not just choosing dialogues but also interacting with the environment. (but not like Nancy Drew)

The story is totally very good. It would make you feel like your watching the series itself. The ending is very sad and touching. It can make you shed tears.

This game is really worth buying but I recommend that you buy it when it's on sale (preferrably a daily deal) so that you'll be able to buy the DLC and Season 2 for a cheaper price.

The 400 Days DLC is not worth its price since it's quite very short for the 5 additional characters but what's good about it is that the actions you chose on Season 1 and 400 days will be carried over to Season 2. That's why it's worth buying Season 1, 400 Days and Season 2 altogether. Overall, it's a great game with a totally touching story. By the way, I'm not a fan of the series but I highly recommend it to everyone.

Story: 10/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 10/10
Music: 10/10

Overall: 9.8/10

reviewText:
As a fan of the first season of the show, I really wanted this game to work. It was recommended to me as a great story driven game with deep charcters. And it is exactly that, but more!

Not really enjoying this genre - I was beyond pleasantly suprised with the game!
It made me reconsider my thoughts on the genre as a whole.

The word as we all know it has ended. Zombie craziness has ensued. You are Lee, you are riding in the back of a police car when the game begins. You'll find a small child and become responsible for her and here is where the similarities between your playthrough and mine will end!

Your game will be shaped by the choices you make, or don't make, the things you say, or don't say and the people you save, or don't...

The game has an understandably small cast, because, you know, the world has ended.

The charcters you encounter are well written and believable. Resulting in sometimes agonising choices that need to be made. I found myself really caring about the charcters and wanting to do what's best for them all. This is a credit to the game designers who have done an outstanding job with designing them .

As Lee you will have limited time to read through the choices and shape the game you want to play. This game will demand a reply if only to find out what would have happened if you'd said something different at that critical moment!

Decisions I made in the first episode are coming back to haunt me even now, in the middle of episode 4!

Although there are no real brain crushing puzzels to be found, there are a few basic ones to be solved and that's fine.

The puzzles never get too trying or boring and are broken up very nicely by bludgeoning, slashing, stabbing and a general variety of very satisfying zombie kills

A great introduction to the genre and a great game in general too!

reviewText:
The Walking Dead Season 1 is an episodic movie series, ONLY it's interactive which means you're both playing a game & watching a movie at the same time.

Who Are The Developers:
This game is developed by the brilliant minds at Telltale Interactive, who not only create games but they create storybooks inside games.

About The Game:
The Walking Dead is all about choices, choices that in the end may have dire consiquences & in terms alter the games experience each playthrough and throughout it's multiple episodes.

The Review:
In Season 1 of The Walking Dead you play as the main protaganist, Lee Everett, who is on his way to prison on day 1 of the Outbreak for commiting a fellony.

Right off the bat you're thrust into the story that is both compelling to play through & complete & so  entertaining that awaiting each episode felt like what the Television series feels like while it is on break, it makes you want more & the lust of satisfication can only come from completing it as each new episode gets you even more sucked in.

The story is 100% top notch and it not only makes you feel like you have to do everything in your power to protect Lee & Clementine (the secondary protagonist in Season 1 & the main protagonist in Season 2) from harm, this game forces you upon some VERY tough decisions but expects you to make them so quickly at the same time, otherwise death is grasping you and choking the life out of you while it sinks it's teeth in to your soft neck.

During the episodes of The Walking Dead, you make choices that affect the entire game each episode & as i said early this creates a domino effect on the next episode that can either be a good thing or a bad thing, so make sure you're 100% about what choices you make.

This game creates all types of different emotions, it can create:
Suspence
Fear
Horror
Happiness
Sadness
And on the final episode can even bring your emotions so low it can induce crying in even the toughest people. (Because the final episode is so heartbreaking & you feel as if all the work you've put into the game is being let out during the last few minutes of the episode).

The Verdict:
This game is an emotinal rollercoaster & a DAMN fine interactive story at that, it is one which if you're a fan of the the TV Series or even the Comic Books you'll be wanting to buy, even if you're not into The Walking Dead and are just looking for a story driven game then this game is for you & i can 100% guarentee that. (I swear on my life!)

This game gets a 10 out of 10 from me.

Why does it get a 10 out of 10? Because it's so damn good, it has a strong story, each and every character you meet feels like they are a real person & you're in control of each and every friendship or enemy you make in this game, if you make someone a friend then you're going to be treated like a friend and that friend will come through thick or thin to save your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• if you're in need of assistance but if you make somebody an enemy then you'll feel the hate from them with every choice you make and that will make the game a lot more difficult, so choose your friends carefully.

Not only these few things but each episode brings new dangers to face & more hard decisions to make which all bring you 1 step closer to the absolutely beautiful but terribly depressing finale which will have you almost in tears (if not in tears anyway).

Do I Recommend This Game?:
Really do i need to say this? YES of course i do with 1 hand on my heart and a straight back i will stand by my purchase with this & NEVER ASK FOR MY MONEY BACK!

BRING ON SEASON 2 AND ALL IT'S EPISODES I NEED MORE!

Check Out My Review For Season 2:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Paddles01/recommended/261030/

reviewText:
The Walking Dead just an amazing adventure-horror game.
Even If i didn't watch the TV-series it was awesome.

The graphic are a little bit like a comic. Sound and atmosphere fits very good into the story. The controls are easy. The puzzle's are not so hard but also not too easy.

A game where the characters and the story is on top. The characters are well written and you will connect with them. The dialogs between them are brilliant. There are some brutal, deep & very emotional scenes.

The story is just heart touching. It changes by your choices, there are many hard ones where you need to think and you only have a certain time to choose. I don't think there is a right or wrong choice, everyone has its own and you will see the consequences later. The main story won't be affected from this choices.

The Walking Dead has one of the best storys i've ever played, better than most movies. It took me 11+ hours to finish this incredible game.

Everyone who are thinking of buying it, you will not regret it.

Thanks to Telltale Games.

Rate: 10/10

reviewText:
I wrote a recommendation when this game first came out. On the first 5 minutes, I was hooked, and I said it was a 'great game.' However, after playing to the very end, I now understand the previous recommendation did not do this game the justice it deserves. It did not even come close.

This game was brilliant. I will not reveal what happens, but the game's ending is the most heart-wrenching video game moment I have ever seen. The graphics may not be that of a 2012 game, but the pure excellence of this game is worth more than all the graphics in the world. Never have I seen a game that gives you a chance to create such a strong bond with all the characters that you meet, even the ones that didn't particularly like you. Throughout the entire story, I was on the edge of my seat, even after the last credit rolled off the screen.

With astonishing writing, compelling characters, a heart-wrenching ending, and a strong emotional consistency, this game is - without a doubt - THE best game of 2012.

Fellow gamers, whether you like zombie games or not, hear me out: play this game.

You will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead is a tremendous game story wise. The character development and cinematic gameplay exceeds other games that have tried this style of gameplay. You grow fond of your player character of the course of the episodes and his group. The biggest development is that between Lee and Clementine, who will be the player character in Season 2. There are several ways to go about completing the story, as in whether or not certain characters survive or leave, but this doesn't affect the overall plot.

One thing that did bother me were some of the animations, they seemed clunky in some areas, maybe a little bit lazy for being a game so character centric. And even though Telltale were smart with the comic book stylization to attract fans of the original comics and not the show, they could have used higher resolution textures, as the foliage and some clothing were obviously low resolution.

Overall, it's a fantastic game worthy of its acclaim.

9.0/10

reviewText:
More of an interactive movie than a game, but an excellent one at this. It's all about decisions - tough and timed decisions. The game features a group of characters where no one is a superhero, and deep down everyone of them is fragile.
The excellent storytelling really makes this game an emotional experience. When death, conflict and despair lurk around every corner, each little victory is a ray of hope that can put a smile on your face. And sometimes, when you lose someone you've gotten attached to, you might just end up with a few tears running down your cheeks.

I find it odd to say this about a zombie game, but this really is a piece of art. And a very emotional one at that. One title of the beautiful soundtrack is called Alive inside" - and this is exactly what the game is about. :)"

reviewText:
I've held back from reviewing this for awhile, guess I might as well do it now...

It's kinda obvious that I love this game thanks to the really large amount of time I played this. This game here, is without a doubt one of my favourite (if not my all-time favourite) story driven games of all time. Having been a fan of Telltale Games for a really long time (since the Sam & Max days) it's rather incredible to see how much they've grown up. I always thought to myself that after the third season of Sam & Max they hit their highest possible note, but I was wrong. They acquired some huge licenses afterwards which included Back to the Future, Jurassic Park, Fables and The Walking Dead.

I don't read the comics or watch the show at all. Despite that, I gave the game a chance thanks to how much respect I had for Telltale as well as from the critical acclaim it had been recieving. And wow, I was blown away.

The part of The Walking Dead Game that most people talk about is the characterisation of Lee Everett (the game's protagonist) and Clementine (a young girl you protect throughout the season who also serves as the moral compass) and with good reason, both of them are excellent characters. I couldn't even believe they were as likeable as they were going to be. The best part is while Lee is a blank slate for you to create the personality of, you'll always end up liking him. Because you are Lee. And you're doing what you think is right or wrong in a zombie apocalypse while also trying best to protect Clementine from the harsh world. Even if you play as Lee as a human saviour who stands for everything good left in humanity he will always be the flawed man he was before you took control of him, and that's why he is one of my favourite game characters of all time, period.

And the way the game tackles the nature of seeing what a little girl is going through growing up in an apocalypse is incredible. Clementine is one of the few children characters I've ever seen in a video game that I genuinely cared about and wanted to keep safe. Her adorable nature, innocence and hope that things will be okay is one of the things that keeps this game from being completely bleak and depressing. She is your light in the really messed up world.

Characterisation is without a doubt the most powerful thing of this game. While Lee and Clem are the most important characters in the game you will meet several, several faces that you will like/dislike. Which also, Telltale done a phenomenal job writing. There's some characters people will love, people will hate and some we will all hate (I think anyone who finished the game knows who I mean).

So in short, the game was one of the most incredible experiences I ever had. I loved every minute of it and while I had some save file issues recently (thanks to 400 Days) there's no doubt that this game is best on PC. It suffers pretty much 0 freezes and never lags when it's autosaving. Which were issues the console versions unfortunately suffered quite significantly.

Plus if you can, get 400 Days. It was a neat side-story and I have a good thought in my head that it will have an impact on Season Two in the months to come. Which FYI, started very strongly indeed.

This game isn't for everyone, it's not an action game, it's an adventure game-choose your own adventure hybrid. And I love it for that.

Buy this game, even if you think you have had a fatigue with zombies (which are not even the main concept of this game) it's already won quite a few awards, so I don't think I need to say much else other than this was the best game of 2012. Which I, 100% agree with.

reviewText: I can't say it enough. GET A PROJECTOR!! It will change your gaming life!!!! This game was nice, BUT, it was so much better on my wall! Games like this one, Jurassic Park & The Wolf Among Us, with huge storylines and limited interaction possibilities would be better enjoyed with the picture as great as you can make it! Yes I have imported my decisions into season 2 (mass effect), I played the DLC, & am excited to hear of further upcoming seasons. The main protagonist, an african-american man, is a romantic, and easy to like, although he won't (can't) continue beyond this season. I am still getting used to the idea of playing a little girl (Clementine) in season 2. As a story, and played through the projector on my wall, I liked this game, HINTING that without doing that my enjoyment as much as I did now may have been reduced by HALF! So yes that big-picture made a difference! Nice.

reviewText:
This is the first Telltale game I have ever played, and it definitely was not what I expected.  Given their previous games and despite the subject matter, I was not expecting such a dark game but they pulled it off very well.  I can't think of any other game I have played that gives the player such difficult decisions to make and they do have a significant impact on the story later on.  The storytelling and voice acting is fantastic, as I would expect.

Graphically, the game really isn't great.  It is styled to look like the comics, but many of the textures are absurdly low resolution for a modern game which hurts the visible detail.  It's passable though and not really the focus of the game.

The gameplay is a bit of a mixed bag for me.  While I do like the innovative way they deal with many struggle" events with a cursor that appears in a random place

reviewText:
Cold, cruel, dark... how do I describe this game? No, this story? I just hope for one thing, and that is that no one has to ever experience the kind of emotional suffering involved for people in real life with real life decisions like choosing between lives to save or between your own welfare and your children's. No human should have to be forced to make those kinds of decisions. But that is exactly what this game forces you to do. Sure, you can stay silent during conversations, but you'll lose all respect.

I played all five episodes, one each day, and I've just finished the last one. And I feel like I really don't want to play another Season. This game is not hard, it's brutal. I think about things like the apocalypse a lot, like what a world full of the living dead will be like, or a world where only you are alive. This game had me questioning, as I still do, the worth and value of human existence in times of prolonged suffering. Is there hope? Real hope? Or is that simply a mental mechanism to keep going and find a reason, however illogical, to keep living. What is the purpose of life, what are we living for? To raise up children, to just enjoy ourselves, to keep moving towards the inevitability of death? However unreal and farcical you may think a zombie apocalypse is, it acts as a compelling context for life questions.

And not just that. It serves to seek out how we might react in a certain situation. Everyone has different personalities, and I'm sure you'd agree with me when I suggest that in this modern society, it's difficult to really know someone within a few days of meeting them. But when the world goes to absolute sh*t, there is no need for false impressions anymore. You can see people pretty square on. I had my brain in agony deciding, at times, what to say. I found myself trying to protect Clementine as much as I could. I realised her deepest desire was to see her parents, and I kept that in mind. I tried to save whoever I could. I saw people as humans, I saw them beneath their often capricious personalities (Kenny, Larry, Lilly - heh, even me sometimes). I tried to keep a level head all the time, and I guess that goes with my own underlying scepticism of life, held together by vocally agreeing with people who are good by their actions. I defined good as judging people not by what I or even our group needs, but by what the person being judged actually says they need. I could cite several situations, but I note this is a review, for those yet to buy the game.

I'm glad, now looking at the game as a whole, that TellTale didn't do a 'Last of Us'. Not only is this game true to the comic book foundations of TWD, but it meant that more resources can go into making a fantastic decision-based story that feels so real and just draws you into it. Yes, you are not Lee Everett, you don't have his history, his family, or even his words (talking about the choices of dialogue you get), but it's close enough to identifying what kind of a person YOU are, because each dialogue option takes a certain philosophy and moral direction. Mostly, I was consistent, but sometimes, such as with Larry, I blew. I could talk a lot about what this game teaches you, or has taught me, but I must restrain myself, knowing not to let a review become an essay in philosophical thought.

I haven't played anything like this before. It's different, and it's intelligent, and it will make you, yes, force you, to really think about what you say and do.

reviewText:
I finally played the entire game and the entire DLC and now I can finally make a review. I will be separating my review, focusing first on the game itself, and then the DLC.

MY THOUGHTS ON THE GAME
I was introduced to Telltale by a friend on mine, who loved zombies and had also played Law & Order: Legacies. We both thought the games looked cool and the idea of being responsible for your own choices sounded amazing.
The Walking Dead was a game I also wanted to play because of the TV show and let me tell you right here that there are no connections between the two. Sure, the creators thought it would be cool to add Glenn in the first episode, but excluding the zombie plot, the show and this game are two different things (and that is actually a pro).

The Walking dead has a specific look that in a sense reminds me of comics, however they are still appealing. And when it comes to gore, the comic-looking design still works, which is an amazing plus. Although it doesn't have, in my opinion, the best design/graphics I've ever seen, it's still quite atractive to look at.

In terms of how the game works itself, as you can easily see in any review of this game, if you're hoping for a game where you can get some guns and blow some heads while you walk around Georgia, then you are wrong. Although there are some fighting scenes and the interaction exists in the entire game (you move characters, make them click stuff, etc.), this is a story-driven game, where the plot moves according to your choices. More than playing a game, you're watching a story. And for those who watch the show and like it's heavy/depressed tone, this game has it too.

But how are the choices? Do you REALLY choose? Well, I haven't played many other games where your choices define the story so I dare say you do REALLY choose. But I must also advise you this is a game and being such, it has limitations. Meaning sometimes you might choose the words or other paths but some destinations are the same. This isn't necessarily bad, it still influences on the relations between characters and it still changes situations, so I wouldn't get too worked up about it. Even if it's not perfect, it's still a good game.

PROS
- nice and easy interface. If you've used a computer before, you can play this.
- interesting design/graphics
- strong plot that will very likely make you look for your tissues

reviewText:
This game/interactive novel is based on the same universe as the comics and TV series with the same name. However it follows the timelines of a different bunch of people instead of focusing on Rick Grimes which is the main character in both comic and TV series.

The main inspiration for this franchise is Robert Kirkman and as stated from his first 'walking dead' comic onwards, the main focus of this zombie apocalypse story was to explore how 'messed up we all are' and that basically everyone when exposed to extreme situations, everyone eventually changes into a blurry monster bent on survival. Those that don't change/adapt according to Robert Kirkman's universe do not survive. Any sense of needing to be 'civilised' is an inconvenient illusion in this world, which since it is also no longer hindered by fear of potential punishment from God or government, mankind in general will shrink back to its primal instinct.

This moral dilemma of what the world was and what the world now is; is what the franchise plays on. In both Comic and TV series it does this by following the time line Of Rick Grimes a police officer, with an inbuilt sense of right and wrong because of his occupation. Eventually as time goes on Rick loses all this morality and justifies perverse actions as a necessity for survival or justice. In this game however it does the same thing in a slightly different fashion. It follows the time line of Lee a convicted murderer who is trying his hardest to protect the innocence of Clementine an orphaned child, while at the same time give her the necessities to survive by herself if needs be without it corrupting her innocence.

The inspiration behind this notion that 'we are all monsters' comes from the various bloody genocides that have often plagued our history such as Rwanda, Hutu and Tutsi, World War 1 and 2 etc. The game therefore goes out of its way to expose this potential monster not just in the general characters of the game, but also in you the gamer too. It does this in a number of ways. First it gives you various moral dilemma‚Äôs such as to choose between saving one person or the other, or to maim a person forever in order to keep them alive in general, or to let someone suicide or not. While the game gives you the illusion that your choice matters, it doesn't. Whatever choice you make there will be faulty reasoning attached, and the cost of that decision will always be high against someone else. The game therefore will tell you off for whatever choice you make exposing that you may not be innocent or guilt-free. Secondly regardless of how you much you try and protect the innocence of Clementine, Clementine will be forced to make a decision in the end which will change her innocence forever and lastly a decision which may have seemed trivial in the middle of the game ends up being the most crucial decision in the end and it will come back and haunt you to show how many people have died or suffered because of your ignorance. Thankfully this message is delivered in a fashion which is palatable largely because the character that is condemning and exposing your inconsistencies is someone a few sandwiches short of a picnic themselves...

Since the game is largely focused on the human psyche more so, than it is on its story elements as a zombie apocalypse, the game will never go on to explain the outbreak? It will never explain why the virus only affects humans and not animals? It will not explain where it originated or if there is a cure? The only thing that the game explains is that all humans have it and it is only activated when a person is bit or when they die naturally. Therefore the title 'The Walking Dead' is not referring to the zombies; it's actually referring to the survivors. Since they all have the virus they are the 'Walking Dead' prolonging the inevitable.

Personally I do not agree with Robert Kirkman's notion that we are all potentially monsters and those that aren't would be somewhat disadvantaged against those that are. The notion 'survival of the fittest' also applies to things like stealth and charisma and even in the most bloodiest times of human history, the importance to survive with one's morals intact is just as important to some people as survival itself. This has boosted some people's ability to survive such moments in history relatively unscathed of bloodguilt or wrongdoing. Also Kirkman fails to note the length that some guilty parties have gone too to protect those that are still innocent. In all times of human's bloodiest history the miracle of innocence has always survived somewhere.

This game also highlights one of the biggest faults behind Kirkman's notion of an ongoing zombie apocalypse. In one of the episodes the survivors come across a zombie so weak that it cannot even support its own body weight to move. Since the Zombies would require a constant source of fresh meat, within a week the zombie population would be starved and unable to support itself. Hence even in Kirkman's world, stealth would be way more practical than tyrannical thinking.

The game since it is adult in nature has many scenes which are not suitable for children. There is one situation where you‚Äôre required to cave in a zombie skull with a hammer or another scene where you are required to cut off someone's leg from a bear trap. There is also a large amount of course language in the game too.

The storyboard is probably one of the game's best attributes and the cartoon is quite stylish in its rendering. There are constantly things to do in the game which break up the monotony of the reading novel aspects, though it is constantly accompanied by top notch voice acting and a well envisioned musical score.

In final, it is a game where you cannot escape making perverse actions, but you can choose how your character feels about those actions. A game recommended for those that do not mind adult content. Not recommended for those that do.

reviewText:
I finally played the entire game and the entire DLC and now I can finally make a review. I will be separating my review, focusing first on the game itself, and then the DLC.

MY THOUGHTS ON THE GAME
I was introduced to Telltale by a friend on mine, who loved zombies and had also played Law & Order: Legacies. We both thought the games looked cool and the idea of being responsible for your own choices sounded amazing.
The Walking Dead was a game I also wanted to play because of the TV show and let me tell you right here that there are no connections between the two. Sure, the creators thought it would be cool to add Glenn in the first episode, but excluding the zombie plot, the show and this game are two different things (and that is actually a pro).

The Walking dead has a specific look that in a sense reminds me of comics, however they are still appealing. And when it comes to gore, the comic-looking design still works, which is an amazing plus. Although it doesn't have, in my opinion, the best design/graphics I've ever seen, it's still quite atractive to look at.

In terms of how the game works itself, as you can easily see in any review of this game, if you're hoping for a game where you can get some guns and blow some heads while you walk around Georgia, then you are wrong. Although there are some fighting scenes and the interaction exists in the entire game (you move characters, make them click stuff, etc.), this is a story-driven game, where the plot moves according to your choices. More than playing a game, you're watching a story. And for those who watch the show and like it's heavy/depressed tone, this game has it too.

But how are the choices? Do you REALLY choose? Well, I haven't played many other games where your choices define the story so I dare say you do REALLY choose. But I must also advise you this is a game and being such, it has limitations. Meaning sometimes you might choose the words or other paths but some destinations are the same. This isn't necessarily bad, it still influences on the relations between characters and it still changes situations, so I wouldn't get too worked up about it. Even if it's not perfect, it's still a good game.

PROS
- nice and easy interface. If you've used a computer before, you can play this.
- interesting design/graphics
- strong plot that will very likely make you look for your tissues
- the story is REALLY interesting - I almost felt like I was watching a tv show while still making decisions about it.

CONS
- some episodes are more stronger than others (altough this is highly subjective)
- although you make choices, sometimes you will still be led to the same path

MY THOUGHTS ABOUT THE DLC
When the DLC was announced my first thought was: oh my god
date: I have to play it because otherwise I won't understand a thing about season two!". Then a friend of mine actually told me the DLC was totally irrelevant to the story and I wasn't sure what to do. Eventually

- same decision making
- introduces small stories about new characters that are in some ways connected
- some references to season 1

CONS
- the references to season 1 are funny but that's about it. You hear about the fate of one or two characters

reviewText: 10/10\n\nIt is an incredible game. If you came here because you either read the comics or watch the AMC Walking Dead on TV, it is just as good! The story is incredible, providing some funny, scary and sad moments that will just tie you to the rest of the game. Be prepared for this emotional story though, just like the comics and tv series universe, it's quite good at making you cry, but it's totally worth it.

reviewText:
One of the most enjoyable, unique and impressive games I've ever played. It's emotional, epic, involving, fun and so in-depth with regards to the characters and the revolutionised choice-based plot.

The way Lee comes across entirely depends on you, as does the relationship with the people you are stuck with/chose to survive along with you. Very clever and heart-wrenching. The final scenes had me welling up and the last time I did that over a game was, like, 8 years ago.

I'd recommend this to anyone and everyone. If you want a standard 'run around and shoot zombies using two brain-cells' game then don't expect that here, but do expect something different and a million times better. It just should be exerienced.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An absolutely unbelieveable game. The Walking dead is the epitome of games; everything about this game is perfect, be it the story or gameplay - it's perfect.

Even moreso is the fact that you actually care what Clementine, a person who doesn't even exist, thinks about you is just plain amazing. I never once thought about whether or not I was hurting somebody close to me in a video game yet Clementine somehow made me care.

10/10 - I only hope this is enough to make Clementine happy!

reviewText:
Point-n'-click and decision based games are awesome when done properly, and now, mix both and add zombies to the result?
You can really feel empathy for the characters in the game, plus, it's obviously NOT the kind of games where you can go out murdering hundreds of zombies playing as an OP character, this is sort of realistic.

.........Plus, it's way better thant the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• TV series, with a MUCH faster pace.
